title: Agreement between the EU and the USA on the processing and transfer of financial messaging data from the EU to the USA for purposes of the Terrorist Finance Tracking Program: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the United States of America on the processing and transfer of Financial Messaging Data from the European Union to the United States for the purposes of the Terrorist Finance Tracking Program
background: Following the 2010 rejection of an interim EU-US Terrorist Finance Tracking Program agreement over data privacy concerns, negotiations resumed under Lisbon Treaty provisions enhancing parliamentary oversight. The Parliament will discuss revised terms for transatlantic financial data transfers addressing counterterrorism cooperation, data protection safeguards, and sovereignty implications.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the agreement’s balance between counterterrorism objectives and data protection safeguards, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to upholding Article 8 of the EU Charter while ensuring security.  
EPP applauds the institutional progress under the Lisbon Treaty, particularly Parliament’s strengthened oversight role, which effectively advances their priority of democratic accountability in transatlantic cooperation.  
EPP proposes formalizing a timeline for the Commission to nominate the three independent oversight candidates within 60 days, enhancing procedural transparency without opposing the issue’s core framework.  
EPP commends the integration of EU-based data supervision mechanisms, reflecting their manifesto pledge to assert European jurisdictional control over sensitive financial messaging transfers.  
EPP emphasizes the urgency of establishing a parallel EU Terrorist Finance Tracking Programme, as foreseen in the issue’s inter-parliamentary dialogue clause, to further reduce reliance on third-country systems.

GREEN_EFA rejects the agreement as fundamentally incompatible with EU fundamental rights standards, particularly regarding bulk data transfers without independent judicial authorization.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the reliance on Europol for authorization under Article 12(1), which contradicts their demand for oversight by a fully independent judicial body rather than a law enforcement agency.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the failure to prohibit five-year data retention periods, directly conflicting with their principle of data minimization and proportionality under Article 8 of the EU Charter.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the absence of actionable redress mechanisms for EU citizens in U.S. courts, rendering the agreement's safeguards legally unenforceable against intelligence agencies.  
GREEN_EFA warns that the U.S. definition of terrorism risks misuse against civil society groups, undermining their commitment to preventing mission creep in counterterrorism frameworks.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the conclusion of the Agreement between the EU and the United States on the processing and transfer of Financial Messaging Data for the Terrorist Finance Tracking Program, aimed at combating terrorism and terrorist financing. It emphasized compliance with fundamental rights, particularly Article 8 of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, requiring independent oversight of personal data. The resolution called on the Commission to propose three candidates for the role of an independent EU person to monitor data control under Article 12(1) of the Agreement, aligning the selection process with the procedure for appointing the European Data Protection Supervisor under Regulation (EC) No 45/2001. Additionally, Parliament instructed its President to communicate its position to relevant EU and U.S. institutions and to initiate inter-parliamentary dialogue with U.S. legislative bodies on future data protection frameworks, ensuring ongoing scrutiny and cooperation. The resolution underscored the need for robust safeguards, independent oversight, and transparency in transatlantic data transfers while supporting counterterrorism objectives.

title: Amendment of Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 listing the third countries whose nationals must be in possession of visas when crossing the external borders of Member States and those whose nationals are exempt from that requirement: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 listing the third countries whose nationals must be in possession of visas when crossing the external borders of Member States and those whose nationals are exempt from that requirement
background: Taiwan, a developed democracy with high per capita income and low irregular migration rates, maintained visa exemptions for most EU Member States, while other listed third countries faced visa requirements. The Parliament will discuss amending EU visa regulations to transfer Taiwan and several Caribbean and Pacific states to the exemption list, addressing regional coherence and reciprocity.

stances.stance:
EFD supports the visa exemption for Taiwanese nationals, emphasizing their historical alignment with Western principles of liberty and human rights as consistent with EU values.  
EFD advises enhancing preemptive security evaluations for visa liberalization with Bosnia and Herzegovina, Albania, and Turkey, proposing amended criteria to prioritize Member State safety assurances.  
EFD highlights Taiwan’s successful societal integration and absence of conflicting ideological exports as a model for third-country visa policy coherence.  
EFD requests the Commission formally consult Parliament on future visa waiver expansions to uphold transparency, per Article 294 procedural safeguards.  
EFD stresses the issue must rigorously apply existing EU conditionality frameworks to all beneficiary states, ensuring parity in human rights and security assessments.

SD strongly sanctions the visa waiver for Taiwan as a strategic enhancement of EU-Asia relations, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to fostering international mobility and economic cooperation.  
SD approves the reciprocity measures ensuring all Member States benefit, proposing enhanced Commission monitoring to address ongoing disparities with other third-country agreements.  
SD emphasizes the issue's alignment with fundamental rights principles, particularly in advancing youth exchange programs and academic mobility opportunities with Taiwan.  
SD welcomes Taiwan's democratic progress and security standards as meeting EU benchmarks, effectively advancing SD's priority of promoting governance reforms through partnership incentives.  
SD suggests expanding the Commission's biannual review mechanism to include comparative analysis of visa reciprocity across all external partner states without opposing the current framework.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a Commission proposal (COM(2010)0358) concerning measures under Article 77(2)(a) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which relates to border checks and free movement. The resolution, informed by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and the Committee on Foreign Affairs, adopted Parliament’s first-reading stance, urging the Commission to prioritize coherence with existing EU policies and respect for fundamental rights. It emphasized the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments or alternative texts to ensure legislative transparency and democratic oversight. The resolution further directed the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing institutional collaboration and adherence to EU legislative procedures under Article 294 of the Treaty.

title: European Border Surveillance System (EUROSUR): REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council Establishing the European Border Surveillance System (EUROSUR)
background: Persistent irregular migration flows, cross-border criminal activity, and recurring migrant fatalities in the Mediterranean, alongside fragmented border surveillance mechanisms among EU member states, prompted calls for enhanced coordination. The Parliament will discuss establishing a unified border surveillance framework to improve situational awareness, operational cooperation, and crisis response at EU external borders.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the establishment of EUROSUR as a critical tool to enhance real-time border surveillance, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to securing Europe’s external borders while preventing migrant tragedies through advanced monitoring technologies.  
EPP approves the integration of satellite systems and interagency cooperation frameworks, which effectively advance EPP’s priority of combating human trafficking networks and improving crisis response coordination across member states.  
EPP emphasizes the need to accelerate operational deployment of EUROSUR, proposing amendments to Article 17 bis to ensure Schengen integrity by requiring unanimous Council approval for non-Schengen state participation, thereby addressing procedural concerns without opposing the system’s core objectives.  
EPP highlights EUROSUR’s potential to save lives through early detection of migrant vessels, urging immediate budgetary reinforcement for Frontex and expanded maritime patrols to operationalize this commitment.  
EPP applauds the issue’s focus on third-country partnerships as matching EPP’s 2023 manifesto goals, particularly in enhancing Tunisian cooperation to disrupt smuggling routes and strengthen pre-embarkation monitoring.

GUE_NGL absolutely disputes the EUROSUR proposal as it prioritizes migrant surveillance over humanitarian obligations, directly conflicting with their commitment to human rights and refugee protection.  
GUE_NGL rejects Article 1’s focus on border control measures, which they argue institutionalizes the criminalization of migration instead of addressing systemic causes of displacement.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as allocating resources to life-saving operations, instead funneling funds into security infrastructure that exacerbates migrant vulnerabilities.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s failure to mandate rescue missions as a core objective, rendering it incompatible with international humanitarian law and solidarity principles.  
This framework perpetuates a border militarization agenda inconsistent with GUE_NGL’s demands for equitable development aid and refugee resettlement programs over deterrence-based policies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0873) concerning legislative measures under Article 77(2)(d) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, adopting its first-reading stance and approving an annexed statement outlining its views. It emphasized the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments or alternative texts, ensuring procedural accountability. The resolution incorporated input from the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and the Committee on Budgets (A7-0232/2013), while addressing concerns from the Swedish Parliament regarding compliance with subsidiarity principles. Parliament instructed its President to transmit its formal position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing inter-institutional communication and adherence to legislative protocols.

title: European Investigation Order: REPORT on the draft directive of the European Parliament and of the Council regarding the European Investigation Order in criminal matters
background: Increasing cross-border crime within the EU's open borders exposed gaps in judicial cooperation, prompting calls to modernize mutual legal assistance frameworks amid fragmented implementation of prior instruments. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing cross-border criminal investigations through a standardized evidence-gathering mechanism to address transnational security challenges.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects the European Investigation Order as entirely conflicting with national sovereignty, citing the erosion of Britain's historic legal safeguards like habeas corpus and trial by jury.  
EFD opposes the issue's harmonization agenda, arguing it prioritizes EU integration over justice by expanding flawed mechanisms like the European Arrest Warrant that enable prolonged detentions without case-ready evidence.  
EFD condemns the UK government's partial opt-in to EU criminal measures as a betrayal, demanding full withdrawal to protect citizens from "foreign police overreach" under Article 3 investigative powers.  
EFD highlights contradictions with procedural rights, noting the issue fails to address presumption of innocence violations where extradited individuals face pretrial detention without conclusive evidence.  
EFD asserts existing mutual legal assistance treaties suffice for cross-border cooperation, rendering the directive an unnecessary step toward centralized EU justice systems incompatible with British law.

GREEN_EFA strongly upholds the European Investigation Order proposal as a proportional alternative to coercive measures like the Arrest Warrant, aligning perfectly with their commitment to minimizing state overreach in judicial cooperation.  
GREEN_EFA approves the inclusion of proportionality assessments and fundamental rights exceptions in the Investigation Order framework, effectively advancing their priority of preventing abusive cross-border detentions.  
GREEN_EFA proposes extending Article 82(1)(a) to mandate equivalent proportionality tests and prison condition evaluations for the European Arrest Warrant, ensuring consistent safeguards across judicial instruments.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s emphasis on legal clarity and defendant rights as critical to rebuilding mutual trust, matching their manifesto goals for humane justice systems.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the urgency of revising the Arrest Warrant’s implementation mechanisms within one year to prevent further rights violations, reinforcing the need for enforceable accountability in cross-border cases.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to enhance judicial cooperation in criminal matters across EU member states by harmonizing procedural safeguards, based on the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (Articles 76(b) and 82(1)(a)) and a 2010 initiative from member states (09288/2010). The resolution, informed by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs report (A7-0477/2013), emphasized strengthening mutual trust and legal consistency by ensuring minimum rights for suspects and defendants, such as access to legal advice, interpretation, and information about their rights. It called for aligning national laws with EU standards to facilitate cross-border cooperation while safeguarding fundamental rights, reflecting the Parliament’s commitment to a unified legal framework in justice and home affairs.

title: EU citizenship for sale: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on EU citizenship for sale
background: Several EU member states introduced investor programs granting residency or citizenship to third-country nationals, enabling access to Schengen mobility and EU rights, with Malta’s 2013 citizenship scheme lacking residency requirements, prompting concerns over market distortions, security risks, and compatibility with EU principles. The Parliament will discuss implications of citizenship-by-investment schemes on EU values.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the issue's condemnation of citizenship commodification, aligning perfectly with EPP's commitment to preserving EU citizenship as a bond of shared values rather than financial transaction.  
EPP totally approves the demand for Malta to revise its program, echoing Manfred Weber's call to halt legislation that undermines residency requirements and genuine societal ties.  
EPP proposes enhancing due diligence protocols in Article 4 to include mandatory pre-approval consultations with Frontex and Europol, strengthening security safeguards against money laundering risks.  
EPP applauds the emphasis on citizenship integrity as articulated by Roberta Metsola, affirming that EU rights must reflect human dignity rather than wealth-based privileges.  
EPP strongly approves Carlos Coelho's distinction between residency permits and citizenship schemes, urging treaty-aligned guidelines to prevent fragmented national practices from eroding free movement principles.

ECR rejects the issue’s push for EU-wide oversight of citizenship schemes, asserting that such interference completely opposes with ECR’s defense of national sovereignty in determining citizenship criteria under treaty provisions.  
ECR opposes the issue’s security risk narrative, arguing it overlooks critical aspects of existing anti-money laundering frameworks and member states’ capacity to vet applicants independently without supranational mandates.  
ECR condemns the issue’s singling out of Malta as discriminatory, emphasizing that unilateral citizenship policies align with ECR’s principle of fiscal autonomy and sovereign equality among member states.  
ECR disputes the claim that investment-based citizenship erodes EU integrity, highlighting the proposal’s failure to acknowledge economic benefits and its contradiction with ECR’s advocacy for market-driven national solutions.  
ECR rejects the issue’s loyalty concerns around dual citizenship, noting it ignores global precedents and ECR’s stance on protecting individual freedoms in transnational contexts.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over certain EU Member States, particularly Malta, enabling third-country nationals to obtain citizenship or residency through investment schemes, which effectively commodify EU citizenship and undermine mutual trust and shared values. It highlighted that such practices, including Malta’s citizenship-for-sale program lacking residency or tax obligations, risk security (e.g., money laundering), distort housing markets, and discriminate by privileging wealth over genuine ties to Europe. The resolution stressed that EU citizenship, conferring free movement, voting rights, and consular protection, must not be tradable and should reflect human dignity and responsibilities, not financial transactions. It urged Member States to align national schemes with EU values, called on the Commission to assess compliance with treaties and Schengen rules, and demanded Malta revise its program. The Parliament emphasized the need for guidelines to prevent citizenship and residency schemes from eroding EU integrity, while acknowledging national competence in citizenship matters but urging caution to avoid harmful side-effects.

title: EU-Australia agreement on the processing and transfer of PNR data: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and Australia on the processing and transfer of Passenger Name Record (PNR) data by air carriers to the Australian Customs and Border Protection Service
background: The European Union and Australia established a 2008 agreement on Passenger Name Record data transfers, with the Commission proposing a global framework in 2010 to standardize such agreements. Australia sought updated terms aligning with evolving EU data protection laws under the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU and the Charter of Fundamental Rights. The Parliament will discuss the revised agreement’s compliance with data protection standards and transnational security cooperation.

stances.stance:
ECR strongly endorses the EU-Australia PNR Agreement, emphasizing its critical role in combating serious crimes such as terrorism and human trafficking while ensuring data protection aligns with fundamental rights.  
ECR highlights the agreement's balance between security imperatives and civil liberties, reflecting their commitment to both public safety and individual freedoms.  
ECR endorses the updated framework as a necessary evolution from the 2008 agreement, enhancing transcontinental security cooperation without opposing its core principles.  
ECR applauds the proportionality measures in the issue, which align with their longstanding advocacy for effective yet rights-conscious law enforcement tools.  
ECR proposes strengthening periodic reviews of data retention protocols to ensure ongoing compliance with EU Charter standards, framing this as an enhancement opportunity rather than opposition.

GUE_NGL rejects the agreement as it firmly opposes with their opposition to mass surveillance and indiscriminate data retention prohibited under EU fundamental rights frameworks.  
GUE_NGL opposes the five-and-a-half-year data storage period, arguing this enables profiling practices that violate Articles 7 and 8 of the EU Charter by treating all passengers as criminal suspects.  
GUE_NGL challenges the issue's proportionality claims, noting the absence of proven operational necessity for bulk PNR transfers as required under Article 16 TFEU.  
GUE_NGL warns the agreement sets dangerous precedents for future data-sharing pacts with third countries like the US, where oversight mechanisms are weaker than Australia's customs authority.  
GUE_NGL condemns the transformation of air travelers into surveillance subjects as incompatible with their core principles of defending civil liberties against security overreach.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the EU-Australia Agreement on the transfer and processing of Passenger Name Record (PNR) data, aimed at enhancing security cooperation by enabling air carriers to share passenger data with Australian authorities. It acknowledged the replacement of the 2008 PNR Agreement with the updated version, thereby rendering the prior legislative procedure (2009/0186(NLE)) obsolete. The resolution emphasized alignment with fundamental rights under Article 16 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and Articles 7 and 8 of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, ensuring data protection and proportionality. It referenced prior resolutions and communications, including the Commission’s 2010 global approach to PNR transfers, to contextualize the agreement within broader EU efforts to standardize data-sharing frameworks with third countries. The Parliament instructed its President to communicate its approval to the EU Council, Commission, member states, and Australia, finalizing the adoption process.

title: Extension of the scope of Directive 2003/109/EC to beneficiaries of international protection: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2003/109/EC to extend its scope to beneficiaries of international protection
background: Directive 2003/109/EC initially excluded beneficiaries of international protection from long-term EU residence rights, despite a 2007 Commission proposal for inclusion. Post-Lisbon Treaty institutional changes and prior unsuccessful Council negotiations highlighted legal disparities. The Parliament will discuss amending the directive to extend eligibility to refugees and subsidiary protection holders.

stances.stance:
EPP completely agrees the harmonization of long-term residence rights for refugees and subsidiary protection beneficiaries, perfectly aligning with their commitment to a unified European asylum system.  
EPP applauds the elimination of differential treatment through this directive, advancing their priority of equitable integration for legally residing third-country nationals.  
EPP recognizes the critical safeguards against refoulement in cross-border mobility provisions, ensuring protection continuity across Member States.  
EPP highlights the issue’s reinforcement of interinstitutional cooperation under Lisbon Treaty frameworks as exemplary for future asylum policy development.  
EPP acknowledges the symbolic recognition of frontline states’ challenges while maintaining full support for the five-year residence threshold as a balanced compromise.

GREEN_EFA strongly agrees extending long-term residence rights to refugees as a critical step toward ending precarious legal statuses, aligning perfectly with their commitment to dignified migration systems.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s focus on harmonizing integration pathways across member states, effectively advancing their priority of eliminating discriminatory mobility barriers.  
GREEN_EFA approves the rapporteur’s emphasis on cross-border comparison mechanisms, which empower beneficiaries like Mamuth to pursue meaningful reintegration opportunities.  
GREEN_EFA proposes amending Article 15 to mandate biannual reporting on nationality grant timelines, enhancing transparency without opposing the directive’s core objectives.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the urgency of implementing these reforms to prevent prolonged administrative limbo for protection holders, as exemplified in the Greek case study.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal concerning the EC Treaty and the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, specifically addressing Articles 294(3), 79(2)(a), and 79(2)(b), which relate to legal migration and institutional procedures. It adopted its stance at first reading, emphasizing alignment with the Commission’s 2007 proposal and the 2009 Communication on the implications of the Lisbon Treaty’s entry into force for ongoing interinstitutional processes. The resolution underscored the Council’s 2010 commitment to approve Parliament’s position under Article 294(4) and called on the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if intending substantial amendments, ensuring procedural continuity. Parliament instructed its President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing institutional cooperation and adherence to EU legislative frameworks.

title: An EU approach to criminal law: REPORT on an EU approach on criminal law
background: The EU's evolving criminal law competences under the TFEU, including judicial cooperation provisions and Article 83's framework for harmonizing offenses, alongside the Commission's 2011 policy communication, have prompted efforts to balance cross-border crime challenges with national legal diversity. The Parliament will discuss establishing a coherent EU approach to substantive criminal law harmonization.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the issue’s adherence to subsidiarity and proportionality, aligning perfectly with their commitment to preserving Member States’ legal traditions while enhancing cross-border judicial cooperation.  
EPP applauds the emphasis on fundamental rights and *lex certa* principles, effectively advancing their priority of maintaining robust procedural safeguards in EU criminal law.  
EPP proposes developing a conceptual framework to systematize procedural principles before operational tools like the European Investigation Order, ensuring coherence with *ultima ratio* requirements.  
EPP endorses harmonization as indispensable for combating transnational crime, matching their security-focused agenda to unify enforcement while respecting national diversity.  
EPP emphasizes rigorous impact assessments and inter-institutional coordination, reinforcing their stance on evidence-based, proportionate criminal law measures.

EFD rejects fundamentally the EU criminal law framework as incompatible with national sovereignty and centuries-old common law protections like habeas corpus.  
EFD opposes the mutual recognition regime for enabling extradition without proper judicial oversight, directly contradicting Magna Carta principles cited in Article 83 TFEU applications.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as irreconcilable differences between continental civil law systems and Britain's precedent-based judiciary, rendering harmonization attempts legally destructive.  
EFD condemns the issue's presumption of EU-level necessity as a false premise, asserting domestic laws already sufficiently address cross-border crimes without supranational overreach.  
This framework firmly againsts with EFD's core doctrine that criminal justice must remain exclusively national to preserve constitutional safeguards against arbitrary detention.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need for EU criminal law to adhere strictly to subsidiarity, proportionality, and respect for Member States’ legal traditions, emphasizing that criminal measures must be a last resort (*ultima ratio*) targeting conduct causing significant societal or individual harm with a cross-border dimension or direct impact on EU policies. It stressed that EU criminal legislation must respect fundamental rights, including the presumption of innocence, legal certainty (*lex certa*), non-retroactivity, and the principle of individual guilt (*nulla poena sine culpa*), while allowing corporate liability in exceptional cases. The resolution highlighted the necessity of factual evidence to justify criminal provisions, requiring proof that less intrusive measures are insufficient, offenses are serious and widespread, and sanctions are proportionate under Article 49(3) of the EU Charter. It called for harmonization to support mutual recognition of judicial decisions, urging coherent enforcement of existing laws, uniform minimum standards for suspects’ rights, and non-legislative measures to build trust among Member States. The Parliament criticized fragmented approaches, advocating for inter-institutional coordination via agreements and working groups to ensure quality, consistency, and reduced conflicts in EU criminal law. It demanded rigorous Commission impact assessments, alignment with principles like necessity and proportionality, and enhanced parliamentary oversight through legal analyses of proposals. References to Treaty provisions (e.g., Article 83 TFEU) underscored the legal basis for EU action while respecting national criminal justice systems.

title: Application of Schengen acquis in Bulgaria and Romania: REPORT on the draft Council decision on the full application of the provisions of the Schengen acquis in the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania
background: Bulgaria and Romania, EU members since 2007, were subject to post-accession evaluation processes under the Schengen acquis, focusing on border controls, data protection, and judicial cooperation. Technical readiness assessments confirmed compliance with Schengen standards, while broader governance concerns persisted among some member states. The Parliament will discuss the Council decision on their full Schengen integration.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly accepts Bulgaria and Romania's Schengen accession as a vital step toward European free movement principles, aligning perfectly with their commitment to border justice.  
GREEN_EFA approves the issue's procedural accountability measures, urging strict Council adherence to parliamentary reconsultation protocols under Rule 55 to enhance institutional transparency.  
GREEN_EFA proposes maintaining the cooperation and verification mechanism post-accession as a confidence-building measure, transforming initial concerns into sustained governance improvements.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes eliminating evaluation double standards between existing and new Schengen states, ensuring acquis compliance aligns with their equality-focused manifesto commitments.  
GREEN_EFA firmly defends Parliament's decision-making role, rejecting any Council attempts to alter legal bases that would diminish democratic oversight in enlargement processes.

ECR opposes fundamentally the inclusion of Bulgaria and Romania in Schengen, citing unresolved deficiencies in border security and organized crime compliance.  
ECR rejects the proposal as a threat to non-Schengen states, highlighting risks of increased illegal migration to countries like the UK through "leaky" borders.  
ECR argues the issue overlooks critical demands for corruption impact assessments and Europol involvement in Schengen evaluations.  
 ECR member Paweł Robert Kowal's support for accession contradicts the group's stance, indicating internal divisions on Schengen criteria.  
The proposal totally disputes with ECR's principle that Schengen integrity requires rigorous evaluations of crime impacts, not just technical readiness.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval of the amended draft Council decision (14142/2010), emphasizing procedural accountability by urging the Council to formally notify Parliament if it deviates from the approved text and to reconsult Parliament should it propose substantial amendments to its draft decision. The resolution, informed by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice, and Home Affairs’ report (A7-0185/2011), underscored institutional cooperation by instructing the Parliament’s President to communicate its position to the Council and the Commission, ensuring alignment under Article 4(2) of the 2005 Act of Accession while adhering to procedural Rule 55.

title: Application of the provisions of the Schengen acquis relating to the Schengen Information System in Bulgaria and Romania: REPORT on the draft Council decision on the application of the provisions of the Schengen acquis relating to the Schengen Information System in the Republic of Bulgaria and Romania
background: Following Bulgaria and Romania’s 2007 EU accession, both initiated Schengen integration, requiring compliance with Schengen acquis provisions on data protection and SIS. The Council conducted evaluations assessing their readiness. The Parliament will discuss the draft Council decision on applying these provisions to enable SIS implementation.

stances.stance:
EFD entirely disapproves expanding SIS access to Bulgaria and Romania, citing unresolved security vulnerabilities that contradict EFD's insistence on rigorous border control standards.  
EFD rejects the financial burden implied for non-Schengen states like the UK, conflicting with their principle of fiscal sovereignty and opposition to subsidizing EU integration projects.  
EFD highlights the issue's failure to address critical cybersecurity risks, noting that 500,000 vulnerable SIS terminals directly undermine EFD's demands for fail-safe data protection frameworks.  
EFD condemns the proposal's disregard for corruption risks in newer Member States, inconsistent with their stance against EU enlargement without proven institutional integrity.  
EFD warns the expansion exacerbates illegal trafficking pathways, overlooking their long-standing advocacy for strict national border oversight over shared systems.

GREEN_EFA strongly agrees the integration of Bulgaria and Romania into the Schengen Information System, aligning with their commitment to EU cohesion and equitable enlargement principles.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the necessity of rigorous follow-up mechanisms to address detected shortcomings in data protection, proposing strengthened parliamentary oversight to ensure compliance with fundamental rights standards.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s alignment with democratic scrutiny requirements for the Schengen evaluation mechanism, reflecting their core advocacy for transparent and accountable governance.  
GREEN_EFA suggests prioritizing technical solutions to resolve SISOne4ALL slot availability challenges, ensuring seamless operational integration without opposing the decision’s overarching goals.  
GREEN_EFA welcomes Commissioner Malmström’s assurance of parliamentary involvement, viewing it as a critical step toward upholding their vision of participatory EU policymaking.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval of the amended draft Council decision 06714/2010, emphasizing the need for the Council to notify Parliament if it intends to deviate from the approved text and to reconsult Parliament should it propose substantial amendments to the originally submitted draft. The resolution underscored procedural accountability by instructing the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its position to the Council and the Commission, ensuring alignment in legislative processes while upholding Parliament’s consultative role under relevant legal frameworks.

title: Agency for the management of large-scale IT systems in the area of freedom, security and justice: REPORT on the amended proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing an Agency for the operational management of large-scale IT systems in the area of freedom, security and justice
background: The European Commission proposed centralized management of EU large-scale IT systems (SIS II, VIS, Eurodac) amid operational challenges, fragmented oversight, and evolving security needs in border and migration policy. The Parliament will discuss establishing a dedicated agency for operational management of these systems in freedom, security, and justice policy areas.

stances.stance:
EPP completely supports the establishment of the agency as it perfectly aligns with EPP's longstanding commitment to robust security infrastructure and parliamentary oversight, ensuring centralized management of critical IT systems while preventing Commission overreach.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on data integrity, particularly the incorporation of a dedicated data security manager and independent oversight body, advancing EPP’s priority of upholding Article 8 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights.  
EPP completely supports the synergy-driven operational model unifying SIS II, VIS, and Eurodac under one agency, effectively advancing EPP’s vision for cost-efficient, interoperable border management systems.  
EPP unequivocally supports the strategic compromise on the agency’s governance structure, praising the balanced distribution of technical operations in Strasbourg and strategic tasks in Tallinn as a model for EU institutional coherence.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue’s exclusion of political decision-making powers for the agency, ensuring its role remains strictly technical and consistent with EPP’s principle of clear separation between operational and policymaking functions.

EFD supports the establishment of the Agency but advises amending Article 14 to limit biometric data retention to three years, preventing excessive surveillance risks raised by SIS integration.  
EFD advises inserting a sovereignty clause in Annex III to exempt non-Schengen states like the UK from EU immigration control mechanisms, respecting national border management frameworks.  
EFD expresses concern over centralized operational costs, proposing decentralized IT management models in Article 7 to align with subsidiarity and reduce bureaucratic duplication.  
EFD urges revision of Recital 9 to require explicit parliamentary approval for future system expansions, addressing accountability gaps in VIS interoperability plans.  
EFD highlights the need for stricter compliance checks with the 2009 Data Protection Supervisor opinion, particularly regarding third-country national biometric processing under Eurodac protocols.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal concerning EU policies related to freedom, security, and justice, adopting amendments to the Commission’s initial proposal (COM(2010)0093) and endorsing a joint statement with the Council annexed to the resolution. It emphasized compliance with legal bases under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, particularly Articles 77, 78, 79, 74, 82, and 87, and incorporated input from the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, as well as opinions from the Budgets and Budgetary Control Committees. The resolution called on the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if substantial revisions or replacements were planned, ensuring parliamentary oversight. It also instructed the President to formally communicate Parliament’s adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reflecting procedural alignment with Rules 55 and 37 of its Rules of Procedure and Article 294 of the Treaty. The text highlighted adherence to the European Data Protection Supervisor’s 2009 opinion, underscoring data protection considerations in legislative measures.

title: EU-USA agreement on the use and transfer of PNR to the US Department of Homeland Security: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the use and transfer of Passenger Name Records to the United States Department of Homeland Security
background: The EU and US negotiated passenger data sharing since 2003 under post-9/11 security frameworks, with a 2007 interim agreement governing transfers. Renewed discussions followed EU concerns over data protection standards, reciprocity, and legal clarity for air carriers under evolving privacy regulations. The Parliament will discuss terms for a revised transatlantic agreement regulating law enforcement access to airline passenger records.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA rejects the PNR agreement as fundamentally incompatible with EU data protection standards, citing mass automated profiling of travelers' data as disproportionate surveillance exceeding counter-terrorism necessities  
GREEN_EFA opposes legitimizing bulk data transfers to DHS, highlighting violations of Articles 7-8 EU Charter through 15-year retention periods and lack of meaningful judicial redress for EU citizens under US law  
GREEN_EFA condemns the agreement's security tokenism, noting failures to prevent attacks like Toulouse/Detroit despite existing PNR access while diverting resources from targeted police investigations  
GREEN_EFA warns against normalizing third-country data demands, stressing this sets dangerous precedent for authoritarian states like China/Saudi Arabia to request similar invasive access  
GREEN_EFA challenges the agreement's legal durability, asserting it "fully rejects" with CJEU jurisprudence requiring strict necessity tests for bulk data processing absent concrete threats

ECR strongly upholds the EU-US PNR agreement as a vital security tool aligning with their commitment to transnational counterterrorism cooperation and proven data-sharing frameworks.  
ECR emphasizes the necessity of uniform legal standards for air carriers and passenger redress rights, rejecting fragmented bilateral agreements as impractical for EU-wide security governance.  
ECR approves the Commission’s legal oversight as sufficient safeguard, asserting trust in US partnership given shared security vulnerabilities post-9/11 and operational successes in preventing attacks like the 7/7 London bombings.  
ECR highlights citizens’ prioritization of travel safety over abstract privacy concerns, noting most Europeans expect governments to implement proactive security measures without detailed technical awareness.  
ECR acknowledges negotiated improvements to data protection clauses as demonstrating responsiveness to EU Charter principles while maintaining intelligence-gathering efficacy against borderless terrorist threats.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the conclusion of the Agreement between the EU and the United States on the use and transfer of Passenger Name Records (PNR) data to the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, replacing the 2007 PNR Agreement and rendering the prior procedure (2009/0187/NLE) obsolete. The resolution emphasized adherence to fundamental rights under the EU Charter and data protection standards, referencing prior Commission communications, European Data Protection Supervisor opinions, and Parliament resolutions on PNR transfers to third countries, including the global approach framework. It highlighted the need for alignment with EU treaties, particularly Article 16 TFEU and Articles 7-8 of the Charter, while instructing its President to communicate the decision to the Council, Commission, member states, and the U.S. government, without detailing procedural steps or amendments.

title: Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the Asylum and Migration Fund
background: Persistent migration pressures, uneven responsibility-sharing among EU states, and fragmented financial instruments for asylum, integration, and border management prompted calls for streamlined EU funding mechanisms. The Parliament will discuss establishing a consolidated Asylum and Migration Fund to address migration governance, solidarity mechanisms, and operational coherence across member states.

stances.stance:
SD supports the emphasis on solidarity and equitable burden-sharing, aligning with their commitment to collective EU solutions for migration challenges while opposing border closures as counterproductive.  
SD advises revising outdated minimum financial thresholds for fund allocation to reflect current migration realities, particularly for frontline states facing disproportionate pressures like Bulgaria and Italy.  
SD endorses mandatory 20% minimum fund allocations for asylum processing and integration programs to ensure balanced prioritization of humanitarian and social cohesion objectives.  
SD recommends strengthening civil society organization involvement in fund implementation to enhance accountability and ensure rights-based outcomes for migrants and asylum seekers.

GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the repressive and regressive measures in the Asylum and Migration Fund, which conflate asylum claims with migration control priorities, directly contradicting their commitment to human rights-based approaches.  
GUE_NGL rejects the externalization of EU migration policy through third-country funding provisions, deeming this incompatible with principles of international solidarity and refugee protection enshrined in the issue's purported solidarity goals.  
GUE_NGL condemns the budgetary prioritization of border security and returns over integration and asylum, highlighting its inconsistency with Article 78(2) TFEU obligations to develop "a common policy on asylum".  
GUE_NGL disputes the issue's claim of equitable burden-sharing, noting how reduced EU parliamentary oversight and preference for national programs over community actions erode collective responsibility frameworks.  
GUE_NGL denounces the "smart borders" emphasis as emblematic of fortress Europe logic, failing to address systemic rights violations criticized in their 2023 manifesto on migration justice.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0751) to establish criteria and mechanisms for determining Member State responsibility in asylum applications and immigration policies under Articles 78(2) and 79(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The resolution endorsed measures to strengthen solidarity and equitable burden-sharing among EU member states, emphasizing compliance with fundamental rights and procedural safeguards for asylum seekers. It called on the Commission to maintain transparency by re-engaging Parliament if proposing substantial amendments to the original text, ensuring alignment with legislative protocols. The Parliament also approved annexed statements outlining its stance, took note of Council and Commission declarations, and instructed its President to forward the adopted position to relevant EU institutions and national parliaments to advance legislative coherence.

title: Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and Internal Security Fund (general provisions): REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down general provisions on the Asylum and Migration Fund and on the instrument for financial support for police cooperation, preventing and combating crime, and crisis management
background: Persistent migration pressures, Mediterranean border challenges, and fragmented EU funding instruments prompted calls for streamlined financial mechanisms. Rising asylum applications, irregular migration routes, and transnational crime necessitated cohesive policy responses. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing asylum, migration, and internal security funds to enhance operational coherence and address cross-border management challenges.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA rejects the allocation of €1.1 billion for "smart borders" as incompatible with humanitarian priorities, citing the absence of a legal basis and its role in fortifying "Fortress Europe" rather than protecting refugees.  
GREEN_EFA opposes fundamentally the Internal Security Fund’s focus on surveillance and "fighting illegal migration," which undermines human rights and diverts resources from asylum seeker integration.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the disproportionate cuts to asylum and migration integration funding, noting the issue’s failure to prioritize refugee resettlement or support NGOs aiding vulnerable populations.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the contradiction in using home affairs funds to finance third-country activities that may conflict with EU human rights and development policy goals.  
GREEN_EFA challenges the schizophrenic policy approach that prioritizes border militarization over addressing Mediterranean tragedies, demanding a future mandate centered on humanitarian action over policing.

ECR strongly advocates the national allocation flexibility of the Asylum and Migration Fund, aligning with their commitment to Member State autonomy in migration policy implementation.  
ECR approves the integration of voluntary resettlement programs and border security measures, effectively advancing priorities to balance humanitarian efforts with combating illegal immigration.  
ECR highlights an enhancement opportunity to strengthen cybercrime prevention mechanisms under the Internal Security Fund while preserving national discretion in security cooperation.  
ECR endorses the UK’s participation as a model for incentivized state engagement, demonstrating the fund’s adaptability to diverse national labor and social needs.  
ECR emphasizes the issue’s success in maintaining non-binding objectives for migration initiatives, ensuring alignment with subsidiarity principles.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal concerning EU policies related to asylum, immigration, judicial cooperation, and internal security, as outlined in the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0752) and aligned with Treaty provisions under Articles 78(2), 79(2), 82(1), 84, and 87(2) TFEU. The resolution emphasized adopting Parliament’s stance at first reading, incorporating input from the European Economic and Social Committee (July 2012) and the Committee of the Regions (July 2012), while urging the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if substantial amendments or replacements were planned. It instructed the Parliament’s President to formally transmit its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring alignment with procedural requirements under Rule 55 of Parliament’s Rules of Procedure and Article 294(4) TFEU, following the Council’s commitment to endorse Parliament’s position as of December 2013.

title: Conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for the purposes of research, studies, pupil exchange, remunerated and unremunerated training, voluntary service and au pairing (recast)
background: The European Union’s existing directives (2004/114/EC, 2005/71/EC) governing third-country nationals’ entry for research, studies, and training faced criticism for fragmented implementation, inconsistent national rules, and insufficient alignment with global competition for skilled migrants amid demographic shifts affecting labor markets. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing entry and residence conditions for third-country nationals engaged in education, research, remunerated training, voluntary service, and au pairing.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA firmly agrees the issue’s expansion of cross-border research mobility, perfectly aligning with their commitment to academic collaboration and EU knowledge-sharing frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the strengthened protections for au pairs, recognizing this as critical to ensuring dignified working conditions in line with social justice principles.  
GREEN_EFA firmly agrees the inclusion of family reunification rights for students, advancing their manifesto goals for inclusive migration policies that prioritize human dignity.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the streamlined application processes for researchers and students, effectively addressing bureaucratic barriers that undermine Europe’s research competitiveness.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on volunteering as lifelong learning, reflecting their advocacy for non-formal education pathways in Green New Deal policies.

ECR rejects the proposal's centralized approach to social policy regulation as firmly conflicting with their principle of national sovereignty over labor and educational matters.  
ECR opposes the immigration-driven growth model, citing unresolved youth unemployment across EU states and the directive's failure to prioritize existing European citizens' employment needs.  
ECR condemns the transfer of authority to EU institutions regarding third-country nationals' access to education systems, demanding member states retain control per subsidiarity principles.  
ECR challenges the demographic rationale, arguing the issue overlooks pro-family policies in favor of unsustainable reliance on foreign labor markets.  
ECR warns against creating parallel labor rights for non-EU nationals while intra-EU mobility restrictions persist for citizens of newer member states.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the Commission’s 2013 legislative proposal (COM(2013)0151), which aimed to codify existing legal texts without introducing substantive amendments beyond those explicitly identified. It noted the Consultative Working Party’s conclusion that the proposal merely consolidated prior acts without altering their substance. The resolution highlighted the Greek Parliament’s reasoned opinion contesting compliance with the subsidiarity principle, alongside consultations with the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions. Parliament adopted its first-reading position, incorporating the Working Party’s recommendations, and urged the Commission to resubmit the proposal if intending significant amendments. It further instructed its President to transmit Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, emphasizing procedural adherence while maintaining the integrity of existing legal frameworks.

title: Enhanced intra-EU solidarity in the field of asylum: REPORT on enhanced intra-EU solidarity in the field of asylum
background: Disparities in asylum application distribution across EU states, compounded by geographic and migration flow pressures, highlighted challenges in equitable responsibility-sharing under the Common European Asylum System. The Parliament will discuss mechanisms to strengthen intra-EU solidarity in asylum procedures and burden-sharing among member states.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects the mandatory relocation quotas based on GDP and population, as this disregards migrants' language preferences and integration capacities. The proposal absolutely disapproves with EFD's belief in national sovereignty over asylum decisions.  
EFD opposes the centralized EU distribution key system, arguing it creates artificial barriers to integration by ignoring cultural and linguistic ties between migrants and specific Member States.  
EFD condemns the Dublin Regulation reforms as maintaining a flawed framework, advocating instead for asylum seekers' freedom to choose destinations aligned with their existing language skills and community connections.  
The issue's approach to solidarity through forced redistribution violates EFD's principle of voluntary cooperation between states, failing to address the practical realities of migrant assimilation in host societies.  
EFD totally challenges the issue's EU-wide burden-sharing mechanisms, which they view as undermining Member States' autonomy to manage asylum processes according to their unique social contexts.

SD totally approves the issue's emphasis on establishing a CEAS with integrated responsibility-sharing, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to EU asylum system reforms that prioritize human rights and equitable burden distribution.  
SD perfectly aligns with the call for financial solidarity through AMF and EASO tools, recognizing this as critical to advancing SD's long-standing goal of protecting frontline states from disproportionate pressures.  
SD totally approves the critique of the Dublin Regulation's structural inequities, viewing its proposed replacement with GDP-based relocation as essential to realizing SD's vision of a genuinely collective asylum approach.  
SD perfectly supports the issue's focus on safeguarding non-refoulement and asylum seekers' rights, reflecting SD's unwavering adherence to international protection standards enshrined in the Geneva Convention.  
SD totally approves leveraging AMF flexibility for crisis response, seeing this as effectively advancing SD's manifesto pledge to operationalize solidarity through rapid funding access and capacity-building.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need for enhanced intra-EU solidarity and responsibility-sharing in asylum policies, emphasizing the establishment of a fair and efficient Common European Asylum System (CEAS) aligned with international and EU law, including the Geneva Convention, ECHR, and EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. It highlighted disparities in asylum application distribution, noting that in 2011, ten Member States handled over 90% of applications, while only 4,125 refugees were resettled across ten states, and 227 beneficiaries were relocated from Malta. The resolution called for financial and administrative support to Member States facing disproportionate pressures, particularly those at EU entry points, through tools like the Asylum and Migration Fund (AMF) and the European Asylum Support Office (EASO), which should prioritize emergency assistance, capacity-building, and coordination of joint processing and relocation schemes. It criticized the Dublin Regulation for placing undue burdens on border states and urged reforms, including a potential EU distribution key for relocation based on GDP, population, and integration capacity. The Parliament stressed the importance of data collection, compliance with non-refoulement, and safeguarding asylum seekers' rights, while addressing xenophobia through awareness campaigns. It advocated for flexible funding under the AMF, including up to 90% EU co-financing for critical projects, and urged cooperation with third countries to address root causes of migration. The resolution also called for evaluating the Temporary Protection Directive’s activation criteria and improving mutual trust via consistent asylum standards and early warning mechanisms to prevent systemic failures.

title: Establishment of 'Eurodac' for the comparison of fingerprints: REPORT on the amended proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the establishment of 'EURODAC' for the comparison of fingerprints for the effective application of Regulation (EU) No […/…] (establishing the criteria and mechanisms for determining the Member State responsible for examining an application for international protection lodged in one of the Member States by a third-country national or a stateless person) and to request comparisons with EURODAC data by Member States' law enforcement authorities and Europol for law enforcement purposes and amending Regulation (EU) No 1077/2011 establishing a European Agency for the operational management of large-scale IT systems in the area of freedom, security and justice (recast)
background: Persistent disparities in EU asylum procedures and responsibility-sharing mechanisms, coupled with migration pressures on frontline states, highlighted inefficiencies in existing fingerprint data systems for asylum applications. The Parliament will discuss establishing updated EURODAC regulations to enhance asylum criteria application and enable controlled law enforcement access for serious crime investigations.

stances.stance:
EPP fully sanctions the EURODAC reforms as a critical advancement in harmonizing asylum procedures, perfectly aligning with its commitment to secure borders and combat migratory abuse through enhanced biometric data governance.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on minimum reception standards, particularly applauding provisions for unaccompanied minors and vulnerable groups as a testament to Europe’s human dignity principles.  
EPP proposes strengthening future solidarity mechanisms to complement Dublin reforms, ensuring peripheral states receive proportional support while maintaining responsibility-sharing frameworks.  
EPP highlights EURODAC’s law enforcement access as a model for balancing asylum integrity with cross-border crime prevention, effectively advancing its security agenda.  
EPP urges swift implementation of accelerated asylum procedures to deter economic migrants, framing this as essential to preserving public trust in protection systems.

GUE_NGL rejects fundamentally the expansion of EURODAC access to law enforcement authorities as a dangerous perversion of its original asylum purpose.  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue's failure to prohibit detention of asylum seekers in regular prisons and unaccompanied minors, contradicting core human rights principles.  
GUE_NGL condemns the perpetuation of the Dublin Regulation's "first entry" logic that disproportionately burdens border states and denies asylum seekers' dignity.  
GUE_NGL denounces accelerated border procedures and "safe third country" transfers as systemic violations of due process in international protection claims.  
GUE_NGL declares the criminalization of asylum seekers through police database access irreconcilable with their status as rights-holders under international law.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a Commission proposal (COM(2012)0254), emphasizing that the text constituted a straightforward codification of existing legal provisions without substantive amendments beyond those explicitly identified. It adopted its first-reading stance based on the Consultative Working Party’s assessment, which confirmed the proposal’s technical nature and lack of material changes to earlier acts. The resolution urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if it substantially amends or replaces the proposal, ensuring legislative transparency and procedural adherence. Additionally, Parliament instructed its President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing interinstitutional coordination under relevant Treaty articles (TFEU 294(2), 78(2)(e), 87(2)(a), and 88(2)(a)) and the 2001 Interinstitutional Agreement on recasting legal acts.

title: Establishment of an evaluation mechanism to verify application of the Schengen acquis: REPORT on the draft Council regulation on the establishment of an evaluation mechanism to verify the application of the Schengen acquis
background: The Schengen Area’s existing intergovernmental evaluation framework faced criticism for inconsistent application of border control rules and insufficient oversight, prompting calls for a standardized EU-level mechanism to ensure compliance. The Parliament will discuss establishing a revised evaluation system to strengthen governance of the Schengen acquis.

stances.stance:
EPP completely advocates the enhanced Schengen evaluation mechanism as a vital reinforcement of Europe's border security architecture  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on Commission-led evaluations to ensure objective scrutiny of member states' border management practices  
EPP applauds the integration of Frontex expertise into monitoring processes, fulfilling their manifesto commitment to operationalize EU border protection tools  
EPP emphasizes future enhancement opportunities through increased parliamentary oversight of Schengen governance decisions   
EPP categorically rejects nationalist narratives about Schengen's security impacts while endorsing temporary border measures only under strict Commission supervision

GUE_NGL rejects the reintroduction of border controls justified by migration flows as a violation of free movement and a scapegoating of migrants, absolutely rejecting with their commitment to free movement and migrant rights.  
GUE_NGL opposes the two-year extension of border controls under the "emergency clause," which undermines Schengen’s core principle of abolishing internal borders and disproportionately targets vulnerable populations.  
GUE_NGL condemns the exclusion of parliamentary oversight in the evaluation mechanism, highlighting its contradiction with democratic accountability and institutional balance in EU governance.  
GUE_NGL argues the issue legitimizes political misuse of Schengen by member states, enabling border controls as a bargaining tool rather than safeguarding free movement as a fundamental right.  
GUE_NGL acknowledges the evaluation mechanism’s limited transparency but rejects the overall framework for institutionalizing border control reinstatement without addressing root causes of migration challenges.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval of the Council draft (10273/2013) concerning measures under Article 70 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, endorsing the joint statement by Parliament, the Council, and the Commission annexed to the resolution. The resolution emphasized the adoption of the act as transmitted by the Council, following the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs’ report (A7-0215/2013), and instructed its President to formally communicate Parliament’s position to the Council and the Commission, ensuring alignment with the agreed framework and procedural commitments outlined in the interinstitutional agreement.

title: European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union (FRONTEX): REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 2007/2004 establishing a European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union (FRONTEX)
background: Persistent migratory pressures along EU external borders, particularly in Southern Europe and the Mediterranean, and operational challenges faced by FRONTEX since its 2004 establishment prompted calls to strengthen border management. The Parliament will discuss amending the agency’s mandate to enhance operational capacity and address human rights obligations in border operations.

stances.stance:
ECR strongly agrees empowering FRONTEX with enhanced operational tools to intercept irregular migrants, aligning with their border security priorities under Article 77 TFEU.  
ECR approves the issue's emphasis on subsidiarity through Schengen reforms enabling national governments to address exceptional migratory pressures.  
ECR endorses cross-border cooperation mechanisms to resolve migratory challenges without intra-EU confrontation, reflecting their multilateral governance principles.  
ECR proposes augmenting FRONTEX's budget allocation for rapid deployment capabilities while maintaining the issue's core objectives.  
ECR commends the alignment with judicial cooperation frameworks as critical for lawful border operations under the Treaties.

GUE_NGL rejects the Frontex mandate expansion as fundamentally incompatible with human rights protections, citing documented migrant deaths and unlawful pushbacks in Mediterranean operations  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue's failure to prohibit violence in border operations, directly contradicting their principle that "people cannot be illegal" and requiring non-militarized migration responses  
This fully disapproves with GUE_NGL's position that border agencies inherently violate dignity by categorizing migrants, instead demanding continental asylum system reforms per Article 78 TFEU  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as binding accountability mechanisms for Frontex officers' actions and meaningful third-country refugee resettlement commitments  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's authorization of mass charter deportations without data protection guarantees, exacerbating risks of refoulement to conflict zones like Libya

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the legislative proposal on EU procedures for international protection and border management (COM(2010)0061), emphasizing compliance with the Treaties and subsidiarity principles. It adopted its first-reading position, approving an annexed statement outlining its stance, and called on the Commission to resubmit the proposal if substantial amendments or replacements were planned. The resolution highlighted the Polish Senate’s reasoned objection that the proposal breached subsidiarity, while noting the European Economic and Social Committee’s supportive opinion from 15 July 2010. It instructed the Parliament’s President to forward the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reflecting commitments under Article 294 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU and procedural obligations under Rule 55 of Parliament’s Rules of Procedure. The resolution aimed to ensure alignment with legal bases in Articles 74 and 77(1)(b)-(c) TFEU, focusing on judicial cooperation and border controls.

title: European Arrest Warrant: REPORT with recommendations to the Commission on the review of the European Arrest Warrant
background: The European Arrest Warrant, established in 2002 to streamline cross-border judicial cooperation, faced operational challenges including divergent national interpretations, proportionality concerns in minor offenses, and debates over fundamental rights protections amid evolving EU criminal justice integration. The Parliament will discuss balancing efficient law enforcement with procedural safeguards and mutual trust mechanisms.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects the European Arrest Warrant framework as fundamentally incompatible with national sovereignty and traditional legal safeguards like habeas corpus and trial by jury.  
EFD opposes the issue's proportionality assessments, arguing they fail to address systemic injustices where individuals are extradited without prima facie evidence or case-ready trials.  
The proposal totally challenges with EFD's position that mutual recognition mechanisms erode Britain's independent justice system in service of EU federalization goals.  
EFD condemns the UK government's decision to opt into the EAW as a betrayal, emphasizing that existing international cooperation tools render EU harmonization unnecessary and dangerous.  
The issue overlooks critical aspects such as prolonged pre-trial detention under continental systems, which the EAW exacerbates by bypassing evidentiary standards upheld in British courts.

GREEN_EFA strongly advocates mandating proportionality assessments for EAW issuance, aligning with their commitment to preventing judicial overreach in cross-border cases.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing the issue by explicitly requiring refusal of EAWs when prison conditions breach human dignity, citing systemic failures in certain Member States.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the prioritization of alternatives to detention, reflecting their longstanding advocacy for minimizing coercive measures in judicial cooperation.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the urgency of implementing human rights safeguards within the one-year timeline to halt preventable miscarriages of justice under the current EAW framework.  
GREEN_EFA endorses standardized judicial training and case-law databases as critical steps toward reconciling mutual recognition with fundamental rights protections.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the implementation and operation of the European Arrest Warrant (EAW) framework, emphasizing the need to balance efficiency with fundamental rights safeguards. It highlighted the EAW’s role in accelerating cross-border judicial cooperation but identified gaps, including inconsistent application, lack of proportionality checks, and insufficient protection of suspects’ rights. The resolution called for legislative reforms, urging the Commission to propose measures within a year to address systemic issues, such as standardizing the definition of "judicial authority," mandating proportionality assessments for EAW issuance (considering offense severity, trial readiness, and human rights impacts), and establishing consultation procedures between Member States to resolve execution concerns. It stressed the necessity of mandatory refusal grounds for EAWs incompatible with human rights obligations under the EU Charter and ECHR, alongside enhanced legal remedies for individuals. The Parliament urged Member States to prioritize alternative measures to detention, improve prison conditions in line with human dignity, and ensure compensation for miscarriages of justice. It emphasized data collection on EAW use, withdrawal of non-executed warrants, and updates to EU databases like SIS II. Training for legal practitioners, judicial networks, and a centralized case-law database were recommended to foster a European judicial culture. The resolution linked detention reforms to mutual trust, advocating EU-level initiatives to improve pre-trial standards. Financial implications were to be covered by existing budgets, with anticipated long-term savings from streamlined procedures. Overall, the resolution sought to strengthen mutual recognition instruments while safeguarding rights, proportionality, and legal certainty in the EU’s area of freedom, security, and justice.

title: European Protection Order: REPORT on the draft directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Protection Order
background: The European Union's framework for judicial cooperation in criminal matters, alongside disparities in national victim protection laws, highlighted challenges in cross-border enforcement of restraining orders. The Parliament will discuss establishing a mechanism for mutual recognition of protection orders across Member States to enhance victim safety within the EU area of freedom, security, and justice.

stances.stance:
EFD supports the draft directive’s focus on addressing cross-border custody disputes and protecting children from legal exploitation across Member States.  
EFD advises amending Article 4 to mandate domestic court validation of foreign protection orders, ensuring compatibility with national legal frameworks and local societal norms.  
EFD proposes reinforcing subsidiarity safeguards by requiring explicit justification for supranational enforcement mechanisms under Protocol No 2.  
EFD highlights the necessity of maintaining judicial sovereignty, suggesting periodic reviews to assess the order’s impact on national legal systems.  
 Contradictory EFD arguments reflect conditional support, balancing child protection goals with caution against supranational overreach.

ALDE firmly advocates the European Protection Order as a vital instrument to safeguard freedom and security across borders, perfectly aligning with ALDE's commitment to judicial cooperation and gender equality.  
ALDE highlights enhancement opportunities for future development of a European register of protection orders to ensure immediate application and cost efficiency while maintaining privacy standards.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s political boldness in advancing cross-border victim protection and urges refinement of translation support through the forthcoming victims’ rights package.  
ALDE emphasizes the directive’s critical role in protecting women from violence and urges expansion to address victims of organized crime in subsequent legislative measures.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s human rights focus, affirming its moral duty to uphold physical and psychological integrity as a universal principle within EU justice frameworks.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on a legislative proposal concerning justice and home affairs, grounded in Treaty provisions including Article 76(b) and Article 82(1)(d) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), which establish EU competence in judicial cooperation and harmonization of criminal law. The resolution incorporated input from the Committee on Legal Affairs and addressed concerns from a national parliament challenging compliance with subsidiarity under Protocol No 2. It emphasized collaboration between the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality, reflecting procedural adherence to Rule 51 of Parliament’s Rules of Procedure. The Parliament urged the Commission to resubmit the proposal if substantial amendments or replacements are planned, ensuring continued alignment with legislative intent and parliamentary oversight under Article 294 TFEU.

title: European Public Prosecutor's Office: INTERIM REPORT on the proposal for a Council regulation on the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office
background: The European Union faced persistent challenges in safeguarding its financial interests, with annual fraud estimates exceeding €500 million, amid fragmented national enforcement and overlapping mandates of EU bodies like OLAF and Eurojust. The Parliament will discuss establishing a European Public Prosecutor’s Office under Article 86 TFEU to centralize prosecution of EU budget-related crimes.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office, arguing that reinforcing national prosecutors’ coordination and training would more effectively combat EU budget fraud without creating bureaucratic redundancies.  
EFD opposes the proposal’s budgetary implications, emphasizing that allocating funds to a new institution during a crisis contradicts fiscal responsibility and strains member states’ resources.  
EFD fully challenges with the issue’s dismissal of competence clashes, warning that overlapping jurisdictions between the EPPO and national authorities will lead to legal uncertainty and inefficiency.  
EFD criticizes the undemocratic appointment process for the EPPO chief prosecutor, demanding greater parliamentary oversight to align with democratic accountability principles.  
 Слави Бинев (EFD) contradicts party stance by endorsing the EPPO as a safeguard against corruption in states like Bulgaria, though this view is isolated within EFD’s broader opposition.
