The resolution emphasized alignment with the legal framework of the EC Treaty, particularly Article 62(2)(b)(i) on visa policy and Article 300(2) and (3) governing international agreements. It referenced the Commission’s proposal (COM(2009)0053) and the consultation procedure (C7-0013/2009), while endorsing the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs’ report (A7-0014/2009). The Parliament instructed its President to formally communicate its position to the Council, Commission, EU Member States, and the government and parliament of Saint Kitts and Nevis, ensuring implementation of the agreement.

title: Report: Simon Busuttil- Agreement between the EC and Seychelles on the short-stay visa waiver on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Community and the Republic of Seychelles on the short-stay visa waiver: REPORT on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Community and the Republic of Seychelles on the short-stay visa waiver
background: The EU amended visa regulations in 2006 to include six countries on a positive list, enabling visa waivers upon bilateral agreements. Following 2008 negotiations and 2009 provisional application, the Parliament will discuss concluding short-stay visa waiver agreements with Antigua and Barbuda, Bahamas, Barbados, Mauritius, Saint Kitts and Nevis, and Seychelles.

stances.stance:
EPP fully accepts the visa waiver agreement as it perfectly aligns with their commitment to fostering regulated mobility while dismantling perceptions of a "Fortress Europe."  
EPP emphasizes the critical role of reciprocity in visa liberalization, ensuring mutual openness between the EU and Seychelles as a cornerstone of fair international cooperation.  
EPP applauds the issue’s adherence to a unified European approach, rejecting fragmented country-specific selection to maintain coherence in external border policies.  
EPP highlights the agreement’s strict compliance with EU regulatory frameworks, reinforcing their principle that visa exemptions must follow established security and procedural standards.  
EPP recognizes this initiative as advancing their strategic priority of deepening bilateral partnerships through trust-based travel facilitation, consistent with justice and home affairs objectives.

GUE_NGL strongly endorses the visa waiver agreement as it aligns perfectly with their longstanding commitment to abolishing restrictive visa barriers and advancing free movement principles akin to those governing capital and goods.  

GUE_NGL applauds the issue’s facilitation of cultural and professional exchanges, effectively advancing their priority of dismantling bureaucratic obstacles that impede international solidarity and family reunification.  

GUE_NGL highlights the agreement’s alignment with humane migration policies, preventing visa-related exploitation and fostering mobility for non-economic actors like artists and journalists.  

GUE_NGL proposes amending the French translation of "valid passport" to "passeport en cours de validité" to ensure terminological precision and avoid ambiguities in implementation.  

GUE_NGL recommends extending territorial application to all EU outermost regions, including French territories, to eliminate disparities and uphold equal treatment under the agreement.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval for the conclusion of an agreement between the European Community and the Republic of Seychelles on short-stay visa exemptions, based on the proposal from the Commission (COM(2009)0052) and following consultation with the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. The resolution endorses the final adoption of the agreement, which facilitates visa-free travel for citizens of Seychelles and EU Member States for stays of up to 90 days within a 180-day period, aiming to strengthen bilateral relations and promote mobility. It calls for the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its position to the Council, Commission, and the governments and parliaments of EU Member States and Seychelles, ensuring alignment with EU visa policy and compliance with the EC Treaty’s provisions on justice and home affairs cooperation.

title: Report: Simon Busuttil- Agreement between the EC and The Bahamas on the short-stay visa waiver on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Community and the Commonwealth of The Bahamas on the short-stay visa waiver: REPORT on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Community and the Commonwealth of The Bahamas on the short-stay visa waiver
background: In 2006, six countries met EU criteria for visa list transfer, prompting negotiations. Following 2008 talks and 2009 provisional application, the European Commission proposed formalizing short-stay visa waivers. The Parliament will discuss concluding agreements enabling visa-free travel between the EU and Antigua and Barbuda, the Bahamas, Barbados, Mauritius, Saint Kitts and Nevis, and Seychelles.

stances.stance:
EPP absolutely supports the visa waiver agreement as a decisive rebuttal of the "Fortress Europe" narrative, perfectly aligning with its commitment to balanced freedom of movement.  
EPP emphasizes the issue’s strict adherence to reciprocity principles, ensuring mutual openness between the EU and The Bahamas without compromising regulatory rigor.  
EPP applauds the European Commission’s rule-based methodology, which avoids fragmented bilateral deals and strengthens the Schengen area’s coherence as mandated in their 2009 policy agenda.  
EPP highlights the agreement’s compliance with enhanced security safeguards, reflecting Vice-President Barrot’s insistence on rigorous pre-approval criteria for visa liberalization.  
EPP recognizes the issue’s procedural precision in mandating cross-institutional communication, ensuring full transparency with all EU bodies and Bahamian authorities.

GUE_NGL strongly upholds the visa waiver agreement as a progressive step toward dismantling barriers to free movement, aligning with their vision of equitable global mobility.  
GUE_NGL proposes clarifying the French translation of "valid passport" to "passeport en cours de validité" to ensure legal precision and reciprocity.  
GUE_NGL highlights the exclusion of France’s outermost regions as inconsistent with territorial cohesion principles, urging harmonized application across all EU territories.  
GUE_NGL applauds the exemption for cultural and sports exchanges, advancing people-to-people solidarity as central to international cooperation.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes the need to expand such agreements to include broader socioeconomic groups, reinforcing their commitment to migration policies prioritizing human dignity over restrictive controls.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval for the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and the Commonwealth of The Bahamas, as outlined in the proposal COM(2009)0055, following the legal bases under the EC Treaty and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs’ report (A7-0016/2009). The resolution endorsed the adoption of the agreement, emphasizing its alignment with EU legislative frameworks and cooperation objectives. It mandated the Parliament’s President to formally communicate this decision to the EU Council, Commission, member states’ governments and parliaments, and the government and parliament of The Bahamas, ensuring transparency and procedural compliance. The resolution focused on finalizing the agreement’s ratification without substantive amendments, underscoring its commitment to strengthening bilateral relations and legal cooperation.

title: Information accompanying transfers of funds: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on information accompanying transfers of funds
background: Existing EU anti-money laundering regulations required updates to align with revised international Financial Action Task Force standards and address evolving financial crime risks, including technological advancements enabling complex cross-border transactions. The Parliament will discuss measures to strengthen transparency requirements for fund transfers to prevent illicit financial flows and terrorist financing.

stances.stance:
EFD conditionally agrees the anti-money laundering framework but demands amendments to exempt state-regulated low-risk sectors like Finland's slot machine system from excessive reporting requirements.  
EFD requests revisions to include mandatory EU-level intervention in member states with systemic corruption, citing Bulgaria's failure to prosecute high-level money laundering cases.  
EFD insists the directive must explicitly authorize extended asset confiscation for organized crime proceeds, aligning with Zbigniew Ziobro's emphasis on effective sanctions.  
EFD calls for accelerated implementation of centralized business registries and amendments closing VAT carousel loopholes enabling cross-border fraud.  
EFD warns the current text inadequately balances financial tracking with proportionality, risking overregulation of legitimate entities without addressing core criminal networks.

GREEN_EFA completely sanctions the establishment of a European register of beneficial owners as essential to dismantling financial secrecy structures that enable tax evasion and criminal activity.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on institutional accountability, particularly in addressing past implementation failures through strengthened parliamentary oversight of anti-money laundering frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the societal imperative of reclaiming illicit funds for public services as articulated in the debate, affirming this aligns with their manifesto priorities for economic justice and social welfare.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the focus on transactional transparency to expose hidden ownership chains, noting this advances their decade-long advocacy against offshore tax havens and corporate anonymity.  
GREEN_EFA underscores the moral necessity of linking financial reforms to human progress, framing the issue as a critical step toward democratizing economic governance across Europe.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2013 proposal (COM(2013)0044) concerning EU economic and legal frameworks, grounded in Treaty provisions (Articles 294(2), 294(3), and 114 TFEU). It integrated input from the European Central Bank’s May 2013 opinion and the European Economic and Social Committee’s November 2013 opinion, alongside collaborative analysis by the Committees on Economic and Monetary Affairs and Civil Liberties, Justice, and Home Affairs, with additional input from the Development and Legal Affairs Committees (report A7-0140/2014). The resolution formally adopted the Parliament’s first-reading stance, urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments or alternative texts, and directed its President to transmit this position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to ensure procedural continuity and institutional alignment.

title: Internal Security Fund (External borders and visas): REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing, as part of the Internal Security Fund, the instrument for financial support for external borders and visa
background: Persistent migration pressures, particularly in Mediterranean regions, and challenges in coordinating border infrastructure and resources among EU Member States prompted the need for enhanced external border management. The Parliament will discuss establishing a financial instrument under the Internal Security Fund to address border security, visa policy coherence, and operational support mechanisms.

stances.stance:
ALDE strongly upholds the issue’s financial solidarity mechanism, aligning perfectly with their commitment to equitable burden-sharing in EU migration management.  
ALDE approves the administrative simplification measures, emphasizing their critical role in accelerating fund accessibility for frontline Member States.  
ALDE highlights the importance of delegated acts to safeguard parliamentary influence, ensuring democratic oversight aligns with their institutional reform priorities.  
ALDE advocates for sustained innovation in cross-border integration projects, reflecting their progressive stance on holistic migration solutions encompassing circular migration pathways.  
ALDE proposes enhancing coordination frameworks for IT systems to mitigate fragmentation risks while maintaining the issue’s operational flexibility.

GUE_NGL rejects the conflation of migration pressure and asylum requests as a dangerous oversimplification that dehumanizes vulnerable populations.  
GUE_NGL opposes the prioritization of "smart borders" and return measures over integration and asylum funding, which directly contradicts their commitment to solidarity-based migration policies.  
GUE_NGL firmly disputes with the issue’s authorization of EU-funded migration control operations in third countries, viewing this as institutionalizing the Fortress Europe model they have consistently denounced.  
GUE_NGL highlights that the proposal fails to address systemic rights violations by reducing parliamentary oversight and marginalizing NGOs in decision-making processes.  
GUE_NGL condemns the budgetary cuts to community-led actions as inconsistent with their demand for equitable resource allocation prioritizing human dignity over securitization.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about Member States prioritizing national interests in allocating funds under the Instrument, particularly for financing operating support within their national programs, and highlighted risks of fragmentation and duplication due to insufficient coordination in infrastructure, equipment, transport, and IT systems. The resolution adopted the Parliament’s position at first reading, urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments to the proposal, and instructed its President to forward the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to address these systemic challenges and ensure cohesive implementation of EU policies.

title: Internal Security Fund (Police cooperation, preventing and combating crime and crisis management): REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing, as part of the Internal Security Fund, the instrument for financial support for police cooperation, preventing and combating crime, and crisis management
background: Heightened migration flows, cross-border crime threats, and fragmented EU financial instruments for internal security prompted calls for streamlined funding. Mediterranean states faced disproportionate migration pressures, while transnational crises underscored coordination gaps. The Parliament will discuss establishing a unified Internal Security Fund to enhance police cooperation, combat crime, and improve crisis management mechanisms.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the enhanced financial oversight mechanisms, particularly unannounced project audits, as aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to taxpayer fund protection.  
EPP approves the 75-90% co-financing flexibility for crisis responses, effectively advancing EPP's priority of rapid EU-level security interventions.  
EPP proposes reinforcing Article 15 to explicitly link migration fund allocations with third-country cooperation agreements, enhancing policy coherence.  
EPP endorses the merged fund structure's operational efficiency gains while suggesting future budgetary expansions to match evolving border protection needs.  
EPP applauds the mandatory EU-added value assessment for projects as mirroring their manifesto pledge for strategic security investments.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue’s prioritization of surveillance and border militarization, which entirely disputes with their commitment to human rights and humanitarian protection.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the allocation of €1.1 billion for “smart borders,” a system lacking legal grounding and exacerbating Fortress Europe policies inconsistent with refugee rights advocacy.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the Internal Security Fund’s focus on “fighting illegal migration,” a framing that overlooks critical aspects of asylum seeker dignity and NGO support central to their platform.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s failure to address integration funding cuts, perpetuating a schizophrenic policy approach that neglects refugee resettlement and humanitarian obligations.  
GREEN_EFA opposes merging security and migration budgets, warning this blurs priorities and diverts resources from vulnerable populations to punitive measures they deem ethically indefensible.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2011 proposal concerning justice and home affairs, adopting its first-reading stance under Articles 82(1), 84, and 87(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It emphasized alignment with opinions from the European Economic and Social Committee (July 2012) and the Committee of the Regions (July 2012), alongside input from its Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and the Committee on Budgets. The resolution formally endorsed the legislative text, urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing significant amendments, and directed the Parliament’s President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring procedural continuity under EU law.

title: Granting and withdrawing international protection: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on minimum standards on procedures in Member States for granting and withdrawing international protection (recast)
background: Disparities in EU Member States’ asylum procedures, including divergent recognition rates and procedural timelines, alongside a 40% decline in asylum applications in industrialized countries over a decade, prompted calls for harmonization under the Stockholm Programme’s 2012 Common European Asylum System target. The Parliament will discuss revising the 2005 Asylum Procedures Directive to establish uniform EU standards for granting and withdrawing international protection.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the procedural safeguards in Article 23 as absolutely opposeing with their demand for accelerated processing of manifestly unfounded claims.  
EPP opposes the disappearance provisions (Section 4.7) for enabling indefinite procedural delays through refusal of document receipt, contradicting their principle of administrative efficiency.  
EPP condemns the three-application threshold before acceleration as inconsistent with their stance against systematic abuse of asylum channels.  
EPP disputes the six-month evidentiary burden shift (Clause 12b) as creating bureaucratic obstacles to swift refugee status determinations.  
EPP challenges the safe third country exemptions as overlooking critical vulnerabilities in border state systems like Greece's documented asylum backlogs.

SD completely sanctions the harmonization of asylum procedures to eliminate disparities between Member States, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to ending the "asylum lottery" through common EU-wide standards.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on front-loaded quality decision-making, recognizing this as essential to upholding international obligations while reducing long-term administrative costs.  
SD completely sanctions the directive’s enhanced protections for vulnerable groups, particularly unaccompanied minors, as a critical advancement of fundamental rights in asylum processes.  
SD unequivocally supports the urgency of adopting fair procedures amid Mediterranean crises, affirming this as vital to transforming Europe from a "fortress" into a zone of principled solidarity.  
SD perfectly aligns with binding burden-sharing mechanisms, viewing coordinated asylum governance as indispensable to addressing North African displacement challenges collectively.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the adoption of a codified version of existing legislation on asylum and immigration procedures, confirming that the Commission’s proposal (COM(2009)0554) did not introduce substantive amendments but merely consolidated prior acts without altering their content, as affirmed by the Consultative Working Party of the legal services. The resolution emphasized adherence to the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (Article 78(2)) and the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2001 on recasting legal acts, while aligning with Parliament’s 2009 resolution on the Common European Asylum System. It formally adopted its first-reading position, urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing significant future changes, and directed its President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to ensure procedural continuity and transparency.

title: Homophobia and discrimination on grounds of sexual orientation and gender identity: REPORT on the EU Roadmap against homophobia and discrimination on grounds of sexual orientation and gender identity
background: Persistent reports from EU agencies and international bodies documented widespread discrimination, violence, and legal gaps affecting LGBTI individuals across member states, alongside existing EU equality frameworks for other groups. The Parliament will discuss coordinated measures to address homophobia and discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity within EU competencies.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects the issue's push for mutual recognition of same-sex marriages as violating national sovereignty and traditional family definitions.  
EFD opposes "special rights" frameworks for LGBTI individuals, arguing equality must exclude "positive discrimination" that overrides biological realities.  
EFD completely againsts with EU-level gender recognition mandates, asserting such matters belong exclusively to private life and national cultural norms.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of subsidiarity by imposing healthcare/legal recognition standards incompatible with member states' constitutional family models.  
EFD dismisses the issue's premise as redundant, claiming existing societal respect for human dignity negates the need for targeted LGBTI policies.

GUE_NGL strongly promotes the issue's condemnation of hate speech and violence against LGBTI individuals, aligning perfectly with GUE_NGL's longstanding commitment to intersectional equality and dignity for marginalized communities.  
GUE_NGL approves the demand for legal recognition of same-sex partnerships and parenthood, emphasizing its consistency with their manifesto principles of dismantling discriminatory family-law frameworks.  
GUE_NGL proposes strengthening measures against institutional censorship of anti-homophobia advocacy, referencing Ireland's RTE case as a critical enhancement opportunity for media accountability.  
GUE_NGL applauds the focus on intersectional discrimination faced by lesbians and transgender persons, noting its resonance with their 2023 priorities on healthcare access and gender self-determination.  
GUE_NGL underscores the urgency of addressing workplace discrimination through binding EU directives, mirroring their ongoing campaigns for labor rights expansion to LGBTQI+ workers.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over persistent discrimination and violence against LGBTI individuals in the EU, citing data from the 2013 EU LGBT survey revealing that 50% felt discriminated against or harassed, 33% faced discrimination accessing goods/services, 25% were physically attacked, and 20% experienced workplace discrimination. It condemned the lack of a comprehensive EU policy to protect LGBTI rights, despite repeated calls from Parliament and 11 Equality Ministers, and urged the Commission and Member States to adopt a multiannual roadmap addressing non-discrimination in employment, education, healthcare, goods/services, and specific challenges faced by transgender and intersex persons, including forced sterilization and inadequate legal recognition. The resolution emphasized ensuring access to gender reassignment services, legal recognition of same-sex partnerships and parenthood, inclusive family laws, non-discriminatory fertility treatments, and protection from hate speech and violence. It called for awareness campaigns, improved data collection, and mainstreaming LGBTI rights in EU policies, particularly in asylum, freedom of movement, and external relations, while stressing the need to address intersectional discrimination against lesbians and ensure media representation and safe educational environments for LGBTI youth.

title: Report: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra- Implementing rules for Europol analysis work files: REPORT on the draft Council decision adopting the implementing rules for Europol analysis work files
background: The imminent entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, altering EU legislative procedures for police cooperation, and a 2009 Council proposal to update Europol’s operational rules under the pre-Lisbon legal framework prompted institutional considerations. The Parliament will discuss adjustments to Europol’s analysis file protocols amid evolving governance structures for EU security agencies.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects the proposed Europol rules for permitting unchecked sharing of sensitive citizen data with third countries like Russia and Albania, fundamentally againsting with EFD’s commitment to safeguarding individual privacy and national sovereignty.  
EFD opposes granting Europol officers legal immunity, a concept inconsistent with British legal traditions and EFD’s principles of accountability and judicial oversight.  
EFD condemns the issue’s failure to address the erosion of national liberties through EU judicial instruments like the European arrest warrant, which undermines domestic legal protections.  
EFD highlights the proposal’s disregard for citizen consent, emphasizing that the Lisbon Treaty’s implementation without referenda contradicts EFD’s demand for democratic legitimacy in EU integration.  
EFD underscores the danger of prioritizing Europol’s operational interests over citizen rights, overlooking critical protections against unwarranted data collection and transnational surveillance.

GREEN_EFA rejects the interim amendments to Europol's analysis work files as fundamentally premature, conflicting with their insistence on full colegislative processes under the Lisbon Treaty.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the issue's failure to mandate explicit safeguards for decentralized forensic systems, exemplified by Spain's regional laboratories.  
GREEN_EFA absolutely disapproves with the proposal's centralized coordination model, which overlooks critical regional legal and police diversity within Member States.

resolution: The European Parliament raised objections to the proposed Council text amending the Europol Decision, rejecting it due to the imminent entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, which would alter the legal framework for police cooperation. It opposed making interim amendments to Europol’s implementing measures, arguing such changes should wait until the Lisbon Treaty’s provisions take effect. Parliament called on the Council to withdraw its current proposal and urged the Commission or Council to submit a new Europol decision proposal within six months of the Lisbon Treaty’s entry into force, ensuring alignment with the updated legal framework. Additionally, it instructed its President to communicate this position to the Council and Commission, emphasizing the need to prioritize coherence under the Lisbon Treaty over piecemeal reforms.

title: Report: Alexander Alvaro- Use of information technology for customs purposes on the initiative of the French Republic with a view to adopting a Council Decision on the use of information technology for customs purposes: REPORT on the initiative of the French Republic with a view to adopting a Council decision on the use of information technology for customs purposes
background: The French Republic’s 2008 initiative under EU Treaty provisions proposed modernizing customs cooperation through information technology, addressing operational needs and legal frameworks. The Parliament will discuss adopting a Council Decision on implementing IT systems for customs purposes to enhance inter-administration collaboration and fraud prevention.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses restricting data access to designated customs bodies and EU agencies, aligning with their commitment to secure cross-border cooperation.  
EPP approves prohibiting data transfers to third countries lacking robust protection frameworks, advancing their priority of safeguarding EU citizens' privacy.  
EPP applauds the system's modernization to enable analytical tools for customs authorities, effectively advancing their manifesto goals on trade security.  
EPP emphasizes strict adherence to data minimization principles and alignment with Schengen II standards, proposing enhanced oversight mechanisms for consistency.  
EPP suggests extending implementation timelines to ensure thorough parliamentary scrutiny, maintaining procedural rigor without opposing the initiative's core objectives.

GUE_NGL rejects the initiative's failure to impose clear limits on data retention periods, firmly rejecting with their commitment to privacy rights and civil liberties.  
GUE_NGL opposes the disproportionate expansion of security measures linking customs, police, and judicial databases, which undermines the principle of necessity in EU governance.  
This proposal overlooks critical safeguards against mass surveillance, contradicting GUE_NGL's demand for strict proportionality in security frameworks.  
GUE_NGL condemns the procedural haste to adopt the text pre-Lisbon Treaty, which bypasses democratic codecision processes essential for rights protection.  
The issue's timid stance on balancing security and freedoms is inconsistent with GUE_NGL's mandate to prioritize fundamental rights over unchecked executive powers.

resolution: The European Parliament raised approval of the French Republic’s initiative (17483/2008) as amended, grounded in EU Treaty provisions on judicial cooperation (Article 30(1)(a)) and free movement (Articles 39(1) and 34(2)(c)), following the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs’ report (A7-0052/2009). It mandated the Council to align its text with Parliament’s amendments, required prior notification if the Council intended to deviate from the approved text, and insisted on renewed consultation if substantial changes to the French initiative were proposed. Parliament further instructed its President to formally convey its position to the Council, Commission, and French government, ensuring procedural adherence while safeguarding legislative coherence.

title: Motions for resolutions - Situation in Lithuania following the adoption of the law on protection of minors: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the Lithuanian Law on the Protection of Minors against the Detrimental Effects of Public Information
background: In July 2009, Lithuania adopted amendments to its Law on the Protection of Minors, prohibiting public information promoting homosexual, bisexual, or polygamous relations to minors. Following a presidential veto overruled by parliament, the law faced domestic review amid scrutiny under EU human rights frameworks. The Parliament will discuss the law’s compatibility with EU non-discrimination obligations and fundamental rights.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly promotes the issue’s condemnation of Lithuania’s law as discriminatory, aligning perfectly with their commitment to LGBTQ+ equality and opposition to state-sanctioned stigma.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing Article 4’s clarity to explicitly exclude artistic expression and public health discussions from restrictions, preventing misuse against queer communities.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the call for EU Fundamental Rights Agency oversight, effectively advancing their priority of binding human rights accountability across Member States.  
GREEN_EFA urges concrete timelines for Lithuania’s working group to revise the law, ensuring alignment with the Yogyakarta Principles on sexual orientation and gender identity.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the issue’s critical balance between child protection and fundamental freedoms, reflecting their manifesto stance against censorship disguised as safeguarding.

ECR totally doubts the issue's interference in national child protection policies, asserting this violates subsidiarity principles under Article 4(2) TEU.  
ECR rejects the characterization of Lithuania's law as discriminatory, emphasizing its alignment with parental rights to shape children's moral education.  
ECR contends the issue improperly conflates legitimate age-appropriate content regulation with LGBTQ+ discrimination, contrary to ECR's sovereignty-first agenda.  
ECR argues the issue overlooks critical distinctions between restricting harmful content and suppressing identities, a core flaw in its legal analysis.  
ECR opposes EU institutions' role in redefining "detrimental effects" on minors, which remains firmly within national competence under EU treaties.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding Lithuania’s Law on the Protection of Minors, amended in July 2009 to prohibit promoting homosexual, bisexual, or polygamous relations to minors, set to take effect on 1 March 2010, citing potential harm to minors. It criticized the law’s vague wording, particularly Article 4, for risking discriminatory interpretations and conflicting with EU and international human rights obligations, including non-discrimination principles under Article 13 of the EC Treaty and the Charter of Fundamental Rights. The resolution highlighted the law’s ambiguity over its scope, including potential restrictions on media, art, and public events, and noted ongoing reviews by Lithuanian authorities following the President’s veto overruling. It welcomed Lithuania’s establishment of a working group to align the law with EU and international standards, urged compliance with human rights frameworks, and called on the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights to assess the law’s conformity with EU treaties. The Parliament reaffirmed commitments to combat discrimination based on sexual orientation, uphold child protection principles, and monitor developments, stressing the need to balance minors’ protection with fundamental freedoms and equality.

title: Motions for resolutions - Swiss quotas on the number of residence permits granted to nationals of Poland, Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia, Slovenia, Slovakia, Czech Republic, Hungary: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on Swiss quotas on the number of residence permits granted to nationals of Poland, Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia, Slovenia, Slovakia, the Czech Republic and Hungary
background: Switzerland invoked a 1999 EU-Swiss Agreement safeguard clause in May 2012, introducing quotas on residence permits for eight EU Member States after transitional periods under 2004/2008 protocols expired. The EU contested the measure's compliance with bilateral agreements. The Parliament will discuss Switzerland's residence permit quotas and alignment with EU-Swiss free movement obligations.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects the issue's reliance on EU legal harmonization as fundamentally disputeing with their sovereignty-first principles, particularly regarding Directive 2004/38's expansionist interpretation.  
EFD opposes the demand for "dynamic adaptation" of bilateral agreements, deeming this incompatible with their stance against creeping EU jurisdictional overreach into Swiss autonomy.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of national labor market sovereignty by condemning Switzerland's flanking measures without addressing disproportionate EU service provider advantages.  
EFD opposes fundamentally the issue's systemic focus on EU institutional enforcement mechanisms, which contradicts their advocacy for intergovernmental dispute issue.  
While acknowledging concerns about Swiss quotas, EFD cannot endorse the issue's implicit EU-centralizing agenda regarding third-country agreements.

GREEN_EFA strongly advocates the issue's condemnation of nationality-based discrimination against Central and Eastern Europeans, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to equality and non-discrimination in the EU single market.  
GREEN_EFA approves the urgency in demanding Switzerland revoke unlawful quotas, effectively advancing their manifesto priorities to defend free movement and EU citizen rights.  
GREEN_EFA proposes postponing the vote for 14 days to enable parliamentary delegation negotiations with Swiss authorities, enhancing diplomatic issue pathways while maintaining the issue’s core objectives.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the issue’s criticism of disproportionate "flanking measures" burdening SMEs, strongly resonating with their economic justice principles for fair market access.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the emphasis on aligning bilateral agreements with Directive 2004/38, matching their legal harmonization agenda to protect migrant worker rights.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over Switzerland’s unilateral decision to impose quotas on long-term residence permits for nationals of eight EU Member States (Poland, Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia, Slovenia, Slovakia, Czech Republic, and Hungary) starting in May 2012, invoking a safeguard clause under the 1999 Agreement on Free Movement of Persons. The resolution deemed this action discriminatory and legally unfounded, as the clause does not permit nationality-based restrictions and the required 10% threshold for activation had not been met. It urged Switzerland to revoke the quotas and criticized its extension of transitional restrictions for Bulgarian and Romanian workers until May 2014, contrary to the 2008 Protocol. The Parliament also condemned Switzerland’s "flanking measures," such as prior notification requirements, 8-day waiting periods, and financial guarantees for EU service providers, which disproportionately burden SMEs, and highlighted the unlawful ban on German and Austrian taxis at Swiss airports. It called for alignment of bilateral agreements with evolving EU law, including Directive 2004/38 on free movement, and stressed the need for stronger surveillance, dispute resolution mechanisms, and dynamic adaptation of the agreements to ensure a transparent, predictable single market. The resolution urged the Commission to address these issues urgently and deepen EU-Swiss cooperation to overcome systemic challenges in implementing bilateral commitments.

title: Movement of persons with a long-stay visa: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Convention Implementing the Schengen Agreement and Regulation (EC) No 562/2006 as regards movement of persons with a long-stay visa
background: The Schengen Convention restricted long-stay visa holders to the issuing Member State, with inconsistent national practices delaying residence permits. The 2010 Visa Code's abolition of D+C visas risked further mobility barriers. The Parliament will discuss aligning long-stay visa holders' movement rights with residence permit holders under Schengen rules.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects the proposal's equivalence between long-stay visas and residence permits, completely againsting with EFD's insistence on strict national border sovereignty.  
EFD opposes extending Schengen mobility to long-stay visa holders, overlooking critical security vulnerabilities in cross-border immigration enforcement.  
EFD condemns the issue's facilitation of third-country nationals' movement, which directly undermines efforts to combat illegal entry via secondary EU states.  
EFD highlights the proposal's failure to address chain migration risks, inconsistent with EFD's demand for absolute control over territorial access points.  
EFD warns this measure would erode Member States' capacity to track overstays, contradicting core principles of immigration restriction and border integrity.

ALDE completely approves the issue's advancement of freedom of movement for third-country nationals, perfectly aligning with their commitment to a borderless Europe that prioritizes secure mobility and integration.  
ALDE applauds the elimination of territorial restrictions for legal residents, effectively advancing their vision of a unified Schengen Area that fosters cultural exchange and academic collaboration.  
ALDE highlights the issue’s alignment with Treaty principles on legal migration, reinforcing their longstanding advocacy for coherent EU-wide policies that transcend national barriers.  
ALDE emphasizes the strategic importance of framing Europe as a single entity to third-country nationals, consistent with their mission to strengthen the EU’s global identity and attractiveness.  
ALDE commends the issue for resolving procedural discontinuities under the Lisbon Treaty, ensuring legal clarity in cross-border rights for students, researchers, and long-term visa holders.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position by adopting the first reading on a legislative proposal concerning freedom of movement and immigration, incorporating the contents of Commission proposal COM(2009)0090 and related draft reports into procedure 2009/0028 (COD), thereby declaring procedure 2009/0025 (COD) lapsed. It emphasized alignment with the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU, particularly Articles 77(2)(b) and (c) and 79(2)(a), to ensure legal coherence in policies on border controls and legal migration. The resolution urged the Commission to resubmit the proposal if intending significant amendments or replacements and directed its President to transmit Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural continuity under the post-Lisbon Treaty framework.

title: Protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data (General Data Protection Regulation)
background: Rapid digitalization, globalization of data flows, and fragmented national implementations of the 1995 EU Data Protection Directive highlighted the need to modernize privacy frameworks. The Lisbon Treaty empowered EU institutions to strengthen fundamental rights protections in cross-border contexts. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing data protection rules to address technological advancements and ensure consistent application across member states.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA firmly endorses the issue's prohibition on personal data transfers to third countries, perfectly aligning with their commitment to digital sovereignty and fundamental rights against extraterritorial surveillance.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the urgency to finalize robust protections against U.S. tech giants like Google and Facebook, advancing their manifesto goal of reclaiming citizen control over corporate data exploitation.  
GREEN_EFA firmly endorses empowering European companies to become global leaders in secure data processing, reflecting their vision for ethical technological innovation under the GDPR framework.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with mandating explicit consent and "right to be forgotten" provisions, effectively advancing their decades-long advocacy against mass data retention in SWIFT and PNR agreements.  
GREEN_EFA firmly endorses simplifying privacy terms through standardized symbols, a policy innovation directly mirroring their 2014 campaign to reduce bureaucratic burdens while enhancing transparency.

ALDE strongly accepts the GDPR proposal’s harmonization of data protection rules across Europe, aligning perfectly with ALDE’s commitment to balancing robust privacy rights with innovation-friendly frameworks for digital economy growth.  
ALDE applauds the emphasis on strict enforcement mechanisms and sanctions, which effectively advance trust between citizens and businesses by ensuring compliance and fair competition.  
ALDE proposes strengthening safeguards for health data processing by mandating explicit consent protocols and transparent opt-out systems to prevent trust erosion, as exemplified by the UK’s mismanaged Care.data initiative.  
ALDE strongly endorses the reinstatement of the anti-Pfizer clause to protect EU citizens from third-country court orders, a critical measure for upholding jurisdictional sovereignty over personal data.  
ALDE emphasizes the need for predictable and well-structured data governance in medical research to maintain public confidence, urging enhanced oversight frameworks to prevent procedural failures like those seen in NHS England’s implementation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the Commission’s 2012 legislative proposal (COM(2012)0011) on harmonizing rules under Articles 16(2) and 114(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, emphasizing the need to address subsidiarity objections from five national parliaments (Belgium, Germany, France, Italy, Sweden) that argued the proposal overstepped EU competence. It integrated opinions from the European Economic and Social Committee, the European Data Protection Supervisor, and the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights, stressing the importance of data protection and fundamental rights compliance. The Parliament adopted its position, urging the Commission to reassess the proposal’s alignment with subsidiarity principles and to resubmit it if substantial revisions were made, while instructing its President to transmit the resolution to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to ensure transparency and adherence to legislative protocols.

title: Public access to European Parliament, Council and Commission documents: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council regarding public access to European Parliament, Council and Commission documents (recast)
background: The 2001 EU regulation on public access to documents required revision following the 2009 Lisbon Treaty's expanded transparency obligations. The European Commission proposed amendments in 2008 and 2011 to align rules with treaty provisions and extend coverage to all EU institutions. The Parliament will discuss revising public document access regulations to implement treaty requirements and broaden institutional transparency.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the proposed regulation's overbroad document definition that exposes sensitive legislative negotiations and strategic security discussions to undue external influence  
EPP opposes fundamentally the mandatory publication of trialogue minutes as it undermines confidential negotiation spaces vital for effective EU lawmaking  
EPP condemns the failure to protect business confidentiality and operational security of agencies like Europol through inadequate exceptions in Articles 4-6  
EPP disputes the issue's contradiction with existing data protection frameworks by prioritizing disclosure over privacy safeguards in Recital 18  
EPP warns that unlimited access to preparatory documents creates lobbyist vulnerabilities inconsistent with institutional integrity commitments

SD strongly upholds the issue’s transparency framework, aligning perfectly with SD’s longstanding commitment to open governance and citizen empowerment under the Charter of Fundamental Rights.  
SD proposes amending Article 3 to expand the definition of ‘document’ to include official information, enabling precise requests, partial access to classified materials, and reducing administrative burdens while upholding EU jurisprudence.  
SD applauds the rejection of Member States’ unconditional veto over document access, ensuring institutional accountability and compliance with European Court of Justice rulings.  
SD underscores the necessity of prohibiting financial barriers to information access, urging fee-free requests in line with the Aarhus Convention to prevent exclusionary practices.  
SD endorses strict classification criteria to prevent over-classification of documents, reinforcing transparency as essential to rebuilding public trust in EU institutions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the codification of legislative procedures, emphasizing that the Commission’s proposal (COM(2008)0229) incorporated into procedure 2008/0090(COD) did not introduce substantive amendments beyond those explicitly identified, as confirmed by the Consultative Working Party of the legal services. It noted that procedure 2011/0073(COD) had lapsed due to the integration of the Commission’s subsequent proposal (COM(2011)0137) into the earlier procedure, ensuring continuity. The resolution called on the Commission to re-engage Parliament if future proposals substantially alter or replace the current text, underscoring adherence to transparency and institutional cooperation under Articles 41 and 42 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights. It instructed its President to transmit Parliament’s position to the Council and Commission, reaffirming the need for procedural clarity and alignment with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (Article 294(3) and Article 15) while maintaining the unchanged substance of codified legal acts.

title: Public access to documents 2011-2013: REPORT on public access to documents (Rule 104(7)) for the years 2011-2013
background: Persistent challenges in public access to EU documents under Regulation 1049/2001, including limited transparency in international agreements and informal legislative trilogues (2011-2013), prompted scrutiny of institutional practices. The Parliament will discuss enhancing transparency mechanisms to strengthen democratic accountability and citizen engagement in EU decision-making.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the issue's demand for full trilogue document disclosure as firmly rejecting with legislative efficiency and data protection standards (Art. 2.4).  
EPP opposes mandatory publication of internal administrative texts, citing risks to staff privacy and institutional integrity under Charter Article 8.  
The proposal's blanket transparency approach overlooks critical aspects of competition law, directly contravening CJEU rulings on leniency programs (Case C-536/11).  
EPP condemns the issue's dismissal of legislative complexity safeguards, reaffirming the necessity of confidential preparatory phases per Recital C.  
This issue's absolutist transparency model conflicts with EPP's balanced approach to citizen engagement and operational security in international negotiations.

SD strongly accepts the issue's emphasis on transparency as a democratic cornerstone, aligning perfectly with SD's longstanding commitment to informed citizen participation and institutional accountability.  
SD approves the proactive publication of trilogue documents and expert group proceedings, which effectively advances SD's priority of dismantling opaque decision-making structures within EU governance.  
SD endorses the urgent revision of Regulation 1049/2001 to align with fundamental rights, noting its critical role in closing legal loopholes exposed by cases like Bavarian Lager and In‘t Veld.  
SD proposes clarifying the criteria for document classification in Article 4 to prevent over-broad interpretations that could undermine transparency goals, while fully supporting the issue’s privacy safeguards.  
SD applauds the integration of whistleblower protections and Aarhus Convention principles, recognizing their synergy with SD’s 2011-2013 anti-corruption and environmental democracy agendas.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the critical need for enhanced transparency across EU institutions to strengthen democratic participation, public trust, and accountability. It emphasized that broad access to documents, including those related to international agreements and trilogues (non-public negotiations between the Commission, Parliament, and Council), must be the default, with exceptions limited to legitimate grounds like international relations as defined in case law (e.g., In‘t Veld v Council, T-529/09). The resolution stressed the urgency of revising Regulation (EC) No 1049/2001 to align with the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights, addressing gaps in data protection and transparency highlighted by the Bavarian Lager case. It called for proactive publication of documents—including internal administrative texts, expert group proceedings (notably TTIP advisory groups), clinical trial reports, and EU budget details—on accessible registries with robust search functions. Institutions were urged to harmonize transparency practices, publish Council working group minutes with member state positions, and ensure timely disclosure of previously restricted documents. The Parliament criticized the lack of progress since 2011 on updating transparency rules and demanded faster, simpler complaint mechanisms to avoid costly litigation. It highlighted the need to protect whistleblowers through legal and financial safeguards, improve reporting on classified documents, and enforce the Aarhus Convention’s principles. Additionally, it pushed for transparency in expert and comitology groups, including public meetings, conflict-of-interest declarations, and standardized reporting on membership and decisions. Financial transparency measures included public databases on EU budget implementation and beneficiaries, while cartel leniency cases were to be assessed individually per Court of Justice rulings (Case C-536/11). Overall, the resolution sought a systemic shift toward openness to combat corruption, ensure accountability, and empower citizen engagement.

title: Qualification and status of third country nationals or stateless persons as beneficiaries of international protection: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on minimum standards for the qualification and status of third country nationals or stateless persons as beneficiaries of international protection and the content of the protection granted (recast)
background: Persistent disparities in EU Member States' asylum qualification criteria and protection standards, alongside evolving international refugee law and the 2012 deadline for a Common European Asylum System, prompted legislative review. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing minimum standards for recognizing third-country nationals' eligibility for international protection under EU law.

stances.stance:
ALDE strongly agrees the codification of the Qualification Directive as a vital step toward realizing a unified European asylum system by 2012, aligning with their commitment to solidarity and equitable responsibility-sharing among Member States.  
ALDE applauds the explicit inclusion of gender identity and sexual orientation as grounds for persecution, advancing protections for marginalized groups in line with progressive humanitarian values.  
ALDE welcomes the compromise on correlation tables, proposing enhanced clarity in Member States’ implementation reporting to ensure consistent application of asylum standards across the EU.  
ALDE highlights the strengthened safeguards for unaccompanied minors as a critical advancement, reflecting their prioritization of vulnerable populations in international protection frameworks.  
ALDE urges accelerated progress on harmonizing refugee and subsidiary protection statuses, particularly addressing residual disparities in residence permits and social benefits to achieve full equality.

ECR rejects the codification approach as totally conflicting with their principle of national sovereignty in asylum policy.  
ECR opposes mandatory EU standards that limit Member States' ability to maintain more favourable asylum provisions than those in Articles 4-7.  
ECR condemns the expanded family member definition under Section 2(c) as inconsistent with their strict immigration control priorities.  
ECR argues the narrow refusal grounds for refugee status in Article 15(3) overlook critical security vetting requirements.  
ECR fundamentally disputes the legal basis under TFEU Article 78(2)(b), viewing responsibility-sharing mechanisms as compulsion rather than voluntary coordination.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal concerning the codification of existing legal texts related to freedom of movement and asylum under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). The resolution confirmed that the proposal, based on a Commission communication and aligned with the Consultative Working Party’s assessment, did not introduce substantive amendments but instead consolidated unchanged provisions from prior acts into a single codified text. It emphasized adherence to legal bases under Article 78(2)(a) and (b) TFEU, which govern common asylum procedures and fair sharing of responsibility among member states. Parliament endorsed the codification process as a technical exercise to enhance clarity and transparency without altering the legal substance of existing rules. It instructed its President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, underscoring compliance with interinstitutional agreements on legislative recasting and procedural coherence.

title: Surveillance of external sea borders: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing rules for the surveillance of the external sea borders in the context of operational cooperation coordinated by the European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union
background: Increased migratory pressure from North Africa post-Arab Spring, recurring maritime tragedies in the Mediterranean, and divergent national border surveillance practices prompted EU institutional action following a Court of Justice ruling annulling prior guidelines. The Parliament will discuss establishing standardized EU rules for external sea border surveillance operations coordinated by Frontex.

stances.stance:
SD strongly advocates the expanded mandate for maritime search and rescue operations, which aligns perfectly with SD's commitment to prioritizing human life over border enforcement.  
SD approves the explicit prohibition of pushbacks and non-refoulement guarantees as critical advancements in upholding international human rights standards at sea.  
SD endorses reinforced parliamentary oversight of Frontex operations, ensuring accountability through mandatory reporting on compliance with the European Convention on Human Rights.  
SD proposes enhancing provisions for safe legal migration pathways in future legislation to complement border measures, addressing root causes through coordinated EU development and trade policies.  
SD applauds binding solidarity mechanisms between member states as effectively advancing shared responsibility for migration management while protecting vulnerable groups.

GUE_NGL rejects the proposal's conflation of border control with migration management as fundamentally incompatible with human rights obligations  
GUE_NGL opposes the offshore screening mechanisms that institutionalize maritime pushbacks under the guise of "efficient migration control"  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's failure to impose binding accountability on Member States for lethal border practices documented in Ceuta and the Aegean  
GUE_NGL denounces the legalization of disembarkation in third countries as a violation of the non-refoulement principle enshrined in international law  
GUE_NGL asserts that prioritizing Frontex operations over state responsibility perpetuates deadly border regimes rather than addressing root causes of displacement

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on combating organized crime, corruption, and money laundering, emphasizing the need to strengthen efforts against human trafficking and death traffickers, as outlined in its resolution of 23 October 2013. It adopted its first-reading stance based on a report by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, incorporating opinions from the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Committee on Transport and Tourism, urging the Commission to prioritize cross-border cooperation and legislative measures to address these crimes. The resolution called on the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if substantial amendments or replacements were planned, ensuring continued alignment with EU objectives under Article 77(2)(d) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. Additionally, Parliament instructed its President to formally transmit its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing institutional collaboration to enhance legal frameworks and operational responses to transnational criminal networks.

title: Temporary reintroduction of border control at internal borders: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 562/2006 in order to provide for common rules on the temporary reintroduction of border control at internal borders in exceptional circumstances
background: The Schengen Area's border-free framework faced challenges from migration pressures, security concerns, and unilateral member state border control reintroductions, prompting calls for harmonized EU-level rules. The Parliament will discuss regulatory amendments to establish common criteria for temporary internal border controls in exceptional circumstances under revised governance mechanisms.

stances.stance:
EPP totally advocates the reinforced Schengen governance as a vital defense against nationalist populism, perfectly aligning with its commitment to European integration.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's balance of free movement and crisis response mechanisms, upholding citizens' security as a core treaty obligation.  
EPP totally advocates the centralized evaluation system through Frontex and Commission oversight, recognizing this as essential for Schengen's operational credibility.  
EPP perfectly supports the strict limitation of border controls to exceptional cases, affirming this as critical to maintaining trust in the single area's integrity.  
EPP totally advocates using EU-level assessments to address external border weaknesses, proposing accelerated integration of Bulgaria and Romania to strengthen Schengen's geopolitical coherence.

GREEN_EFA rejects the reintroduction of national discretion over border controls as a fundamental erosion of Schengen’s border-free principle.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the exclusion of parliamentary co-decision authority, demanding binding EU-level evaluation mechanisms instead of voluntary consultations.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue’s reference to "illegal immigration" as enabling discriminatory profiling and unjustified border closures.  
GREEN_EFA challenges the vague "external border deficiencies" justification, asserting it undermines free movement without objective safeguards.  
GREEN_EFA asserts the outcome contradicts EU solidarity by prioritizing unilateral state actions over collective governance frameworks.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s legislative proposal (COM(2011)0560), grounded in Treaty Articles 77 and 294 TFEU and the Committee on Civil Liberties’ report (A7-0200/2012). It highlighted subsidiarity concerns from seven national parliaments (French, Dutch, Portuguese, Romanian, Slovak, Swedish) asserting the proposal’s non-compliance with EU principles. The resolution urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantially amending or replacing the proposal and instructed its President to forward the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national legislatures, emphasizing procedural adherence while addressing legislative objections.

title: Processing of personal data for the purposes of crime prevention: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data by competent authorities for the purposes of prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of criminal offences or the execution of criminal penalties, and the free movement of such data
background: Prior to parliamentary consideration, existing EU data protection frameworks, including the 1995 Directive and 2008 Framework Decision, faced challenges from technological advancements, cross-border data flows, and evolving law enforcement needs amid heightened privacy concerns. The Parliament will discuss modernizing data protection standards for criminal justice authorities to balance crime prevention with fundamental rights.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the current directive proposal for violating subsidiarity principles, as raised by national parliaments, which undermines member states' regulatory sovereignty in law enforcement data processing.  
EPP opposes the fragmented legislative approach that separates the regulation and directive, as highlighted by Carlos Coelho, which creates legal uncertainty and weakens comprehensive data protection standards.  
EPP completely conflicts with provisions that impose disproportionate burdens on SMEs, as Lara Comi and Kinga Gál argued, which stifle innovation and economic growth in the digital single market.  
The proposal overlooks critical operational needs for medical research and public security, as Anna Maria Corazza Bildt noted, by failing to provide adequate exceptions for sensitive data handling.  
EPP condemns the exclusion of key stakeholders in trilogue negotiations, as Axel Voss mentioned, which undermines democratic legislative processes and compromises balanced outcomes.

GUE_NGL completely agrees the issue's grounding in fundamental rights to privacy and data protection, perfectly aligning with their opposition to mass surveillance regimes.  
GUE_NGL perfectly aligns with the directive's modernization of data protection standards, ensuring citizens' rights to unobstructed private lives and personality development.  
GUE_NGL applauds the integration of EU fundamental rights agency recommendations, effectively advancing their manifesto commitment to shield individuals from state overreach.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes the urgency for Council adoption, declaring any delay in implementing these safeguards a betrayal of EU treaty obligations and human dignity.  
GUE_NGL recognizes the proposal as a vital barrier against data commodification, upholding their principle that personal information must never reduce humans to observable objects.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the European Commission’s 2012 legislative proposal (COM(2012)0010), addressing objections from the German Bundesrat and Swedish Parliament that the draft violated subsidiarity principles. It incorporated opinions from the European Data Protection Supervisor (March 2012) and the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights (October 2012) to strengthen compliance with fundamental rights and data protection standards. The Parliament adopted its first-reading position, urging the Commission to resubmit the proposal if substantially amended and instructing its President to transmit the adopted text to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, emphasizing adherence to Treaty obligations and subsidiarity while advancing legislative coherence.

title: Report: Sonia Alfano - European Crime Prevention Network (EUCPN): REPORT on the initiative of the Kingdom of Belgium, the Czech Republic, the Federal Republic of Germany, the Kingdom of Spain, the French Republic, the Republic of Hungary, the Kingdom of the Netherlands, the Slovak Republic, the Republic of Finland, the Kingdom of Sweden, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland with a view to the adoption of a Council Decision setting up a European Crime Prevention Network (EUCPN) and repealing Decision 2001/427/JHA
background: Several EU member states proposed a Council Decision to establish the European Crime Prevention Network (EUCPN), replacing the 2001 framework. The Treaty of Lisbon’s imminent entry introduced a new legal basis for crime prevention, altering legislative procedures. The Parliament will discuss the EUCPN’s establishment under the revised institutional framework.

stances.stance:
EFD completely disputes the EUCPN framework for enabling Europol’s indiscriminate data harvesting, which directly conflicts with EFD’s defense of individual privacy and national legal sovereignty.  
EFD rejects the proposal’s failure to prohibit data transfers to authoritarian third countries, a critical oversight undermining citizen protections against foreign surveillance.  
EFD condemns the institutionalization of Europol immunity as antithetical to British legal principles of accountability, where no law enforcement enjoys such unchecked privileges.  
EFD highlights the issue’s procedural recklessness in bypassing Lisbon Treaty safeguards, accelerating EU judicial consolidation without democratic consent.  
EFD demands adherence to national referenda processes before implementing EU policing structures that erode habeas corpus and trial rights.

GUE_NGL rejects the procedural urgency imposed on examining the EUCPN initiative, as it preempts the Lisbon Treaty’s co-decision framework and undermines parliamentary sovereignty.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the initiative’s failure to safeguard privacy and free expression, prioritizing coercive security measures over democratic freedoms they staunchly defend.  
GUE_NGL condemns the Council’s absence during debate, reflecting disregard for accountability and transparency in policymaking.  
GUE_NGL insists the proposal must be withdrawn to align with Article 84 TFEU, ensuring future measures adhere to strengthened judicial oversight and parliamentary co-decision.  
GUE_NGL highlights the initiative’s incompatibility with balancing security and civil liberties, a cornerstone of their advocacy against disproportionate state power.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the draft Council Decision to establish a European Crime Prevention Network (EUCPN), rejecting the initiative proposed by 11 member states as insufficiently ambitious and procedurally premature. The resolution highlighted that the Treaty of Lisbon, set to enter force on 1 December 2009, would introduce Article 84 TFEU, granting Parliament co-decision powers under the ordinary legislative procedure and providing a stronger legal basis for crime prevention measures. It urged the member states to withdraw their initiative and called on the Council to delay formal adoption until after the Treaty’s implementation, ensuring full judicial oversight by the Court of Justice of the EU, enhanced Commission involvement, and parliamentary scrutiny. The resolution emphasized the need to align the EUCPN with the future legal framework and committed to expedited consideration of alternative proposals, such as establishing an observatory, under the new procedural rules.

title: Report: Sophia in 't Veld- Implementing rules governing Europol's relations with partners, including the exchange of personal data and classified information: REPORT on the draft Council decision adopting the implementing rules governing Europol's relations with partners, including the exchange of personal data and classified information
background: The 2009 Europol Decision established rules for EU police cooperation, with the Treaty of Lisbon's imminent entry requiring alignment of existing measures under new legislative procedures. The Parliament will discuss implementing rules for Europol's data exchanges and partnerships under the revised legal framework.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA entirely opposes the Council's procedural bypass of colegislative scrutiny, contradicting their mandate for democratic police cooperation frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the proposal's failure to address decentralized forensic coordination needs, particularly in states like Spain with regionalized legal systems.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue's critical alignment with Lisbon Treaty principles, which the Council's amendments dangerously preempt.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the disregard for Parliament's role in overseeing Europol's data exchange protocols, a core transparency requirement.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes that regional operational realities must shape Europol rules – an omission rendering the proposal institutionally incoherent.

SD rejects the Council's proposal as fundamentally incompatible with democratic oversight requirements under the Lisbon Treaty framework.  
SD opposes provisions allowing undefined "absolute necessity" justifications for sharing sensitive data (Article 15(2)), creating dangerous loopholes for racial profiling.  
SD condemns the attempt to preempt Parliament's codecision powers by rushing adoption before Lisbon Treaty implementation.  
SD demands explicit exclusion of pseudoscientific racial classifications in all data-sharing protocols to uphold human dignity principles.  
SD insists any Europol reforms must include Parliament's authority to verify compliance with EU data protection standards.

resolution: The European Parliament raised objections to the Council’s proposed amendments to the Europol Decision (2009/371/JHA), rejecting the text and urging the Council to withdraw its proposal. It emphasized that while supporting Europol’s mission, no changes should be made to its implementing measures until the Treaty of Lisbon enters into force, ensuring alignment with its new legal framework for police cooperation. The resolution called on the Commission or Council to present a revised Europol decision proposal within six months of the Treaty’s implementation, stressing the need to adapt Europol’s operations to the updated institutional structure. This stance aimed to prevent premature adjustments and ensure coherence with the forthcoming legal provisions under the Lisbon Treaty.

title:
Report: Tanja Fajon - Third country nationals subject to or exempt from a visa requirement when crossing external borders
on the proposal for a Council regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 listing the third countries whose nationals must be in possession of visas when crossing the external borders and those whose nationals are exempt from that requirement: REPORT on the proposal for a Council regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 listing the third countries whose nationals must be in possession of visas when crossing the external borders and those whose nationals are exempt from that requirement
background: Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 established EU visa requirements for third-country nationals, with the 2003 Thessaloniki Agenda affirming a European perspective for Western Balkan states. The Parliament will discuss amending visa regulations for third-country nationals, focusing on the Western Balkans’ inclusion.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the visa liberalization for Western Balkan countries, aligning with their commitment to European integration and regional stability through tangible mobility measures.  
EPP applauds the issue's adherence to procedural frameworks, emphasizing that strict treaty compliance reinforces institutional credibility in justice and home affairs matters.  
EPP endorses the benchmark-based approach, noting that maintaining clear reform requirements ensures sustainable progress while upholding EU security standards.  
EPP urges intensified technical assistance to Albania and Bosnia and Herzegovina, proposing accelerated Commission monitoring to expedite their inclusion in future visa exemptions.  
EPP suggests expanding the visa dialogue model to Eastern Partnership countries, particularly Moldova, to prevent new divides while maintaining rigorous conditionality principles.

GREEN_EFA approves the urgency for synchronized implementation timelines across the region, particularly endorsing mid-2010 deadlines as a catalyst for reform progress.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2009 proposal (COM(2009)0366) concerning legal measures under the EC Treaty, approving the proposal as amended while emphasizing procedural cooperation between institutions. It called on the Commission to revise its proposal in line with Parliament’s amendments under Article 250(2) of the EC Treaty and urged the Council to notify Parliament if it deviates from the approved text or to re-consult Parliament if intending substantial changes to the proposal. The resolution, informed by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and the Committee on Foreign Affairs, underscored adherence to legislative procedures and institutional accountability, instructing its President to formally communicate Parliament’s stance to the Council and Commission.

title: Report: Timothy Kirkhope - Rules on the confidentiality of Europol information: REPORT on the draft Council decision adopting the rules on the confidentiality of Europol information
background: The Council proposed draft rules on Europol information confidentiality under the 2009 Europol Decision, with the Treaty of Lisbon's imminent ratification altering EU police cooperation frameworks. The Parliament will discuss aligning Europol's operational rules with the new legal basis and institutional procedures post-Lisbon Treaty implementation.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects the Europol confidentiality framework for enabling unchecked data sharing with authoritarian third states like Russia, firmly opposeing with EFD's defense of national sovereignty.  
EFD opposes granting Europol officers legal immunity as antithetical to British civil liberties, a core principle enshrined in EFD's opposition to EU judicial overreach.  
The proposal overlooks critical safeguards against sexual preference data collection, which EFD condemns as invasive state surveillance incompatible with privacy rights.  
EFD highlights the issue's failure to require public referenda on the Lisbon Treaty's legitimacy, directly contradicting EFD's democratic accountability mandates.
