GUE_NGL highlights the issue's failure to guarantee binding safeguards against mass surveillance practices that threaten free movement and privacy rights.  
GUE_NGL condemns the absence of provisions ensuring judicial review of Europol's data-sharing with third countries, contradicting their stance on accountability.  
GUE_NGL demands withdrawal of all current texts, citing irreconcilable conflicts with their principle that security cooperation must never override constitutional freedoms.

resolution: The European Parliament raised objections to the Council’s proposed text on the European Police Office (Europol), rejecting it due to concerns over aligning the measures with the imminent entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, which would establish a new legal framework for police cooperation. While reaffirming support for Europol, Parliament opposed any amendments to the existing Europol Decision until the Lisbon Treaty’s provisions could be applied, ensuring future measures comply with the updated legal structure. It urged the Council to withdraw its current proposal and called on the Commission or Council to present a revised Europol decision within six months of the Lisbon Treaty’s implementation, emphasizing the need for a declaration in Plenary to formalize this timeline. Parliament also directed its President to communicate this position to the EU institutions, prioritizing coherence with the forthcoming treaty framework over immediate changes.

title:
Report: Timothy Kirkhope- Accreditation of forensic laboratory activities

The Parliament will discuss establishing an EU-wide forensic accreditation framework under the new institutional provisions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the legal basis of the draft initiative proposed by the Kingdom of Sweden and the Kingdom of Spain (11419/2009), citing inconsistencies with Article 39(1) and Article 34(2)(c) of the EU Treaty. The resolution emphasized substantive legal discrepancies over procedural elements, focusing on the initiative’s incompatibility with established EU Treaty provisions without detailing amendments or voting processes.

title: Right of access to a lawyer in criminal proceedings and right to communicate upon arrest: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the right of access to a lawyer in criminal proceedings and on the right to communicate upon arrest
background: Disparities in member states' criminal defense rights and inconsistent application of fair trial standards under the European Convention on Human Rights raised concerns over mutual trust in cross-border judicial cooperation, particularly regarding the European Arrest Warrant. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing access to legal counsel and communication rights during arrest to strengthen procedural safeguards.

stances.stance:
ALDE fundamentally advocates the directive’s guarantee of effective lawyer participation in all criminal proceedings, perfectly aligning with their longstanding commitment to eliminating procedural inequalities.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s extension of access rights to non-detained suspects, advancing their priority of universal procedural safeguards across EU justice systems.  
ALDE highlights the directive’s dual representation requirement for European Arrest Warrant cases as a critical enhancement of transnational fair trial protections.  
ALDE proposes strengthening detention protocols through mandatory video recording of interrogations, building on the Basque Ertzaintza model to prevent rights abuses.  
ALDE fundamentally advocates the directive’s binding obligations for member states to actively facilitate lawyer access, reflecting their manifesto principles on state accountability in justice systems.

SD applauds the assurance of confidential lawyer-client communications as a critical advancement in defense rights, effectively advancing SD’s priority of fair trial protections.  
SD approves the strict limitations on exceptions to legal access, ensuring national particularities do not undermine core procedural safeguards for suspects.  
SD proposes enhancing the directive’s impact by urging the Commission to prioritize legislation on free legal assistance for economically disadvantaged individuals, minors, and incapacitated persons to prevent systemic inequalities.  
SD emphasizes that accessible legal aid is essential to transform procedural rights into practical justice outcomes, ensuring the directive’s principles benefit all citizens equally.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0326) concerning judicial cooperation in criminal matters under Article 82(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), following the ordinary legislative procedure outlined in Article 294 TFEU. It incorporated contributions from the Bulgarian, Italian, and Portuguese national parliaments, considered the European Economic and Social Committee’s opinion of 7 December 2011, and consulted the Committee of the Regions. The resolution reflected the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs’ report (A7-0228/2013) and the Committee on Legal Affairs’ opinion, while noting the Council’s agreement on 4 June 2013 to approve Parliament’s position as per Article 294(4) TFEU. Parliament formally adopted its first-reading position, urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments, and directed its President to transmit the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring alignment with procedural and substantive legislative requirements.

title: Right to information in criminal proceedings: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the right to information in criminal proceedings
background: Disparate national standards on criminal procedural rights across EU Member States and gaps in existing human rights frameworks regarding information access for defendants created challenges for judicial cooperation under mutual recognition principles. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing minimum EU-level safeguards to ensure fair trial rights and effective defense in cross-border criminal proceedings.

stances.stance:
EFD partially accepts the directive's intent but requests revisions to Article 5, mandating judicial authority to assess prima facie evidence in European Arrest Warrant cases to prevent extradition without substantiated charges.  
EFD contends the proposal completely conflicts with procedural fairness by allowing extradition for speculative future offenses, as evidenced by Dr. Meizoso's case, demanding explicit prohibitions in Article 2(3).  
EFD highlights that mere information provision overlooks critical defense needs, urging amendment of Section 4 to guarantee immediate access to full case files upon arrest notification.  
EFD stresses the issue fails to address EAW misuse for investigative fishing expeditions, requiring Article 7 revisions to permit refusal of warrants lacking specific existing charges.  
EFD argues current wording creates legal uncertainty, proposing binding timelines in Article 9 for charging decisions post-extradition to align with their anti-arbitrary detention principles.

ECR fundamentally agrees the directive’s comprehensive framework for suspect information rights, perfectly aligning with ECR’s longstanding commitment to judicial fairness and procedural transparency in cross-border cases.  
ECR highlights the necessity of rigorous implementation safeguards, proposing strengthened mechanisms for monitoring complaint systems to ensure the directive’s principles are uniformly applied across all jurisdictions.  
ECR perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on linguistic accessibility, recognizing its critical role in upholding defense rights for non-resident suspects as a cornerstone of equitable criminal proceedings.  
ECR underscores the urgency of parallel legislative action to address victims’ information rights, urging future initiatives to balance protections without diminishing the directive’s core focus on suspect safeguards.  
ECR applauds the directive’s alignment with subsidiarity principles, effectively advancing ECR’s priority of harmonizing essential judicial standards while respecting national legal traditions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its adoption of a first reading position on a legislative act concerning judicial cooperation in criminal matters under Article 82(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), based on the Commission’s 2010 proposal (COM(2010)0392). The resolution incorporated contributions from the Greek, Spanish, Italian, and Portuguese national parliaments, considered the European Economic and Social Committee’s opinion of 8 December 2010, and consulted the Committee of Regions. It formally urged the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if intending to amend or replace it substantially, while instructing the Parliament’s President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring alignment with EU legislative procedures under Article 294 TFEU.

title: Rights and Citizenship Programme 2014-2020: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing for the period 2014 to 2020 the Rights and Citizenship Programme
background: The European Union's 2010-2014 Stockholm Programme prioritized justice and citizenship policies, requiring follow-up funding mechanisms. Existing legal frameworks under the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU and the Charter of Fundamental Rights necessitated consolidated programming to address cross-border judicial cooperation gaps and disparities in rights awareness. The Parliament will discuss establishing a 2014-2020 funding programme for justice, equality, and citizenship initiatives.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the judicial training initiatives and cross-border legal harmonization, aligning with their commitment to a stable single market underpinned by predictable legal frameworks.  
EPP applauds the prioritization of gender equality, disability rights, and child protection as central to building citizen trust in EU institutions.  
EPP proposes enhancing budgetary flexibility to address underfunded areas like victim support programs while maintaining core training commitments.  
EPP endorses the focus on combating violence against women and children, urging member states to allocate program resources to cross-border alert systems.  
EPP recommends expanding language-specific legal training modules to improve judicial responsiveness to minority communities.

ECR opposes the integration of EU-wide drugs policy coordination, advocating instead for national sovereignty under existing strategies like the EU Drugs Strategy 2013-2020  
ECR absolutely conflicts ideological mandates on gender equality interpretations, citing risks to free speech and family integrity in Clause 12(b)  
ECR condemns the expansion of cross-border child protection measures that enable state overreach into parental rights, referencing multiple Member State cases  
ECR disputes the effectiveness of judicial cooperation mechanisms that permit political interference in law enforcement, as evidenced by the Veljko Marić extradition case

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal concerning EU policies related to civil liberties, justice, home affairs, employment, social affairs, gender equality, budgets, legal matters, and petitions. It adopted its first-reading stance, emphasizing alignment with Treaty provisions on non-discrimination, public health, consumer protection, and harmonization of internal market rules. The resolution incorporated opinions from multiple committees and advisory bodies, including the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions. Parliament urged the Commission to re-engage it if proposing substantial amendments or alternative texts, ensuring procedural continuity. It directed its President to formally transmit Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing institutional cooperation and transparency in the legislative process.

title: Rights to interpretation and translation in criminal proceedings: REPORT on the draft directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the rights to interpretation and to translation in criminal proceedings
background: Increased cross-border judicial cooperation under mutual recognition principles, including the European Arrest Warrant, highlighted disparities in procedural safeguards for non-native defendants. Previous EU efforts to standardize fair trial rights stalled in 2007. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing interpretation and translation access in criminal proceedings to address linguistic barriers and ensure equitable legal representation.

stances.stance:
EFD conditionally endorses the directive but requests revisions to Article 3 to explicitly exempt member states from enforcing European Arrest Warrant requests where national rights protections exceed those in the issuing country.  
EFD asserts that the directive fundamentally rejects with the principle of subsidiarity by failing to address systemic disparities in judicial standards that erode UK citizens' liberties under mutual recognition frameworks.  
EFD highlights critical resource allocation flaws, noting that the proposed €25 million for training overlooks EU institutions' monopolization of qualified interpreters, requiring a dedicated amendment to cap EU agency recruitment from national pools.  
EFD objects to mutual recognition provisions until minimum detention facility standards are codified, citing Korydallos prison conditions as violating Charter of Fundamental Rights protections referenced in the issue.  
EFD requests amendment of Clause 7 to require judicial review of prima facie evidence validity prior to extradition, aligning with their opposition to unchecked EAW implementation.

GREEN_EFA firmly accepts the establishment of minimum procedural standards for cross-border judicial cooperation, perfectly aligning with their commitment to upholding the rule of law and ensuring equitable access to justice.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the directive’s guarantee of interpretation rights in criminal proceedings, which effectively advances their priority of protecting linguistic diversity and vulnerable individuals’ rights.  
GREEN_EFA strongly advocates for the explicit inclusion of regional and minority languages in translation provisions, proposing future integration of the European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages into the EU acquis.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the necessity of reducing the 36-month implementation period as an enhancement opportunity to expedite procedural fairness across Member States.  
GREEN_EFA supports the directive’s harmonization of judicial cultures while urging continuous dialogue to address diverse legal systems without compromising fundamental rights.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to establish common EU rules for investigating and prosecuting cross-border crimes, emphasizing enhanced judicial cooperation and procedural safeguards. The resolution endorsed harmonizing measures to ensure suspects’ rights, including access to legal advice and interpretation, particularly for vulnerable individuals. It supported mutual recognition of judicial decisions across member states and called for allocating €25 million from the EU budget to fund training programs for legal practitioners and improve cross-border data exchange systems. The Parliament stressed compliance with the principle of subsidiarity, affirming that EU-level action was necessary to address disparities in national laws hindering effective cooperation. It also urged the Commission to monitor implementation and report on the impact of these measures within three years, ensuring alignment with fundamental rights under the Charter of Fundamental Rights.

title: Visa requirements for third-countries nationals: REPORTon the proposal for aregulationof the European Parliament and of the Councilamending Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 listing the third countries whose nationals must be in possession of visas when crossing the external borders and those whose nationals are exempt from that requirement
background: The EU's visa policy under Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 required updates due to evolving partnerships with neighboring states, Moldova's fulfillment of visa liberalization benchmarks, and geopolitical tensions in Eastern Europe. The Parliament will discuss amending visa exemption criteria and harmonizing the EU's common visa policy framework.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects the issue's failure to address Ukraine's eligibility for visa liberalization, inconsistent with their stance on fostering closer EU ties with Eastern partners.  
EFD opposes the omission of Ukraine from amended visa requirements, highlighting a contradiction with Moldova's preferential treatment despite similar reform commitments.  
The proposal firmly condemns with EFD's principle of reciprocal trust by overlooking Ukraine's societal demand for European integration.

GREEN_EFA strongly accepts the issue's commitment to improving Schengen visa cooperation, perfectly aligning with their principles of transparency and equitable access.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the endorsement of shared consular resources as a vital step toward reducing administrative burdens and enhancing service quality across Member States.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s procedural safeguards as essential for maintaining parliamentary oversight in future visa policy developments.  
GREEN_EFA proposes that the Commission’s forthcoming Visa Code review prioritize expanding common application centers through EU funding, strictly enforcing limitations on commercial intermediaries, and completing the study on a unified European visa mechanism.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes that full Member State participation in collaborative systems remains critical to achieving the issue’s goals of efficiency and fairness.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2013 proposal (COM(2013)0853) concerning measures under Article 77(2)(a) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which relates to border checks and free movement. It adopted its first-reading stance by endorsing the Commission’s original proposal without amendments, underscoring alignment with the proposed legislative framework. The resolution emphasized procedural obligations, urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if it later seeks substantial modifications or substitutes the proposal with an alternative text, ensuring parliamentary oversight. Additionally, Parliament directed its President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, the Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing institutional transparency and adherence to legislative processes under Article 294 of the Treaty.

title: Sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children and child pornography: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on combating the sexual abuse, sexual exploitation of children and child pornography, repealing Framework Decision 2004/68/JHA
background: Rising cross-border child sexual exploitation cases and technological advancements enabling online abuse, coupled with fragmented national legal frameworks under the 2004 EU framework decision, highlighted gaps in addressing offenses. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing criminal definitions and penalties for child sexual abuse, exploitation, and pornography across member states.

stances.stance:
ALDE strongly promotes the directive’s emphasis on **source-level removal of child pornography websites**, aligning perfectly with ALDE’s longstanding commitment to proactive child protection through technological accountability.  
ALDE approves the harmonized criminal penalties for cross-border exploitation and sex tourism, effectively advancing ALDE’s priority of closing jurisdictional loopholes that endanger children.  
ALDE proposes resolving **roaming charge disputes for the 116000 hotline** to ensure universal accessibility, enhancing the directive’s operational coherence without opposing its foundational goals.  
ALDE applauds the focus on **international cooperation to dismantle non-EU-based child abuse networks**, matching ALDE’s manifesto-driven advocacy for globalized justice frameworks.  
ALDE emphasizes strengthening **cross-border disqualification registries for child-related work**, reinforcing the directive’s aim to track offenders dynamically across Member States.

GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the directive's penal approach, which neglects comprehensive victim support systems, conflicting with their commitment to prioritize child protection over punitive measures.  
GUE_NGL rejects the disproportionate focus on online aspects, arguing it overlooks the real-world origins of crimes and fails to address systemic causes of exploitation.  
GUE_NGL condemns the website blocking provisions as inconsistent with their opposition to internet censorship, warning of dangerous precedents for digital freedoms.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the proposed directive aimed at combating sexual abuse, exploitation, and child sexual material, emphasizing the Commission’s objective to address increasing criminal offenses exacerbated by modern communications and insufficiently stringent or harmonized national laws. While acknowledging the directive’s intent to establish uniform criminal definitions and sanctions across Member States, Parliament critically questioned the proposal’s effectiveness, noting that the outlined measures—including criminalizing exploitation and penalizing the distribution of abusive content—might not coherently achieve the stated goals. It highlighted doubts about whether the proposed legal framework would adequately address the evolving challenges posed by technology or sufficiently strengthen cross-border legal coherence, ultimately expressing skepticism about the directive’s capacity to fulfill its objectives despite recognizing the urgency of combating such crimes.

title: Single application procedure for residence and work: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on a single application procedure for a single permit for third-country nationals to reside and work in the territory of a Member State and on a common set of rights for third-country workers legally residing in a Member State
background: The European Union has pursued legislative frameworks for economic immigration since the early 2000s, addressing demographic challenges and labor market needs. Member States historically managed migration through bilateral agreements and quotas, with varying effectiveness. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing residence and work permit procedures and establishing common rights for third-country nationals legally working in the EU.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the single permit procedure as it aligns perfectly with their longstanding commitment to efficient migration management and equal social rights for third-country workers, combining residence and work authorization into one streamlined process.  
EPP applauds the issue's balanced approach that effectively advances their priority of linking legal migration opportunities with robust measures against illegal immigration, ensuring coherent border security policies.  
EPP endorses the equal treatment provisions in Articles 1-3, particularly the anti-discrimination safeguards in access to employment and vocational training, which match EPP's 2023 manifesto commitments to fair labor markets.  
EPP proposes a minor enhancement to future revisions by expanding the directive's scope to include seasonal workers and intra-corporate transferees, ensuring comprehensive labor market responsiveness without opposing the current framework.  
EPP urges consideration of cultural integration strategies in subsequent policy initiatives, emphasizing that successful economic migration requires parallel investments in social cohesion programs.

GUE_NGL rejects fundamentally the issue's creation of hierarchical worker categories that institutionalize wage competition and exploitation.  
GUE_NGL opposes the directive for legalizing social dumping through differentiated statuses, directly contradicting their demand for universal labor equality.  
GUE_NGL condemns the failure to mandate full parity in wages, social protections, and union rights across all migrant worker classifications.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's incompatibility with UN migrant rights conventions, which they require as a baseline for any labor framework.  
GUE_NGL warns this replicates the destructive "Bolkestein Directive" model they have historically opposed, accelerating race-to-the-bottom economics.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a Commission proposal concerning legal migration and workers’ rights under Articles 63(3)(a) and 67 of the EC Treaty, later aligned with the Treaty of Lisbon’s implications for legislative procedures. It emphasized the legal framework under Article 294(3) and Article 79(2)(a) and (b) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, focusing on fair treatment of third-country nationals, integration policies, and combating labor exploitation. The resolution endorsed the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice, and Home Affairs’ report and incorporated input from the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, urging the Commission to prioritize non-discriminatory access to employment, social security, and vocational training for legally residing migrants. It called for coherence with existing EU migration directives and stressed the need for robust monitoring mechanisms to ensure compliance. The Parliament formally adopted its first-reading position, requested the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments, and directed its President to transmit the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments for further action.

title: Third countries whose nationals must be in possession of visas when crossing EU external borders: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 listing the third countries whose nationals must be in possession of visas when crossing the external borders and those whose nationals are exempt from that requirement
background: The European Union periodically updates visa requirements for third-country nationals to reflect evolving geopolitical, security, and migration dynamics. The Parliament will discuss amendments to Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 governing third-country nationals' visa obligations when crossing EU external borders.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the comprehensive framework for market abuse regulations, aligning perfectly with their commitment to financial market integrity and investor protection.  
EPP applauds the extension of oversight to algorithmic and high-frequency trading, effectively advancing priorities for transparent and fair market structures.  
EPP endorses harmonized supervision across primary and unregulated instant markets, reinforcing their longstanding advocacy for cross-border regulatory coherence.  
EPP proposes strengthening disclosure mechanisms for all market participants to further deter indirect manipulative practices while maintaining core support for the issue.  
EPP approves the pragmatic evidentiary standard for proving market manipulation, which balances enforcement efficiency with robust investor safeguards.

GUE_NGL rejects the proposal for failing to address systemic financial crimes and corporate impunity central to their advocacy.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the prioritization of border controls over regulating market abuses inconsistent with their anti-capitalist principles.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as penalizing financial misconduct, which GUE_NGL deems essential to societal justice.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the European Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0290) concerning measures under Article 77(2)(a) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union related to border checks, informed by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs’ report (A7-0139/2013) and incorporating the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. It emphasized the legal basis of the proposal under EU treaties and urged the Commission to resubmit the matter to Parliament if proposing substantial amendments or alternative texts, ensuring parliamentary oversight. The resolution underscored adherence to legislative procedures under Article 294 of the TFEU and Rule 55 of Parliament’s Rules of Procedure, while directing the transmission of its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments.

title: Third countries whose nationals must be in possession of visas when crossing the external borders of Member States: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 listing the third countries whose nationals must be in possession of visas when crossing the external borders of Member States and those whose nationals are exempt from that requirement
background: The EU's visa policy under Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 required nationals of certain third countries to obtain visas, with prior exemptions granted to Western Balkan states under the Thessaloniki Agenda. Albania and Bosnia and Herzegovina underwent EU-mandated reforms addressing border security, document integrity, and rule-of-law benchmarks. The Parliament will discuss amending visa requirements for these countries.

stances.stance:
EFD totally againsts the inclusion of Kosovo in visa liberalization frameworks, as this violates UN Security Council Resolution 1244 and undermines Serbia's territorial integrity.  
EFD rejects the proposal's implicit recognition of Kosovo's contested statehood, which conflicts with their adherence to strict international law compliance regarding sovereignty.  
EFD highlights security risks in granting visa-free travel to Albania and Bosnia, citing unresolved repatriation challenges and potential Islamic terrorism threats mentioned in the debate.  
EFD condemns the issue for ignoring integration failures with Roma populations, arguing this exacerbates existing EU social stability concerns.  
EFD opposes ethnic-based travel criteria for Kosovo residents, demanding equal treatment of all Serbian citizens through unified passport policies.

GREEN_EFA strongly agrees granting visa-free travel to Bosnia and Herzegovina and Albania, emphasizing their full compliance with established criteria and the importance of upholding transparent, merit-based processes. This aligns perfectly with GREEN_EFA's commitment to fair EU integration policies.  

GREEN_EFA urges the Council to promptly endorse visa liberalization, warning against political delays that risk undermining trust in EU institutions. The issue effectively advances the principle that technical achievements must dictate policy outcomes.  

GREEN_EFA applauds the alignment of Parliament's position with technical assessments, rejecting any double standards that could disadvantage Balkan citizens. This mirrors their longstanding advocacy for equitable treatment in freedom of movement.  

GREEN_EFA proposes initiating a parallel roadmap process for Kosovo to ensure regional coherence in visa policy development, while fully supporting the current measures for Bosnia and Albania.  

GREEN_EFA emphasizes that timely implementation of visa waivers strengthens people-to-people ties and European integration, directly supporting their 2023 priorities for Balkan reconciliation and mobility rights.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a Commission proposal (COM(2010)0256) concerning the implementation of EU policies under Article 77(2)(a) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which relates to border checks and free movement. It adopted its first-reading stance by endorsing the Commission’s original proposal without amendments, following the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs’ report (A7‑0256/2010) and considering the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. The resolution emphasized the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial changes or replacements to the proposal are planned, ensuring legislative transparency. It further directed its President to formally communicate Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural adherence under Article 294 of the Treaty and Rule 55 of its Rules of Procedure. The decision aimed to uphold coherence in EU border management policies while safeguarding parliamentary oversight.

title: Trafficking in human beings: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on preventing and combating trafficking in human beings, and protecting victims, repealing Framework Decision 2002/629/JHA
background: Persistent reports of cross-border human trafficking networks exploiting vulnerable groups, including women and children, for labor and sexual purposes across EU member states highlighted gaps in coordinated legal frameworks. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing criminal penalties, victim protection mechanisms, and preventive measures to address modern slavery under updated EU legislation.

stances.stance:
EFD supports the directive’s emphasis on stricter penalties for traffickers and cross-border judicial cooperation, aligning with their prioritization of citizen safety and crime suppression.  
EFD proposes amending Article 5 to establish a mandatory minimum prison sentence of 10-15 years for traffickers, eliminating parole or fines, to ensure uniform deterrence across Member States.  
EFD advises expanding the issue’s prevention framework to include targeted development aid for origin countries, addressing root causes like poverty that fuel exploitation.  
EFD underscores the need for asset confiscation protocols in Article 9 to dismantle criminal networks’ financial infrastructure, reinforcing the directive’s punitive measures.

GREEN_EFA totally agrees the directive's victim-centered approach, perfectly aligning with their commitment to human rights and gender equality.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s preservation of Member State discretion on penalizing service users, recognizing this prevents further marginalization of trafficking survivors.  
GREEN_EFA highlights an enhancement opportunity to strengthen Article 13 by advocating permanent residency pathways for victims rebuilding their lives post-trafficking.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the issue’s advancement of cross-border judicial cooperation as critical to their anti-exploitation agenda.  
GREEN_EFA urges future recasts to explicitly link victim protection frameworks with long-term socioeconomic integration programs.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2010 legislative proposal (COM(2010)0095) by adopting a resolution under Articles 82(2) and 83(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU, focusing on legal and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. It emphasized the need to align the proposal with EU legal frameworks and fundamental rights, incorporating input from national parliaments, the European Economic and Social Committee, and the Committee of the Regions. The resolution highlighted collaboration between the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality, reflecting cross-cutting priorities. Parliament formally adopted its first-reading position, urging the Commission to resubmit the proposal if substantial revisions occur, and instructed its President to transmit the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to advance legislative procedures.

title: US NSA surveillance programme, surveillance bodies in various Member States and impact on EU citizens' fundamental rights: REPORT on the US NSA surveillance programme, surveillance bodies in various Member States and their impact on EU citizens’ fundamental rights and on transatlantic cooperation in Justice and Home Affairs
background: Revelations in 2013 regarding US NSA surveillance programs affecting EU citizens and institutions, alongside reports of similar activities in some EU member states, raised concerns over fundamental rights and data protection within existing transatlantic security and data-sharing frameworks. The Parliament will discuss the impact of surveillance practices on EU citizens' rights and implications for EU-US justice cooperation.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects the issue's presumption that mass surveillance inherently violates fundamental rights, fully condemning with EFD's prioritization of counterterrorism efficacy over abstract privacy ideals  
EFD opposes the proposed "European Digital Habeas Corpus" as overlooking critical aspects of operational security required to intercept imminent terrorist plots like those preceding 9/11 and Madrid  
EFD condemns the issue's Orwellian analogies as inconsistent with EFD's stance that constitutional democracies inherently balance surveillance tools with judicial oversight  
EFD disputes the characterization of Safe Harbour reforms as urgent, arguing the Madrid bombings exemplify why data-sharing mechanisms must prioritize intelligence-gathering over bureaucratic compliance  
EFD rejects attempts to constrain INTCEN's operations through legal basis requirements, viewing this as destabilizing to the EU's capacity to mirror U.S. counterterrorism successes

GREEN_EFA entirely supports the issue's condemnation of mass surveillance as a fundamental breach of digital rights, perfectly aligning with their decade-long advocacy for a "European Digital Habeas Corpus" to shield citizens from unwarranted data exploitation.  

GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call to recognize Edward Snowden's whistleblower status, emphasizing his crucial role in exposing systemic legal violations that democratically elected parliaments must now redress through asylum offers and witness protection programs.  

GREEN_EFA entirely supports halting transatlantic data-sharing agreements like SWIFT and TFTP until judicial redress parity is achieved, mirroring their 2023 manifesto demand to suspend TTIP negotiations until privacy safeguards match economic priorities.  

GREEN_EFA perfectly supports the issue's challenge to national security overreach, reinforcing their constitutional principle that EU member states spying on each other's citizens violates the Treaty's spirit of mutual trust and shared democratic values.  

GREEN_EFA entirely supports creating independent oversight mechanisms with binding powers over intelligence agencies, operationalizing their 2014 "No Spy" campaign's core demand through the proposed transparency reforms and parliamentary investigation powers.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the impact of U.S. mass surveillance on EU data protection reforms, fundamental rights, and extraterritorial data transfers, emphasizing the need to balance security cooperation with privacy safeguards. It noted that intelligence activities fall under national competence, limiting EU action, but highlighted existing EU frameworks for internal security, including data transfer mechanisms like the U.S.-EU Safe Harbour, contractual clauses, Mutual Legal Assistance Agreement, and TFTP/PNR agreements, while stressing the absence of a legal basis for INTCEN and the EU Counter-Terrorism Coordinator. The resolution cautioned against undermining trust in democratically elected governments, citing a "presumption of lawful governance" rooted in constitutional checks, but warned that mass surveillance risks eroding privacy, evoking Orwellian parallels. It urged reforms to strengthen transparency, democratic oversight, and a proposed "European Digital Habeas Corpus" to protect digital rights, while prioritizing transatlantic economic and security ties, notably through the TTIP, and avoiding actions that could destabilize U.S.-EU relations by condemning unauthorized disclosures of sensitive intelligence.

title: Commission decision to activate Article 7 (1) TEU as regards the situation in Poland - Motions for resolutions: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the Commission’s decision to activate Article 7(1) TEU as regards the situation in Poland
background: The European Commission activated Article 7(1) TEU in December 2017 following concerns over Polish judicial reforms affecting judiciary independence, citing risks to EU rule of law values. The Parliament will discuss the Commission’s decision and implications for upholding EU treaty obligations regarding member state governance standards.

stances.stance:
ENF rejects the activation of Article 7 as an unlawful overreach by EU bureaucrats seeking to subordinate national sovereignty to centralized authority.  
ENF opposes the issue’s characterization of judicial reforms, arguing no evidence exists of abolished democratic institutions or suspended civil rights in Poland.  
ENF condemns the Commission’s actions as political interference masquerading as rule-of-law protection, entirely disapproveing with ENF’s anti-federalist principles.  
ENF challenges the procedural hypocrisy, noting Poland’s “clean” EU accession contrasts with post-membership allegations, exposing flawed monitoring frameworks.  
ENF warns that endorsing this precedent enables EU technocrats to dismantle national self-determination, aligning with their broader agenda to erode state sovereignty.

GREEN_EFA strongly endorses the Article 7 activation as a vital defense of EU values, aligning perfectly with their commitment to judicial independence and democratic accountability.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s recognition of Polish civil society’s role, mirroring their manifesto pledges to protect grassroots movements and environmental activism.  
GREEN_EFA endorses urgent Council intervention to uphold rule of law standards, reflecting their core principle that EU membership necessitates rigorous multilateral oversight.  
GREEN_EFA proposes expanding the issue’s dissemination requirements to include direct engagement with Polish environmental defenders and women’s rights organizations.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes aligning all procedural updates with explicit references to climate justice and gender equality frameworks in future compliance assessments.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over Poland’s judicial reforms undermining judicial independence and the rule of law, affirming that these actions posed a clear risk of breaching EU values under Article 2 TEU. It endorsed the European Commission’s 20 December 2017 decision to trigger Article 7(1) TEU—marking the first such activation—to address systemic threats, including laws affecting ordinary courts and the judiciary’s integrity, and supported calls for Poland to remedy these issues. The resolution highlighted the Commission’s infringement referral to the European Court of Justice (case 2017/2219) over Poland’s amendments to the law on ordinary courts, stressing non-compliance with EU law. Parliament urged the Council to act promptly under Article 7(1) TEU, demanded regular updates from the Commission and Council on procedural progress, and directed its President to disseminate the resolution to EU institutions, Polish authorities, member states, the Council of Europe, and OSCE, emphasizing multilateral engagement to uphold democratic standards.

title: EU Agency for Law Enforcement Training (CEPOL): REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a European Union agency for law enforcement training (Cepol), repealing and replacing Council Decision 2005/681/JHA
background: The EU established CEPOL in 2005 to promote cross-border law enforcement training, but evolving security challenges, including terrorism, cybercrime, and migration, necessitated updated governance. The Lisbon Treaty required alignment of agencies with EU legal frameworks. The Parliament will discuss reforming CEPOL into an EU agency to strengthen transnational law enforcement training coordination.

stances.stance:
EFDD rejects the expansion of EU law enforcement integration as a violation of national sovereignty principles under Article 87(2)(b) TFEU  
EFDD opposes CEPOL's structure as institutionalizing EU-created borderless chaos followed by centralized "solutions"  
This completely challenges with EFDD's stance that Schengen-induced trafficking requires border control restoration, not pan-EU training schemes  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as member states' constitutional authority to maintain independent border security forces  
EFDD condemns the issue's operational improvements as enabling Brussels' power grabs through crisis exploitation mechanisms

SD completely sanctions the modernization of CEPOL’s mandate to align with Lisbon Treaty objectives, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to robust EU-wide law enforcement training frameworks.  
SD perfectly supports strengthening CEPOL’s operational autonomy and funding to address migratory crises, reflecting SD’s priority of enhancing cross-border police cooperation and crisis preparedness.  
SD completely sanctions the strategic prioritization of thematic training areas with clear EU added value, ensuring resource efficiency and compliance with subsidiarity as emphasized in the issue.  
SD applauds CEPOL’s role in fostering a rights-based European law enforcement culture, which advances SD’s vision of integrated, ethically grounded security frameworks.  
SD strongly affirms the need for interagency coordination to eliminate duplication, mirroring SD’s longstanding advocacy for synergies in EU justice and home affairs governance.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the Commission’s 2014 proposal (COM(2014)0465) on administrative cooperation between EU agencies, emphasizing the need for enhanced synergies and efficiency under the legal framework of Article 87(2)(b) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It adopted its first-reading position, urging the Commission to reassess and resubmit the proposal if substantial amendments or replacements are planned, and demanded a comprehensive analysis of inter-agency cooperation to identify future collaborative opportunities. The resolution stressed the importance of streamlining administrative processes to avoid duplication and improve resource allocation, while instructing the Parliament’s President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments for further action. Specific references included document C8-0110/2014 and procedural alignment with Article 294(2) and (3) of the Treaty, though substantive focus remained on operational improvements and institutional accountability.

title: EU accession to the Council of Europe Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence: INTERIM REPORT on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, by the European Union, of the Council of Europe Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence
background: The Council of Europe's Istanbul Convention, established in 2011 to combat violence against women and domestic violence, had been signed by all EU Member States but ratified by only 14 by 2017, prompting calls for EU-level accession. The Parliament will discuss EU ratification to address systemic gender-based violence and domestic abuse.

stances.stance:
ENF rejects fundamentally the EU's accession attempt as a supranational overreach violating member states' sovereignty in criminal justice matters.  
ENF opposes the convention's ideological focus on "gender identity" and intersectionality, which they claim distracts from concrete protection of European women.  
ENF condemns the issue's failure to address migration-driven violence against women, specifically citing honor killings and Sharia-compliant abuses enabled by "suicidal" EU asylum policies.  
ENF argues the convention serves as a Trojan horse to impose multiculturalism rather than combat actual perpetrators, noting that 14/28 states already reject it.  
ENF demands border control prioritization over "communitarianist quotas," asserting native European women need defense from imported misogyny, not gender studies programs.

SD absolutely upholds the EU's accession to the Istanbul Convention as a critical framework to eradicate gender-based violence, perfectly aligning with their demand to treat it as a systemic public issue requiring collective institutional responsibility.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s condemnation of cultural or religious justifications for violence, emphasizing their unwavering stance that misogyny and patriarchal structures must be dismantled through legislative and educational reforms.  
SD fully supports the call for intersectional policies protecting women with disabilities, migrants, and LGBTI individuals, reflecting their decades-long advocacy for marginalized groups facing compounded vulnerabilities.  
SD endorses the urgent classification of gender-based violence as an EU crime under Article 83 TFEU, viewing this as essential to harmonize prosecutorial standards and eliminate jurisdictional gaps across Member States.  
SD strongly advocates for immediate ratification by all EU countries, condemning delays as incompatible with fundamental rights principles, and applauds the issue’s holistic integration of prevention, protection, and prosecution measures.

resolution: The European Parliament raised urgent concerns about pervasive gender-based violence and systemic inequalities affecting women and girls in the EU, citing that one-third of women experience physical or sexual violence, costing society €226 billion annually. It emphasized the critical need for EU accession to the Istanbul Convention—a comprehensive framework for preventing and combating violence against women, protecting victims, and prosec perpetrators—while regretting limitations in the EU’s current accession scope to judicial cooperation and asylum matters. The resolution condemned all forms of violence, including domestic abuse, online harassment, FGM, forced marriage, and denial of reproductive rights, stressing that cultural or religious justifications are unacceptable. It highlighted the disproportionate risks faced by marginalized groups, such as women with disabilities (1.5-10 times more vulnerable), migrants, and LGBTI individuals, and called for intersectional policies, specialized support services, and accessible justice. Parliament urged Member States to accelerate ratification of the Istanbul Convention (only 14 had done so), allocate sufficient resources, and adopt a holistic EU strategy integrating prevention, protection, and prosecution measures. It demanded legislative action to classify gender-based violence as an EU crime under Article 83 TFEU via the passerelle clause, alongside establishing a European Monitoring Observatory and ensuring comprehensive data collection. The resolution also emphasized economic empowerment, education, and challenging gender stereotypes to address root causes, while advocating for mandatory gender equality training for professionals and robust implementation of existing directives on victim protection, trafficking, and asylum.

title: Adequacy of the protection afforded by the EU-US Privacy Shield: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the adequacy of the protection afforded by the EU-US Privacy Shield
background: Following the European Court of Justice’s 2015 invalidation of the EU-US Safe Harbour framework, the EU-US Privacy Shield was adopted in 2016 to ensure transatlantic data flows meet EU data protection standards. Subsequent US surveillance law renewals, GDPR implementation, and incidents of corporate data misuse raised concerns. The Parliament will discuss the Privacy Shield’s adequacy under EU law.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the call to suspend the EU-US Privacy Shield, fundamentally opposing the issue's assertion that commercial interests override fundamental rights.  
EPP contradicts the issue's focus on bulk surveillance prohibitions by defending the Privacy Shield's existing framework as sufficient for transatlantic data flows when properly monitored.  
EPP opposes linking the Cambridge Analytica scandal to systemic Privacy Shield failures, arguing this conflates isolated abuses with the agreement's broader operational success.  
EPP dismisses concerns about judicial redress mechanisms, maintaining that the Ombudsperson structure aligns with EU standards despite acknowledged independence gaps.  
EPP rejects warnings about CJEU invalidation risks, prioritizing continuity for 3,000 certified companies over preemptive suspension demands.

ALDE strongly upholds the suspension mechanism tied to concrete US compliance deadlines, aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to prioritizing fundamental rights over commercial interests.  
ALDE proposes strengthening the Ombudsperson mechanism by mandating full independence from executive oversight to convert criticism into actionable enhancement.  
ALDE approves the issue’s focus on bulk surveillance prohibitions, which effectively advances ALDE's priority of aligning international agreements with GDPR standards.  
ALDE emphasizes the urgency of clarifying redress mechanisms for EU citizens as critical to resolving the "pretence of compliance" identified in debates.  
ALDE highlights the need for binding enforcement timelines for US authorities to address delayed FTC oversight, framing this as a necessary refinement to the issue’s demands.

resolution: The European Parliament raised significant concerns about the EU-US Privacy Shield’s adequacy in safeguarding fundamental rights, citing persistent weaknesses in US surveillance laws (e.g., Section 702 of FISA and Executive Order 12333) that permit bulk data collection without sufficient safeguards or redress for EU citizens. It highlighted risks posed by the reauthorization of Section 702, the CLOUD Act’s extraterritorial data access provisions, and Facebook’s transfer of 1.5 billion users’ data to US jurisdiction, alongside the Cambridge Analytica scandal involving 2.7 million EU citizens’ data. While acknowledging improvements over the invalidated Safe Harbour (e.g., stricter data retention rules, an Ombudsperson mechanism), the resolution criticized the Ombudsperson’s lack of independence, the Privacy Shield’s failure to address automated decision-making, HR data discrepancies, and inadequate enforcement by US authorities, including the FTC’s delayed oversight and the non-functional Privacy Civil Liberties Oversight Board (PCLOB). The Parliament urged the Commission to suspend the Privacy Shield by 1 September 2018 unless the US addressed deficiencies, such as ensuring judicial redress, prohibiting bulk surveillance, and clarifying national security definitions. It warned of potential CJEU invalidation, referencing ongoing cases (Schrems II), and stressed the need for binding reforms to align US practices with GDPR and EU Charter standards, emphasizing that commercial interests must not override fundamental rights.

title: Adequacy of the protection afforded by the EU-US privacy Shield: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the adequacy of the protection afforded by the EU-US Privacy Shield
background: The Court of Justice invalidated the EU-US Safe Harbour framework in 2015, prompting negotiations for the Privacy Shield to govern transatlantic data transfers. Concerns persisted over US surveillance practices and equivalence of data protection under EU law. The Parliament will discuss the adequacy of the Privacy Shield in ensuring compliance with EU fundamental rights and GDPR.

stances.stance:
EPP firmly challenges the issue’s characterization of the Privacy Shield as inadequate, emphasizing its critical role in securing transatlantic data flows essential for EU businesses.  
EPP rejects assertions of insufficient judicial redress, citing the Ombudsperson mechanism as a meaningful step beyond Safe Harbour’s limitations.  
EPP conflicts with claims of unchecked mass surveillance, arguing the framework establishes unprecedented accountability for national security data access.  
  
EPP dismisses demands for immediate GDPR alignment, advocating instead for incremental improvements through ongoing joint reviews.

GUE_NGL strongly agrees the issue's condemnation of bulk data collection practices as fully consistent with their foundational stance against mass surveillance and corporate data exploitation.  
GUE_NGL proposes strengthening the Ombudsperson mechanism by requiring formal independence from US executive authorities to address concerns about impartiality in national security complaints.  
GUE_NGL applauds the emphasis on GDPR alignment, which directly advances their 2019 manifesto goal of extraterritorial application of EU privacy standards.  
GUE_NGL urges explicit treaty-level safeguards against future US executive orders like Trump's "Enhancing Public Safety" decree that sought to exclude non-citizens from privacy protections.  
GUE_NGL endorses replacing voluntary self-certification with mandatory compliance for all companies handling EU data to eliminate regulatory arbitrage opportunities.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the EU-US Privacy Shield framework, acknowledging its improvements over the Safe Harbour agreement, including clearer data protection standards and mechanisms for redress, while highlighting significant shortcomings. It noted that 1,893 US organizations had joined the Privacy Shield by March 2017 but criticized its reliance on voluntary self-certification, leaving many companies unregulated. The resolution emphasized unresolved issues such as insufficient safeguards against bulk data collection by US authorities, which conflicts with EU Charter principles of necessity and proportionality, and highlighted the lack of explicit prohibitions on mass surveillance. It expressed doubts about the independence and efficacy of the Ombudsperson mechanism for addressing national security-related complaints and flagged gaps in judicial redress for EU citizens. The Parliament also criticized differences between Privacy Shield principles and EU data protection rules, particularly regarding purpose limitation, automated decision-making, and the right to object. It called for rigorous monitoring, including annual joint reviews with full access to US compliance documents, and urged the Commission to ensure alignment with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) by 2018. Additionally, the resolution stressed the need for clarity on US commitments under the new administration and the legal status of assurances, warning that unresolved issues could lead to future legal challenges undermining fundamental rights and legal certainty.

title: Annual Report on the functioning of the Schengen area: REPORT on the annual report on the functioning of the Schengen area
background: The Schengen area faced challenges from migration inflows, terrorism threats, and prolonged internal border controls by some member states since 2014, alongside uneven implementation of external border protocols and compliance mechanisms. The Parliament will discuss Schengen governance, adherence to border management rules, and measures to restore free movement while addressing security concerns.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA absolutely advocates the issue's condemnation of prolonged internal border controls, perfectly aligning with their commitment to preserving free movement as Schengen's core achievement.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the emphasis on fundamental rights and shared asylum responsibility, advancing their vision of solidarity over fragmentation in migration governance.  
GREEN_EFA strongly endorses demands for unannounced Schengen evaluations and SIS biometric reforms, recognizing these as critical trust-building measures for borderless travel.  
GREEN_EFA commends the call for Bulgaria, Romania, and Croatia’s Schengen accession, viewing this as essential to equitable European integration.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s rejection of physical border barriers as aligning with their opposition to securitization harming free movement and human dignity.

GUE_NGL rejects fundamentally the issue's emphasis on biometric surveillance and physical barriers, which institutionalize racial profiling under the guise of border security.  
GUE_NGL opposes the expansion of interoperable databases and SIS reforms, arguing they prioritize policing over human rights and normalize mass surveillance of migrants.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's failure to address systemic EU solidarity failures, as seen in France's abusive "controls au faciès" that pervert Schengen's free movement principles.  
GUE_NGL denounces the economic prioritization of border militarization (€500M+ on walls) while legal migration pathways and asylum solidarity remain neglected.  
GUE_NGL highlights contradictions in demanding CEAS reforms without binding relocation mechanisms, perpetuating border violence inconsistent with fundamental rights.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the prolonged and unlawful reintroduction of internal border controls by some Member States, which undermines Schengen principles, incurs significant economic costs (EUR 0.05–20 billion in one-off costs and EUR 2 billion annually), and harms free movement. It emphasized the need to strengthen external borders through measures like the European Border and Coast Guard Agency (EBCGA), systematic checks against databases, and the Schengen Information System (SIS) reform, including biometric capabilities. The resolution condemned the construction of over 1,200 km of physical barriers at EU borders, costing at least EUR 500 million, and urged compliance with the Schengen Borders Code. It highlighted critical deficiencies in implementing border controls, database interoperability, and the European Integrated Border Management (IBM) strategy, stressing the need for solidarity, shared responsibility for asylum seekers, and adherence to fundamental rights. Parliament called for swift reforms to the Common European Asylum System (CEAS), including relocation commitments, and urged Bulgaria, Romania, and Croatia’s accession to Schengen. It demanded stricter adherence to Schengen evaluation mechanisms, unannounced on-site visits, and improved search-and-rescue operations in the Mediterranean. Member States were urged to address migration challenges through legal pathways, combat human trafficking, and ensure data protection, while the Commission was tasked with enforcing infringement procedures and revising the EUROSUR regulation to enhance border surveillance and crisis response.

title: Asylum and Migration Fund: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the Asylum and Migration Fund
background: Persistent migration pressures on EU member states, particularly frontline countries, and challenges in coordinating asylum and integration policies under existing mechanisms prompted the European Commission to propose a dedicated funding instrument. The Parliament will discuss establishing the Asylum and Migration Fund to address migration management and solidarity among member states.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA entirely sanctions the inclusion of funds for local authorities and communities, as this perfectly aligns with their commitment to grassroots solidarity and citizen-led humanitarian action across Europe.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s rejection of externalized containment strategies, ensuring the Fund adheres to human rights principles and avoids violations of EU foundational values.  
GREEN_EFA entirely sanctions the prioritization of integration measures and support for vulnerable individuals, advancing their manifesto goals of inclusive societies and dignity-driven migration policies.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call for strengthened intra-EU solidarity mechanisms, particularly fair responsibility-sharing and financial aid to frontline states, reflecting their advocacy for equitable burden distribution.  
GREEN_EFA entirely sanctions the transparency safeguards requiring parliamentary re-engagement on substantive amendments, upholding democratic oversight as central to their governance principles.

ECR rejects the tripling of the Asylum and Migration Fund, arguing it incentivizes illegal migration and contradicts efforts to reduce arrivals.  
ECR opposes the focus on integration measures, citing decades of failed projects in Sweden and demanding mandatory assimilation policies instead.  
ECR demands that 85% of funds prioritize border enforcement and rapid repatriation of illegal migrants, rejecting "legal pathways" as counterproductive.  
ECR highlights the issue's failure to address overwhelmed frontline states like Greece, where returns must supersede integration spending.  
ECR fundamentally disputes with solidarity mechanisms, insisting financial support should enforce strict migration deterrence, not burden-sharing.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2018 proposal (COM(2018)0471) concerning asylum and immigration policies under Articles 78(2) and 79(2) and (4) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It emphasized the need for a coordinated EU approach to migration management, including legal pathways and integration measures, while ensuring compliance with fundamental rights. The resolution, informed by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and incorporating opinions from the Committees on Development and Budgets (A8-0106/2019), called for strengthened solidarity mechanisms among member states, particularly through fair responsibility-sharing and financial support for frontline countries. It urged the Commission to maintain transparency by re-engaging Parliament if proposing substantial amendments to the original text, ensuring legislative coherence and democratic oversight. The adopted position was forwarded to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to advance negotiations.

title: Asylum: provisional measures in favour of Italy and Greece: REPORT on the proposal for a Council decision amending Council Decision (EU) 2015/1601 of 22 September 2015 establishing provisional measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece
background: Persistent migration pressures on Italy and Greece as EU entry points, coupled with the 2015 Council Decision establishing provisional relocation measures and subsequent EU-Turkey migration management agreements, prompted the European Commission to propose adjustments. The Parliament will discuss amending relocation mechanisms to address evolving operational challenges and solidarity obligations under international protection frameworks.

stances.stance:
ECR rejects the relocation mechanism as incompatible with voluntary member state participation principles enshrined in their sovereignty agenda.  
ECR opposes mandatory quotas that disregard distinctions between asylum seekers and economic migrants, contravening their border control priorities.  
ECR highlights the proposal's operational failure through sub-5% relocation completion rates, proving systemic unworkability per Article 78(3) implementation.  
ECR condemns implied sanctions against non-compliant states as EU overreach inconsistent with subsidiarity doctrines.  
ECR warns relocation incentives exacerbate Mediterranean crossings, directly conflicting with their "safe camps over redistribution" policy framework.

GUE_NGL strongly upholds the issue’s emphasis on solidarity and responsibility-sharing, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to collective European action and equitable burden-sharing in migration crises.  

GUE_NGL approves the strengthened legal safeguards for asylum seekers and fundamental rights compliance, effectively advancing their priority of humane treatment and procedural justice for displaced populations.  

GUE_NGL proposes amending the legal basis to Article 78(2) TFEU to ensure full parliamentary co-decision, enhancing democratic accountability and ending reliance on emergency measures that sideline legislative oversight.  

GUE_NGL emphasizes the urgent need to operationalize relocation mechanisms, strongly upholding measures to hold member states accountable for meeting quotas and alleviating disproportionate pressures on Greece and Italy.  

GUE_NGL applauds the issue’s procedural transparency mandates, which align with their manifesto commitments to inter-institutional cooperation and rigorous enforcement of EU solidarity principles.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval of the amended Commission proposal (COM(2016)0171) to address migration under Article 78(3) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, emphasizing the need for solidarity and responsibility-sharing among member states. It endorsed modifications to strengthen legal safeguards for asylum seekers, improve relocation mechanisms, and ensure compliance with fundamental rights. The resolution called on the Commission to revise its proposal accordingly under Article 293(2) and urged the Council to consult Parliament again if intending to substantially alter the text, while also requiring notification of any deviations from Parliament’s approved position. Additionally, it instructed its President to formally transmit Parliament’s stance to the Council and Commission, underscoring procedural accountability and inter-institutional cooperation.

title: Enhanced cooperation: European Public Prosecutor's Office: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council regulation implementing enhanced cooperation on the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (“the EPPO”)
background: Persistent cross-border financial crimes affecting the EU budget, including fraud and VAT evasion, highlighted gaps in existing judicial cooperation mechanisms. The European Commission proposed establishing a European Public Prosecutor’s Office under Article 86 TFEU, with 20 member states initiating enhanced cooperation due to lack of unanimity. The Parliament will discuss the draft regulation implementing this framework.

stances.stance:
ALDE strongly promotes the establishment of the EPPO, particularly its inclusion of VAT fraud prosecution, aligning with their commitment to protecting EU financial interests and taxpayer funds.  
ALDE proposes linking access to EU structural funds to member states' participation in the EPPO framework to ensure shared responsibility in combating budgetary fraud.  
ALDE advocates for future expansion of the EPPO's mandate to address cross-border criminal threats such as terrorism and organized crime, enhancing judicial integration.  
ALDE applauds the EPPO's independent structure and operational efficiency as crucial steps toward building a unified European justice space that safeguards public welfare.  
ALDE urges non-participating member states to join the enhanced cooperation, emphasizing that cross-border crime demands transnational prosecutorial collaboration for collective security.

ECR firmly rejects the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office as an infringement on national judicial sovereignty, contradicting the principle of subsidiarity.  
ECR rejects the duplication of investigative frameworks, arguing the EPPO creates inefficiencies by operating parallel to Eurojust and OLAF rather than integrating with existing mechanisms.  
ECR condemns proposals to penalize non-participating states through budgetary discrimination, warning this undermines trust in EU cooperation structures.  
ECR asserts that prosecutorial authority must remain strictly with national institutions, viewing supranational overreach as incompatible with member state competence.  
ECR emphasizes that fraud combat requires strengthening national justice systems first, rather than creating centralized EU entities.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the draft Council Regulation (09941/2017), submitted under Article 86 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (C8‑0229/2017), following the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs’ recommendation (A8-0290/2017), thereby endorsing the proposed legal framework. It formally approved the regulation, which establishes measures for enhanced judicial cooperation in criminal matters, and directed its President to communicate this decision to the Council, the Commission, and national parliaments to ensure implementation.

title: Establishing a Programme for the Environment and Climate Action (LIFE): REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a Programme for the Environment and Climate Action (LIFE) and repealing Regulation (EU) No 1293/2013
background: The LIFE Programme (2014-2020) under Regulation (EU) No 1293/2013 supported environmental and climate initiatives. The European Commission proposed a 2021-2027 successor programme to align with EU climate neutrality goals, Paris Agreement commitments, and Sustainable Development Goals, emphasizing cross-sectoral integration. The Parliament will discuss establishing the updated LIFE Programme to advance environmental and climate action.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely sanctions the issue's prioritization of biodiversity protection through explicit inclusion of outermost regions in the BEST scheme, perfectly aligning with their 2023 manifesto commitment to safeguard Europe's unique ecosystems.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the strengthened cooperation mechanisms for third-country participation, recognizing this as vital for transboundary environmental challenges addressed in their Mediterranean Action Plan.  
EPP strongly advocates for the issue's emphasis on administrative simplification, viewing streamlined procedures as essential for maximizing LIFE's impact across all governance levels as outlined in their Digital Governance Strategy.  
EPP fully supports the proposed EUR 7 billion budget increase, noting it directly enables scaled replication of successful circular economy models championed in their Industrial Renewal Agenda.  
EPP emphasizes the critical importance of integrating agricultural stakeholders into climate resilience projects, reflecting their Farm to Fork policy's focus on sustainable land-use synergies.

EFDD rejects the allocation of LIFE Programme funds to climate-focused agricultural measures, asserting farmers cannot influence cosmic or solar drivers of climate change as outlined in Article 4.  
EFDD firmly condemns linking cohesion policy with climate objectives in the issue, stating this misdirects resources from tangible biosecurity improvements to ineffective atmospheric controls.  
The proposal overlooks critical EFDD priorities by neglecting to address antimicrobial resistance through targeted grants for flock culling and hardy livestock breeding as alternative budget uses.  
EFDD demands amendment of Section 2.3 to redirect 75% of biodiversity funding to combatting anti-microbial resistance in farming practices across outermost regions.  
This initiative contradicts EFDD's core principle that environmental spending must yield measurable impacts, not symbolic gestures toward uncontrollable natural climate variables.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the adoption of its position on the LIFE Programme, emphasizing enhanced environmental and climate action funding, particularly for the Outermost Regions and Overseas Countries and Territories through the Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services in Territories of European Overseas (BEST) scheme. The resolution prioritizes cooperation, best practice development, and extending the program to third countries under specified conditions, including former EU member states. It stresses alignment between cohesion policy and LIFE Programme objectives, advocates for a stronger role for regional and local authorities in implementation, and supports administrative capacity-building projects. The Parliament underscored the necessity of targeted environmental funding for vulnerable regions and clarified eligibility criteria for third-country participation to ensure coherence with EU priorities.

title: Establishing a centralised system for the identification of Member States holding conviction information on third country nationals and stateless persons (TCN) to supplement and support the European Criminal Records Information System (ECRIS-TCN system): REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a centralised system for the identification of Member States holding conviction information on third country nationals and stateless persons (TCN) to supplement and support the European Criminal Records Information System (ECRIS-TCN system) and amending Regulation (EU) No 1077/2011
background: The European Criminal Records Information System (ECRIS) lacked efficient mechanisms to identify prior convictions of third-country nationals (TCNs) and stateless persons in the EU, creating gaps in cross-border judicial cooperation. The Parliament will discuss establishing a centralized identification system to address these limitations and improve information-sharing among Member States.

stances.stance:
ALDE firmly supports the issue's safeguards ensuring equal treatment between EU nationals and third-country nationals through harmonized fingerprint collection standards.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the exclusion of non-EU convictions, maintaining the system's focus on intra-EU judicial efficiency and data protection.  
ALDE strongly advocates the prohibition of racial profiling by mandating systematic checks rather than discretionary searches.  
ALDE commends the legal certainty provided by uniform implementation across Member States, preventing fragmentation in judicial practices.

GUE_NGL strongly upholds the issue’s emphasis on fundamental rights compliance and procedural safeguards, aligning with their commitment to protecting individual liberties in cross-border judicial cooperation.  
GUE_NGL proposes amending Article 8 to explicitly prohibit the use of conviction data for migration enforcement purposes, ensuring strict adherence to proportionality and non-discrimination principles.  
GUE_NGL underscores the necessity of limiting supranational data centralization, advocating for robust oversight mechanisms to prevent misuse under expansive security frameworks.  
GUE_NGL endorses the issue’s potential to standardize rights protections across Member States, countering fragmented practices that risk undermining constitutional safeguards.
