GUE_NGL highlights the urgency of clarifying "terrorism" definitions in Annex II to prevent overreach, aligning with their opposition to securitized migration policies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2017 proposal (COM(2017)0344) to strengthen judicial cooperation in criminal matters, particularly through measures aligned with Article 82(1)(d) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The resolution endorsed adopting legal frameworks to enhance cross-border collaboration, procedural safeguards, and efficient resource allocation, while emphasizing compliance with fundamental rights. It called for consistent implementation across member states, urged the Commission to uphold Parliament’s position during further negotiations, and stressed the need to avoid fragmentation in judicial practices. The resolution also highlighted forwarding the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to ensure alignment and facilitate coherent legislative progress.

title: Establishing the Rights and Values programme: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the Rights and Values programme
background: Rising concerns over challenges to EU foundational values in member states, including rule of law disputes, attacks on judicial independence, media freedom, and civil society, alongside reported incidents of violence against activists and journalists, prompted institutional commitments to reinforce democratic principles. The Parliament will discuss establishing a dedicated Rights and Values programme to promote EU values and support civil society initiatives.

stances.stance:
ENF rejects the Rights and Values programme’s delegation of EU priorities to NGOs, completely opposeing with ENF’s demand for direct institutional accountability in safeguarding European sovereignty.  
ENF opposes the financial prioritization of third-party entities like Open Arms, citing explicit contradictions with ENF’s principles against subsidizing organizations that circumvent national immigration laws.  
ENF condemns the proposal’s moral ambiguity in funding NGOs, which overlooks critical risks of enabling non-aligned agendas that undermine member states’ jurisdictional authority.  
ENF disputes the programme’s alignment with TFEU Article 168, arguing it institutionalizes reckless outsourcing of public health and security mandates to unaccountable private actors.  
ENF challenges the issue’s claim to uphold the rule of law, asserting that its support for NGOs engaged in human trafficking facilitation directly violates ENF’s core stance on border integrity.

SD strongly endorses the increased financial allocation to civil society organizations combating racism, xenophobia, and gender-based violence, aligning with SD’s commitment to social justice and inclusive democracies.  
SD approves the program’s focus on youth education to foster tolerance and diversity, directly advancing SD’s priority of building pluralistic citizenship through formal and informal learning.  
SD endorses the emphasis on grassroots democratic participation as critical to countering authoritarian erosion of rule-of-law principles in Hungary and Poland, reflecting SD’s manifesto against illiberal regimes.  
SD proposes enhancing Article 4 to explicitly prioritize intercultural and interreligious dialogue in citizenship-building initiatives, reinforcing societal cohesion without opposing the program’s core objectives.  
SD applauds the linkage between EU funding and adherence to democratic values, which aligns with SD’s longstanding advocacy for conditionality mechanisms to protect civil liberties.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal (COM(2018)0383) under Treaty provisions related to non-discrimination, cultural diversity, public health, and institutional competencies. It emphasized alignment with legal bases under Articles 16(2), 19(2), 21(2), 24, 167, and 168 of the TFEU, addressing civil liberties, justice, cultural and educational policies, gender equality, employment, social affairs, legal frameworks, and constitutional matters. The resolution integrated inputs from multiple committees, including Civil Liberties, Culture and Education, Women’s Rights, Budgets, Employment, Legal Affairs, and Constitutional Affairs, reflecting a cross-sectoral approach. It formally adopted its first-reading stance and urged the Commission to re-submit the proposal to Parliament if substantial revisions or replacements occur, ensuring legislative transparency and procedural accountability. The resolution also mandated communication of its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing interinstitutional dialogue.

title: European Border and Coast Guard: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Border and Coast Guard and repealing Regulation (EC) No 2007/2004, Regulation (EC) No 863/2007 and Council Decision 2005/267/EC
background: Increased migration flows, security challenges, and fragmented external border management within the Schengen Area prompted the European Commission to propose enhancing Frontex's mandate. The Parliament will discuss establishing a European Border and Coast Guard to strengthen integrated border controls, improve crisis response capacity, and address vulnerabilities in external border surveillance.

stances.stance:
EPP totally endorses the establishment of the European Border and Coast Guard as a vital reinforcement of Schengen security, perfectly aligning with its commitment to effective external border management while respecting national sovereignty.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue’s operational framework, emphasizing rapid deployment capabilities and enhanced Frontex resources to address migration pressures decisively.  
EPP totally endorses the harmonized approach to returns and search-and-rescue operations, which advances its priority of combating human trafficking while upholding fundamental rights.  
EPP strongly agrees the issue’s balance between shared EU responsibility and member state competence, ensuring solidarity without undermining national border control authority.  
EPP applauds the inclusion of children’s rights protections in border operations, reflecting its manifesto commitment to safeguarding vulnerable groups during migration management.

ENF rejects the establishment of the European Border and Coast Guard Agency as a direct assault on national sovereignty, absolutely disapproveing with their principle that border control must remain under exclusive member state authority.  
ENF opposes the mandatory liaison officers outlined in the proposal, condemning them as surveillance tools inconsistent with ENF's demand for unmonitored national autonomy in migration policy.  
The proposal's reliance on EU integration to address migration failures overlooks critical ENF priorities such as reinstating internal borders and adopting pushback policies modeled on Australia.  
ENF condemns the issue's continuation of Schengen's open borders as morally bankrupt, directly contradicting their call to return border authority to sovereign nations.  
The centralized enforcement mechanisms in the proposal are denounced by ENF as coercive overreach, irreconcilable with their vision of Europe as a coalition of independent states.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the European Commission’s 2015 proposal (COM(2015)0671) concerning EU policies on border controls, legal immigration, and asylum under Articles 77(2)(b) and (d) and Article 79(2)(c) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The resolution, informed by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs’ report and opinions from the Committees on Foreign Affairs, Budgets, and Fisheries, formally adopted Parliament’s stance on the legislative proposal. It urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if intending to amend or replace the proposal substantially and directed the Parliament’s President to transmit the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, emphasizing procedural adherence while focusing on harmonizing EU migration and border management frameworks.

title: European Public Prosecutor's Office: INTERIM REPORT on the proposal for a Council regulation on the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office
background: Persistent concerns over fraud affecting EU financial interests, estimated at €500 million annually (potentially up to €3 billion), low prosecution rates of OLAF-referred cases (31% in 2006-2013), and disparities in Member States’ enforcement efficiency prompted calls for centralized oversight under Article 86 TFEU. The Parliament will discuss establishing a European Public Prosecutor’s Office to address cross-border fraud.

stances.stance:
SD firmly approves the establishment of an independent European Public Prosecutor’s Office as a critical mechanism to combat systemic fraud, perfectly aligning with SD’s longstanding commitment to safeguarding EU financial interests through supranational judicial accountability.  

SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s demand for transparent merit-based selection of EPPO leadership, emphasizing that parliamentary involvement in appointments is essential to prevent national interference and uphold institutional credibility.  

SD firmly approves the imperative to harmonize evidence admissibility rules across Member States, recognizing this as foundational to eliminating procedural fragmentation and ensuring equal protection of EU budgetary integrity.  

SD strongly promotes the call to expand EPPO’s mandate to cross-border crimes like organized crime, viewing this as a logical extension of its fraud-combat role and consistent with SD’s broader agenda for integrated judicial cooperation.  

SD emphasizes that the issue’s safeguards for defendants’ rights—including judicial review and non-bis-in-idem protections—must be non-negotiable, aligning with SD’s principled defense of procedural fairness even in high-stakes anti-corruption cases.

ECR rejects the establishment of the EPPO as it infringes on national sovereignty, contradicting the issue's push for centralized prosecution authority. The EU's lack of statehood makes a European prosecutor institutionally incompatible.  
ECR opposes expanding prosecutorial powers to cross-border crimes, arguing this duplicates Eurojust's mandate and creates unnecessary bureaucratic overlap, contrary to the issue's harmonization goals.  
ECR fundamentally objects to budget allocation for the EPPO, viewing it as wasteful when existing mechanisms like OLAF could be strengthened instead, opposing the issue's resource commitments.  
ECR challenges the legal basis for EPPO's creation, noting treaty requirements for unanimous member state approval which the issue's centralized model fails to accommodate.  
ECR condemns the proposal as part of a broader EU overreach into national judicial systems, directly conflicting with the issue's presumption of harmonized legal standards across sovereign states.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about significant fraud risks to the EU’s financial interests, estimating annual losses at €500 million, with potential exposure up to €3 billion, and highlighted a low 31% indictment rate for fraud cases between 2006-2013. It emphasized the need for an independent European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) to address these gaps, ensuring uniform prosecution across Member States despite differing legal systems. The resolution called for a decentralized EPPO structure with central decision-making on jurisdiction, investigations, and prosecutions, stressing judicial review of its decisions to safeguard rights like fair trials, presumption of innocence, and non-bis-in-idem. It demanded transparent, merit-based selection of EPPO leadership with Parliament’s involvement, clear delineation of competences between EPPO, Eurojust, Europol, and OLAF, and harmonized rules for evidence admissibility. The Parliament urged expanding the EPPO’s mandate to include cross-border crimes like terrorism and organized crime, while ensuring annual reporting and budget accountability. It also highlighted the need to avoid overlaps with national prosecutors, prevent forum shopping, and guarantee redress for wrongful prosecutions, aligning EPPO operations with EU fundamental rights and judicial standards.

title: Humanitarian visas: REPORT with recommendations to the Commission on Humanitarian Visas
background: Persistent absence of EU-wide humanitarian visa frameworks led to high irregular migration, with 90% of international protection recipients entering through unsafe routes, resulting in over 30,000 deaths at EU borders since 2000 and heightened risks for vulnerable groups. The Parliament will discuss establishing legal pathways for safe entry to address asylum access challenges.

stances.stance:
SD strongly sanctions the creation of a European Humanitarian Visa framework as a vital alignment with SD’s commitment to human rights and safe migration pathways, directly addressing the lethal gaps in current asylum access.  
SD applauds the gender-sensitive procedural requirements for assessing persecution related to gender-based violence, advancing SD’s priority of protecting women and LGBTQI+ individuals from systemic vulnerabilities.  
SD endorses the 15-day processing timeline and appeal mechanisms as essential safeguards to balance efficiency with due process, reflecting SD’s principles of fairness in migration governance.  
SD proposes enhancing family reunification clarity by explicitly defining eligibility criteria in Article 4 to prevent ambiguity while respecting national asylum protocols, as highlighted in parliamentary deliberations.  
SD emphasizes the imperative of EU-funded implementation under Article 80 TFEU to ensure equitable burden-sharing, mirroring SD’s longstanding advocacy for solidarity-driven migration policies.

ECR rejects the humanitarian visa proposal as fundamentally incompatible with national sovereignty over migration policy, citing Article 80 TFEU's subsidiarity principle.  
ECR opposes the EU-level harmonization attempt, arguing it creates security loopholes exemplified by the Manchester bomber case involving Schengen visa abuse.  
This conflicts with ECR's stance that asylum systems are already exploited, noting Branislav Škripek's evidence of 88,000 Maltese-issued visas to Libyans as precedent for abuse risks.  
The proposal overlooks ECR's priority to combat migration root causes (poverty/war) rather than creating "incentives" through new entry channels, per Νότης Μαριάς' poverty-migration linkage argument.  
ECR challenges the 15-day processing window as operationally unfeasible, citing Ruža Tomašić's insistence on national discretion over asylum procedures and cost burdens.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need for a Union-level legal framework to establish a European Humanitarian Visa, addressing the absence of harmonized safe pathways for individuals seeking international protection. Highlighting that 90% of those granted protection arrive irregularly, leading to stigmatization and risks such as exploitation, gender-based violence (noting women’s heightened vulnerability), and over 30,000 deaths at EU borders since 2000, the resolution called on the Commission to propose a regulation by March 2019. This visa would allow third-country nationals at risk of persecution or harm to enter a Member State solely to apply for asylum, complementing—not replacing—existing national humanitarian entry schemes and resettlement programs. The proposed visa would require streamlined procedures: applications via embassies/consulates, security screenings, a 15-day processing window, appeal rights, and gender-sensitive assessments recognizing persecution based on gender-based violence (e.g., rape, forced marriage). Financial solidarity under Article 80 TFEU was emphasized, with EU funds covering costs, mirroring resettlement compensation. The resolution stressed the need for safe routes to reduce irregular migration, protect vulnerable groups (women, LGBTQI+ individuals, disabled persons), and align with international obligations, including the Refugee Convention and Istanbul Convention. It condemned unsafe practices like "disembarkation platforms" and urged gender-disaggregated data collection, specialized training for staff, and ratification of the Istanbul Convention by all Member States.

title: Follow-up to the European Parliament resolution of 12 March 2014 on the electronic mass surveillance of EU citizens: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the follow-up to the European Parliament resolution of 12 March 2014 on the electronic mass surveillance of EU citizens
background: Revelations of electronic mass surveillance programs affecting EU citizens, the 2014 European Parliament resolution on NSA activities, subsequent inquiries, and the 2015 CJEU ruling invalidating the Safe Harbour Decision highlighted concerns over data privacy. The Parliament will discuss balancing national security objectives with fundamental rights protections in electronic surveillance and cross-border data transfers.

stances.stance:
SD strongly advocates the issue's invalidation of the Safe Harbour Agreement and demand for equivalent data protection standards, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to shield EU citizens from mass surveillance.  
SD proposes enhancing judicial oversight mechanisms by establishing EU-wide definitions distinguishing national security from public security, ensuring consistent fundamental rights protections across all member states.  
SD fundamentally advocates the call for robust whistleblower protections and parliamentary scrutiny of intelligence services, reflecting SD's longstanding priority to uphold democratic accountability in surveillance practices.  
SD strongly approves the emphasis on European digital autonomy through open-source solutions and encryption, effectively advancing SD's manifesto goals for technological sovereignty against US surveillance-driven technologies.  
SD urges immediate Commission action to address emerging threats like the US CISA Act, maintaining full alignment with the issue's principles while strengthening transatlantic data governance frameworks.

ECR rejects the issue's call to suspend anti-terror agreements with the United States as fundamentally incompatible with their prioritization of security cooperation amid heightened threats in Europe.  
ECR opposes the issue's jurisdictional overreach, asserting that national security remains an exclusive member state competence under EU treaties, rendering Parliament's surveillance recommendations illegitimate.  
ECR condemns the issue's failure to uphold core Western legal principles by implicitly accepting state surveillance as default, directly contradicting their belief in strictly limiting government intrusion into civil liberties.  
ECR disputes the issue's reliance on unverified investigative findings from politically motivated inquiries lacking access to classified documents or sworn testimony.  
ECR dismisses the issue's focus on symbolic condemnations of surveillance instead of proposing actionable legislation with penalties for abuses and compensation mechanisms for victims.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over widespread electronic mass surveillance undermining EU citizens’ fundamental rights, particularly privacy and data protection, citing revelations of NSA activities, including espionage targeting French leaders and companies. It criticized Member States like France, the UK, and the Netherlands for expanding surveillance laws, urging compliance with EU law and the European Convention on Human Rights, and called on the Commission to assess France’s 2015 intelligence law. The resolution highlighted the invalidation of the EU-US Safe Harbour Agreement by the CJEU in October 2015, demanding immediate alternatives to ensure equivalent data protection and transparency on negotiations. It stressed the urgency of adopting the Data Protection Package by 2015, ensuring alignment with fundamental rights, and emphasized the need for judicial redress for EU citizens under the EU-US umbrella agreement, contingent on the US passing the Judicial Redress Act. The Parliament condemned inadequate Commission responses to prior recommendations, reserving the right to withhold budgetary resources until compliance. It advocated for stronger democratic oversight of intelligence services, including parliamentary scrutiny and sunset clauses for surveillance laws, and called for global standards on data protection to prevent a "surveillance arms race." The resolution urged IT independence through open-source software, enhanced encryption, and a European strategy for digital autonomy, while criticizing reliance on US surveillance-driven technologies. It also demanded protections for whistleblowers, journalists, and legal professionals, and pressed the Commission to address gaps in international data transfers and ensure remedies for surveillance victims by 2016.

title: Follow-up to the resolution of Parliament of 11 February 2015 on the US Senate report on the use of torture by the CIA: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on follow-up to the European Parliament resolution of 11 February 20015 on the US Senate report on the use of torture by the CIA
background: Revelations of EU member states' complicity in CIA secret detention and torture practices between 2001-2006, documented in the 2015 US Senate report and prior European investigations, prompted scrutiny of human rights violations on European territory. The Parliament will discuss member state accountability, counterterrorism compliance with international law, and obligations under human rights frameworks.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA entirely upholds the issue’s demand for criminal investigations into CIA black sites, perfectly aligning with their unyielding commitment to accountability for human rights violations.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the condemnation of state secrecy abuses, emphasizing that Italy’s obstruction in the Nasr and Ghali case exemplifies systemic impunity requiring urgent redress.  
GREEN_EFA entirely upholds the call to resettle Guantánamo detainees, reflecting their decades-long advocacy for victims of extraordinary rendition and unlawful detention.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the demand for a Commission White Paper, viewing this as essential to prevent national security pretexts from undermining democratic scrutiny.  
GREEN_EFA entirely upholds the issue’s systemic critique, affirming that transparency in counterterrorism operations is non-negotiable for upholding EU values.

ECR rejects the issue's infringement on member states' national security sovereignty, asserting counterterrorism as a core state responsibility under EU treaties.  
ECR opposes demands for EU-level criminal investigations into CIA black sites, deeming them beyond Parliament's legal authority under Article 4(2) TEU.  
ECR firmly condemns with the issue's failure to address terrorist threats to "our civilization," creating an imbalance between human rights and security imperatives.  
ECR criticizes the proposal's disregard for member states' sovereign discretion in classifying documents related to intelligence operations.  
ECR objects to prioritizing judicial scrutiny over counterterrorism efficacy, warning against paralyzing security frameworks through excessive transparency demands.

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns over the CIA’s rendition, secret detention, and torture programs between 2001 and 2006, implicating EU Member States in human rights violations, including unlawful detention, torture, enforced disappearances, and complicity through the use of European airspace and territory. It condemned the lack of accountability by Member States and the US, citing insufficient investigations, excessive reliance on state secrecy, and failure to prosecute perpetrators, despite evidence from the US Senate’s 2014 report and European Court of Human Rights rulings (e.g., Nasr and Ghali v Italy in 2016, which confirmed Italy’s use of state secrecy to shield officials involved in Abu Omar’s abduction). The resolution urged Lithuania, Poland, Romania, and Italy to conduct transparent criminal investigations into CIA black sites, declassify documents, and prosecute those responsible, while criticizing obstacles like undue document classification and slow judicial processes. It reiterated calls for the US to close Guantánamo Bay, ensure fair trials for detainees, prohibit torture, and cooperate with EU investigations, noting President Obama’s unmet 2010 closure pledge and his 2016 plan to Congress. The Parliament emphasized transatlantic cooperation rooted in human rights, rule of law, and accountability, urging the EU and US to align counterterrorism efforts with international law, and demanded a Commission White Paper clarifying limits on invoking national security to block scrutiny. It also pressed Member States to assist in resettling cleared Guantánamo detainees and ensure compliance with ECHR judgments, including Poland’s obligation to seek US assurances against the death penalty and Macedonia’s establishment of an independent investigatory body. The resolution highlighted systemic failures to address torture, enforced disappearances, and arbitrary detention, stressing the need for transparency and democratic accountability to uphold EU values.

title: Full application of the provisions of the Schengen acquis in Bulgaria and Romania: REPORT on the full application of the provisions of the Schengen acquis in Bulgaria and Romania: abolition of checks at internal land, sea and air borders
background: Bulgaria and Romania, EU members since 2007, completed Schengen evaluation requirements by 2011 but faced prolonged Council delays in abolishing internal border controls under the Schengen acquis. The Parliament will discuss their full integration into the Schengen Area.

stances.stance:
SD completely promotes the immediate adoption of a single legal act abolishing all internal border checks for Bulgaria and Romania, as this perfectly aligns with their 2011 fulfillment of Schengen criteria and SD's commitment to non-discriminatory European integration.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's rejection of phased accession, condemning the Council's seven-year delay as a politically motivated violation of the 2005 Accession Treaty's unified integration principle.  
SD completely promotes the economic urgency arguments, emphasizing that maintaining border controls imposes €2 billion annual operational costs while undermining cross-border trade and transport efficiency.  
SD strongly upholds the issue's linkage between Schengen integrity and EU credibility, noting that exclusion of compliant states like Bulgaria and Romania dangerously fuels anti-EU populism.  
SD perfectly aligns with demands for equal treatment of Balkan members, stressing that Romania and Bulgaria's exemplary management of EU external borders warrants full Schengen benefits without additional conditions.

ECR slightly sanctions the call for immediate Schengen integration but demands binding timelines to prevent indefinite political delays by member states.  
ECR requests revisions to Article 5 regarding border management, mandating joint patrols with objecting states like Austria to address migration concerns raised during evaluations.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of asymmetric implementation, failing to penalize existing members who maintain internal checks without justification.  
ECR firmly rejects the two-step approach as inconsistent with treaty obligations, but notes the issue's silence on compensation mechanisms for transport sector losses violates subsidiarity principles.  
This framework conflicts with ECR's insistence on national accountability by not requiring periodic audits of Frontex operations in Bulgaria and Romania as precondition for full accession.

resolution: The European Parliament raised that Bulgaria and Romania fulfilled all Schengen acquis requirements by 2011, including border management, data protection, and police cooperation, as confirmed by the Schengen Evaluation Working Group and the Council. Despite this, the Council has delayed full accession for seven years, deviating from the 2005 Act of Accession, which mandates a single legal act for abolishing internal border checks. Parliament criticized the Council’s proposed two-step approach (abolishing sea/air borders first, land borders later) as unjustified and inconsistent with prior Schengen enlargements, warning it risks fragmenting the EU, undermining trust, and fueling populism. It highlighted the economic costs of maintaining internal border controls, including estimated one-off costs of €0.05–20 billion and annual operational costs of €2 billion, disproportionately affecting cross-border trade, transport, and tourism. While welcoming partial integration steps, such as 2017 Visa Information System access and 2018 Schengen Information System proposals, Parliament stressed that Bulgaria and Romania currently bear Schengen obligations without full benefits. It urged the Council to adopt a single decision abolishing all internal border checks immediately, emphasizing that no additional criteria beyond the 2005 Act should apply, and called for Croatia’s swift Schengen accession upon meeting evaluation criteria. Parliament reiterated that prolonged delays erode EU credibility, exacerbate legislative gaps, and weaken the internal market, stressing Schengen’s role as a cornerstone of European integration.

title: Fundamental rights aspects in Roma integration in the EU: fighting anti-Gypsyism: REPORT on fundamental rights aspects in Roma integration in the EU: fighting anti-Gypsyism
background: Persistent structural discrimination against Roma communities across EU member states, including socioeconomic exclusion, educational segregation, housing inequalities, and healthcare disparities, compounded by historical persecution and rising anti-Gypsyism, has driven systemic human rights concerns. The Parliament will discuss EU policy frameworks for combating institutional racism and advancing Roma integration through fundamental rights protections.

stances.stance:
ENF rejects the issue’s condemnation of assimilation policies, advocating instead for full integration into national identities to prevent societal fragmentation.  
ENF opposes the issue’s perceived attack on nationalist MEPs’ freedom of expression, framing it as ideological exploitation of Roma issues.  
ENF entirely disputes with the issue’s anti-paternalism stance, insisting state-led assimilation is the only path to respect Roma dignity and social cohesion.  
ENF criticizes the issue’s neglect of communitarianism risks, arguing assimilation aligns with ENF’s principle of unified national communities over minority separatism.  
ENF overlooks systemic discrimination claims, prioritizing citizenship-based assimilation over structural equality measures deemed divisive to EU societies.

GREEN_EFA strongly accepts the issue's demand for national truth and reconciliation commissions, aligning with our decolonial justice principles by addressing centuries of systemic anti-Roma persecution through formal acknowledgment and reparations.  
GREEN_EFA entirely upholds designating 2 August as Roma Holocaust Memorial Day and compensating survivors, directly advancing our anti-fascist agenda and historical accountability frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the mandatory anti-bias training for officials as critical to dismantling institutional racism, though proposes enhancing monitoring of training outcomes through Roma-led evaluation committees.  
GREEN_EFA approves the gender-sensitive funding allocation requirements while urging explicit inclusion of compensation mechanisms for forced sterilization survivors in Article 9's healthcare provisions.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes that the proposed ESF resource reallocation must be paired with Roma co-management of funds to prevent misuse, reflecting our participatory governance priorities.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about pervasive anti-Gypsyism and systemic discrimination against Roma communities across the EU, emphasizing structural inequalities in access to housing, healthcare, education, employment, and justice. It highlighted alarming statistics, including 80% of Roma facing poverty risks, 47% of Roma children missing early education, 63% of young Roma not in employment or training (compared to a 12% EU average), and 41% experiencing discrimination in key areas. The resolution condemned forced evictions, segregation in substandard housing (e.g., 10,000 Roma evicted in France in 2016), segregated healthcare and education (e.g., 30.9% of Roma pupils in Czech special schools), and statelessness affecting thousands. It urged Member States to establish national and EU-level truth and reconciliation commissions to address historical persecution, enforce existing anti-discrimination laws (e.g., Racial Equality Directive), and allocate at least 20% of ESF resources to marginalized groups. The Parliament called for desegregation measures, improved Roma participation in policymaking, gender-sensitive strategies addressing intersectional discrimination against Roma women (e.g., forced sterilizations and healthcare neglect), and mandatory anti-bias training for public officials. It stressed the need for robust monitoring of EU funds, enhanced hate crime reporting, and a revised post-2020 EU Roma strategy prioritizing anti-Gypsyism. Additionally, it demanded restitution for Holocaust survivors, recognition of 2 August as Roma Holocaust Memorial Day, and urgent action to end statelessness, ensure birth registration, and provide equal access to utilities and justice.

title: Fundamental rights implications of big data: REPORT on fundamental rights implications of big data: privacy, data protection, non-discrimination, security and law-enforcement
background: Rapid growth of big data technologies, widespread collection of personal data through connected devices and online platforms, and increasing use of advanced analytics by public and private entities have raised concerns under EU legal frameworks. The Parliament will discuss fundamental rights implications regarding privacy, data protection, non-discrimination, and security in evolving data-driven decision-making.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA totally promotes the issue's strict GDPR enforcement requirements, perfectly aligning with their foundational principle that privacy protections must govern all big data processing.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the prohibition against algorithmic determination of criminal suspicion, affirming their stance that human oversight remains non-negotiable in law enforcement decision-making.  
GREEN_EFA fully supports the mandated security-by-design approach, recognizing encryption and pseudonymization as indispensable safeguards against emerging big data risks.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the emphasis on preventing discriminatory training data biases, a policy that directly advances their decades-long fight against structural inequality in technology.  
GREEN_EFA totally promotes the rejection of encryption backdoors, which aligns perfectly with their uncompromising defense of digital security and fundamental rights.

ECR rejects the issue's failure to impose absolute prohibitions on corporate profiling practices that subjugate individual freedoms to profit motives.  
The proposal fully conflicts with ECR's demand for uncompromised data protection by permitting conditional processing under GDPR exemptions.  
ECR opposes the inadequate safeguards against financial institutions creating consumer profiles, directly contradicting their principle that "freedom must not yield to bank interests".  
The issue's algorithmic accountability framework overlooks ECR's requirement for complete transparency in credit scoring and employment decision systems.  
ECR highlights the absence of criminal penalties for unlawful data monetization schemes, inconsistent with their stance on corporate accountability.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and outlined measures regarding the opportunities and risks of big data, emphasizing the need to balance innovation with fundamental rights protections. It highlighted the sector’s 40% annual growth rate, its potential in healthcare, climate action, and smart cities, and its risks to privacy, non-discrimination, and data security under the EU Charter and GDPR. The resolution stressed strict compliance with GDPR principles, including lawful processing, transparency, and data minimization, while advocating for pseudonymization, encryption, and anonymization to mitigate risks. It called for algorithmic accountability, transparency in automated decision-making, and guidelines to prevent biases in training data and discriminatory outcomes, particularly in law enforcement and predictive policing. The Parliament urged enhanced digital literacy, public awareness, and media pluralism to empower citizens, alongside stronger cooperation between regulators to ensure ethical standards, security, and legal certainty. It warned against mass surveillance and unlawful data access, emphasizing the need for human oversight in law enforcement decisions and secure, decentralized databases. The resolution also highlighted the importance of privacy-by-design, mandatory impact assessments, and restrictions on encryption backdoors, while encouraging ethical frameworks and sector-specific guidelines to address biases, ensure data quality, and uphold fundamental rights in both public and private sectors.

title: Internal Security Fund: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the Internal Security Fund
background: Growing cross-border security threats, including terrorism, organized crime, and cybercrime, alongside limitations in member states' individual capacities, prompted the European Commission to propose updating the Internal Security Fund (2014-2020) framework. The Parliament will discuss establishing the Internal Security Fund (2021-2027) to enhance cross-border law enforcement cooperation and address evolving security threats.

stances.stance:
SD strongly approves the issue’s emphasis on fundamental rights and cross-border cooperation, aligning perfectly with S&D’s commitment to human dignity and coordinated EU security frameworks.  
SD applauds the integration of education and training for law enforcement on fundamental rights, which directly advances S&D’s priority of combating systemic discrimination and racism.  
SD proposes extending fund accessibility to civil-military forces like the Carabinieri for domestic security tasks, provided activities remain strictly non-military and comply with civilian oversight principles.  
SD endorses the focus on preventing violent extremism through societal partnerships, reflecting S&D’s proactive stance on addressing root causes of radicalization.  
SD highlights the issue’s alignment with strengthening information-sharing mechanisms and joint investigative teams, critical to countering evolving transnational threats.

GUE_NGL rejects the drastic budget increase for the Internal Security Fund as contradictory to their stance against expanding securitization policies.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the inclusion of private financing through blending operations, which undermines public accountability and democratic oversight.  
GUE_NGL condemns the allocation of funds to intelligence agencies, citing their historical failures and incompatibility with civil liberties protections.  
This fundamentally disapproves with GUE_NGL's position that security frameworks must prioritize transparency and reject militarized surveillance.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as systemic accountability mechanisms for intelligence activities funded under the program.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a Commission proposal (COM(2018)0472) concerning legal measures under Articles 294(2), 82(1), 84, and 87(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which outlines judicial cooperation, crime prevention, and police collaboration frameworks. The resolution adopted Parliament’s first-reading stance, emphasizing the need for coherence with existing EU policies and safeguarding fundamental rights. It urged the Commission to resubmit the proposal if substantial revisions occur, ensuring parliamentary oversight. The resolution also mandated forwarding Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing transparency and institutional alignment. Procedural elements, such as committee reports or voting specifics, were excluded to focus on substantive legal and policy commitments.

title: Listing the third countries whose nationals must be in possession of visas when crossing the external borders and those whose nationals are exempt from that requirement (Kosovo): REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 listing the third countries whose nationals must be in possession of visas when crossing the external borders and those whose nationals are exempt from that requirement (Kosovo*)
background: Kosovo, a potential EU candidate, fulfilled EU-mandated visa liberalization benchmarks including border demarcation with Montenegro and anti-corruption reforms, as confirmed by the Commission in 2018, remaining the only Western Balkan country without visa-free EU access. The Parliament will discuss amending visa regulations to exempt Kosovo nationals from short-stay visa requirements.

stances.stance:
ENF absolutely disapproves the visa exemption proposal as it disregards Kosovo's systemic criminal networks and heroin smuggling routes into the EU, directly contradicting border security priorities.  
ENF rejects the measure for legitimizing Kosovo's illegal 100% tariffs against Serbia and unauthorized army creation, which violate regional stability agreements.  
ENF opposes rewarding Kosovo's institutional discrimination against Serbs, including documented religious persecution and professional exclusion tactics.  
ENF condemns the issue's implicit recognition of Kosovo's contested statehood, conflicting with five EU members' sovereignty positions.  
ENF highlights the proposal's failure to address Dutch mission reports confirming Kosovo's law enforcement collusion with Colombian drug cartels.

ALDE supports the visa liberalization for Kosovo, commending its fulfillment of border demarcation and anti-corruption requirements as pivotal to advancing EU-Kosovo relations.  
ALDE advises expediting Council adoption of the proposal to end prolonged delays, ensuring the EU upholds its credibility as a partner committed to merit-based reforms.  
ALDE emphasizes the strategic benefits of visa-free travel, including strengthened cultural ties, economic collaboration, and reduced incentives for irregular migration.  
ALDE urges strict adherence to legislative transparency provisions, ensuring Parliament’s immediate re-engagement if procedural or substantive changes to the proposal emerge.  
ALDE calls for sustained EU support to Kosovo’s rule-of-law frameworks post-liberalization, aligning with long-term stability goals in the Western Balkans.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position by adopting the Commission’s 2016 proposal (COM(2016)0277) on the basis of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs’ report (A8-0261/2016), endorsing the original text without amendments at first reading. It emphasized the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial changes or replacements to the proposal arise, ensuring legislative transparency. The resolution, rooted in Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union provisions (Articles 77(2) and 294), focused on procedural cooperation, instructing the Parliament’s President to formally transmit its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to advance the legislative process.

title: Listing the third countries whose nationals must be in possession of visas when crossing the external borders and those whose nationals are exempt from that requirement (Kosovo*): REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 listing the third countries whose nationals must be in possession of visas when crossing the external borders and those whose nationals are exempt from that requirement (Kosovo*)
background: The EU initiated a visa liberalization dialogue with Kosovo in 2012, requiring fulfillment of 95 benchmarks, including border demarcation with Montenegro and anti-corruption reforms. The European Commission confirmed compliance in 2018, but Kosovo remained the only Western Balkan jurisdiction without visa-free access. The Parliament will discuss amending Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 to align Kosovo’s visa status.

stances.stance:
ENF rejects the visa exemption for Kosovo, citing unresolved criminal networks and smuggling routes that threaten EU security, firmly doubting with ENF's border protection priorities.  
ENF opposes the proposal due to Kosovo's unilateral tariff impositions and military restructuring, which violate international agreements and undermine regional stability.  
ENF condemns the issue for ignoring systemic discrimination against Serb minorities in Kosovo, directly contradicting ENF's stance on human rights protections.  
ENF challenges the legitimacy of Kosovo's statehood recognition, arguing that visa liberalization rewards a disputed territory born from NATO intervention, inconsistent with ENF's sovereignty principles.  
ENF warns that visa-free access accelerates Kosovo's EU accession prospects, opposing integration of what they deem a non-compliant entity into European structures.

GREEN_EFA strongly upholds the merit-based approach to visa liberalization, aligning perfectly with their commitment to fair and equitable EU policy-making.  
GREEN_EFA applauds Kosovo’s fulfillment of all 95 reform criteria as a decisive step toward regional integration and justice, advancing their priority of stabilizing the Western Balkans.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the necessity of maintaining transparent inter-institutional dialogue, particularly to address concerns from member states yet to recognize Kosovo’s independence.  
GREEN_EFA proposes reinforcing parliamentary oversight mechanisms to ensure future amendments uphold the issue’s core principles without political interference.  
GREEN_EFA encourages all member states to base their stance on Kosovo’s visa exemption solely on achieved merits, reflecting the Greens’ rejection of geopolitical bargaining.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position by adopting the Commission’s proposal (COM(2016)0277) at first reading, affirming alignment with the original text. It emphasized that the Commission must re-engage Parliament if proposing significant amendments or replacing the proposal entirely, ensuring legislative transparency and procedural accountability. Additionally, Parliament instructed its President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, the Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing inter-institutional dialogue. The resolution referenced legal bases under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (Articles 294(2), 294(3), and 77(2)) and procedural frameworks, but focused on upholding the Commission’s initial legislative initiative while safeguarding parliamentary oversight over potential substantive changes.

title: Provisional measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece: REPORT on the proposal for a Council decision establishing provisional measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece
background: Increased Mediterranean migration flows placed significant strain on Italy and Greece, with rising asylum applications overwhelming national capacities under the Dublin III Regulation’s first-entry responsibility framework. The Parliament will discuss establishing provisional EU measures to address disproportionate frontline state burdens in international protection.

stances.stance:
ENF rejects fundamentally the redistribution quotas for failing to distinguish between economic migrants and refugees, conflicting with ENF's demand for stringent eligibility criteria.  
ENF opposes the issue's neglect of pre-2015 arrivals, which undermines repatriation guarantees and contradicts ENF's insistence on retroactive enforcement.  
The proposal overlooks ENF's core principle of preserving Europe's ethnic and cultural homogeneity by institutionalizing mass relocation, risking irreversible demographic shifts.  
ENF condemns the omission of offshore processing centers in North Africa, a measure ENF advocates to deter illegal crossings and address migration at its source.  
This firmly condemns with ENF's stance against incentivizing illegal immigration through welfare access, which the issue implicitly enables.

SD fundamentally upholds the issue as a critical first step toward establishing a permanent binding mechanism to replace the obsolete Dublin Regulation, perfectly aligning with S&D's demands for structural solidarity.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's operational focus on accelerating hotspot implementation and dismantling trafficking networks, advancing S&D's manifesto priorities for humane border management.  
SD fundamentally upholds the issue's recognition of migration as a pan-European challenge requiring collective action, effectively advancing S&D's longstanding rejection of "Mediterranean-only" approaches.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's foundation in treaty-based solidarity principles, mirroring S&D's insistence on transforming temporary measures into permanent responsibility-sharing systems.  
SD fundamentally upholds leveraging this issue to immediately launch long-term EU asylum reforms, aligning with S&D's April 2023 roadmap for mandatory relocation quotas and conflict issue diplomacy.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2015 proposal (COM(2015)0286) under Article 78(3) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, approving the proposal as amended and endorsing an annexed statement outlining its stance. It called on the Commission to revise its proposal in line with Parliament’s amendments under Article 293(2) TFEU and urged the Council to notify Parliament if it intends to deviate from the approved text or substantially amend the proposal, requiring renewed consultation. The resolution emphasized adherence to procedural safeguards, ensuring Parliament’s input in subsequent legislative steps, and instructed its President to formally transmit Parliament’s position to the Council and Commission.

title: Public access to documents for the years 2014-2015: REPORT on public access to documents (Rule 116(7)) for the years 2014-2015
background: Regulation 1049/2001 governs public access to EU documents, with post-Lisbon Treaty amendments expanding transparency obligations. Persistent concerns over institutional compliance, document classification, and legislative process opacity prompted ongoing reviews. The Parliament will discuss enhancing transparency mechanisms and public access to documents across EU institutions to strengthen democratic accountability and administrative openness.

stances.stance:
EPP supports enhancing transparency through updated Regulation 1049/2001 and urges the Council to expedite its revision, aligning with democratic accountability goals.  
EPP advises implementing a unified digital portal for document access across EU institutions to simplify citizen engagement, mirroring successful models like Your Europe.  
EPP recommends balancing trilogue transparency with necessary confidentiality to maintain effective legislative negotiations while increasing public scrutiny of outcomes.  
EPP emphasizes maintaining privacy protections alongside transparency measures, distinguishing responsible access from uncontrolled disclosure practices.  
EPP advocates for strengthening transparency in international agreements while ensuring negotiators retain flexibility to reach consensus in complex discussions.

GUE_NGL strongly accepts the issue’s emphasis on democratic accountability through transparency, aligning perfectly with their commitment to combating corporate secrecy in agreements like TTIP and CETA.  
GUE_NGL proposes enhancing Article 3 to explicitly mandate proactive disclosure of all international negotiation documents, addressing concerns about unequal lobbyist access raised in TTIP debates.  
GUE_NGL applauds the demand for a mandatory EU lobby register but urges extending its scope to include real-time disclosure of corporate influence in trade negotiations.  
GUE_NGL highlights the need to strengthen provisions on ECB transparency, advocating for binding rules to end its exemption from public scrutiny over banking supervision documents.  
GUE_NGL endorses the condemnation of over-classification but suggests stricter penalties for institutions violating Regulation 1049/2001, particularly regarding access to infringement procedures.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over insufficient transparency and access to EU documents, stressing that full transparency is essential for democratic accountability, citizen trust, and compliance with the Lisbon Treaty and the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. It criticized institutions for failing to implement past recommendations, including appointing Transparency Officers and updating Regulation (EC) No 1049/2001 to reflect post-Lisbon Treaty obligations, notably extending its scope to all EU bodies like the European Council and European Central Bank. The resolution highlighted the need for proactive disclosure of legislative and administrative documents, simplified access procedures, and harmonized digital platforms to improve accessibility, while condemning over-classification of documents and unjustified in-camera meetings. It emphasized the lack of transparency in trilogue negotiations, urging publication of agendas, minutes, and outcomes to prevent unequal access by lobbyists and ensure public scrutiny. The Parliament called for a mandatory EU lobby register with detailed disclosures, stronger whistleblower protections, and publication of infringement procedure documents and Structural Fund beneficiaries to combat fraud. It welcomed the European Court of Justice’s reliance on the Charter in cases like *Digital Rights Ireland* and *Schrems*, which invalidated the Data Retention Directive and Safe Harbour Decision, and urged institutions to align document management with Articles 41 and 42 of the Charter. The resolution also demanded faster revision of Regulation 1049/2001, stalled in the Council, to incorporate CJEU jurisprudence and environmental transparency under the Aarhus Convention, and criticized the ECB for lagging in transparency despite publishing Governing Council minutes. Additionally, it pushed for transparency in international agreements, delegated acts, and administrative processes, and highlighted the Interinstitutional Committee’s inactivity since 2009, urging regular meetings with civil society input. The Parliament reiterated demands for public access to legislative documents, plenary amendment co-signatories, and accountability for EU funds, while advocating for standardized conflict-of-interest rules across agencies and improved reporting on Member States’ use of EU funds.

title: Implementation of the European Protection Order Directive: REPORT on the implementation of Directive 2011/99/EU on the European Protection Order
background: The European Protection Order Directive (2011/99/EU), established to enable cross-border recognition of judicial protection measures for crime victims, faced divergent national implementations, limited awareness among authorities and victims, and low uptake despite high rates of gender-based violence in the EU. The Parliament will discuss challenges in harmonizing victim protection mechanisms across member states.

stances.stance:
ALDE strongly sanctions the harmonization of EPO procedures through unified digital platforms, aligning with their commitment to eliminating cross-border legal barriers for violence survivors.  
ALDE endorses binding timelines for member states to implement victim support mechanisms, proposing a 12-month ratification deadline for Istanbul Convention provisions on protection orders.  
ALDE emphasizes the critical need for EU-funded training networks for legal professionals, enhancing cross-border recognition of protection measures through standardized competency frameworks.  
ALDE applauds the issue's focus on gender-based violence classification under Article 83(1) TFEU, urging immediate budgetary allocations for crisis center expansion in low-compliance regions.  
ALDE recommends integrating real-time language interpretation services into EPO application processes to address the issue's identified gaps in migrant victim accessibility.

ECR completely rejects the issue's alignment with the Istanbul Convention, which they deem an ideological overreach incompatible with national legal traditions.  
ECR rejects the characterization of systemic misogyny in European societies, arguing this imposes foreign cultural narratives rather than addressing individual behavioral causes like substance abuse.  
ECR criticizes the focus on cross-border protection orders as ineffective without prioritizing preventive measures against root causes such as gambling and alcohol dependency.  
ECR disputes standardized EU-wide procedures, asserting they disregard member states' competence to address domestic violence through localized solutions.  
ECR highlights the issue's failure to respect subsidiarity in education policies by proposing curriculum interventions beyond EU treaty mandates.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about significant obstacles in implementing European Protection Orders (EPOs), including inconsistent application across Member States due to divergent national measures, insufficient awareness among victims and professionals, and inadequate data collection, with only seven EPOs issued despite thousands of national protection orders. It highlighted the impact on victims, noting that one in three women in the EU experiences physical or sexual violence, yet low reporting rates persist due to fear, stigma, and lack of resources like shelters, legal aid, and translation services. The resolution emphasized the need to align EPOs with complementary frameworks, particularly the Istanbul Convention, urging its ratification and EU accession to strengthen protections against gender-based violence. Recommendations included standardizing EPO procedures through a unified digital form, establishing EU and national registries for data tracking, ensuring free legal aid and interpretation services, and launching awareness campaigns targeting victims, professionals, and the public. It called for enhanced cross-border cooperation, mandatory training for authorities, and leveraging technology like GPS monitoring to improve enforcement. The Parliament also stressed the urgency of addressing systemic gaps, such as underfunded support services, and advocated for classifying gender-based violence as an EU crime under Article 83(1) TFEU to harmonize legal responses and ensure victim safety across borders.

title: Instrument for financial support for border management and visa: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing, as part of the Integrated Border Management Fund, the instrument for financial support for border management and visa
background: Increased migratory pressures, persistent internal border controls challenging Schengen integrity, and demands for enhanced EU external border security prompted the Commission's proposal. The Parliament will discuss establishing a financial instrument to support integrated border management and common visa policies.

stances.stance:
SD completely sanctions the issue’s establishment of financial solidarity for integrated border management, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to balancing security with free movement as a cornerstone of European integration.  
SD perfectly aligns with the imperative to quintuple funding for external border controls under the 2021–2027 framework, recognizing this as essential to uphold Schengen’s integrity while rejecting populist attempts to externalize refugee responsibilities.  
SD emphasizes that the instrument’s human rights safeguards, including non-refoulement and non-discrimination principles, reflect SD’s unwavering prioritization of dignity in migration governance.  
SD applauds the issue’s insistence on interinstitutional coherence, urging the Council to match border security investments with equitable asylum policy advancements to fulfill the EU’s moral stature.  
SD underscores that protecting free movement through shared visa policy harmonization epitomizes the Union’s acquis, directly advancing SD’s vision of a Europe rooted in solidarity and mobility.

ECR totally doubts the issue's diversion from core border security priorities, conflicting with their demand for robust external controls.  
ECR rejects the failure to address critical hotspot overcrowding as seen in Moria and Samos, despite substantial EU funding allocations.  
ECR condemns the proposal's inadequate measures against illegal crossings at Greek-Albanian borders, where Frontex presence remains ineffective.  
ECR opposes the systemic neglect of customs fraud prevention mechanisms required to protect border communities from criminal networks.  
The proposal overlooks critical surveillance infrastructure needs like thermal cameras, directly contradicting ECR's border hardening agenda.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2018 proposal (COM(2018)0473) concerning legal migration and integration policies under Articles 77(2) and 79(2)(d) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, incorporating input from the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, alongside opinions from the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Committee on Budgets (A8-0089/2019). It formally adopted its first-reading stance, urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments to ensure legislative alignment, and instructed its President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to uphold procedural transparency and interinstitutional coherence.

title: Multiannual Framework for the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights for 2018-2022: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision establishing a Multiannual Framework for the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights for 2018–2022
background: The EU Agency for Fundamental Rights (FRA), established under Regulation 168/2007, requires a five-year thematic framework. Post-Lisbon Treaty integration of EU law necessitated alignment of FRA’s scope. The Parliament will discuss the 2018-2022 framework proposal, determining priority areas for the agency’s fundamental rights monitoring and advisory activities.

stances.stance:
ENF rejects the issue's emphasis on migrant integration as entirely conflicting with ENF's stance on cultural assimilation and border protection.  
ENF opposes the allocation of funds to the FRA, denouncing it as a bureaucratic failure that prioritizes "islamofobie" over addressing security threats from radical ideologies.  
ENF entirely conflicts with the Agency's communitarian approach to religious expression in public spaces, which undermines France's republican model of secular integration.  
The proposal's inclusion of police cooperation frameworks is opposed by ENF as an unacceptable expansion into national sovereignty domains.  
ENF condemns the issue's failure to prioritize citizen safety over immigrant rights, citing the Manchester attack as evidence of misplaced priorities.

ALDE entirely promotes the expanded mandate of the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights, which perfectly aligns with their longstanding commitment to upholding fundamental rights across all EU policies, particularly in police cooperation and judicial domains.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s inclusion of critical thematic priorities such as combating discrimination and protecting privacy, effectively advancing their priority of ensuring comprehensive rights monitoring post-Lisbon Treaty.  
ALDE emphasizes the necessity of swiftly implementing the amended Regulation (EC) No 168/2007 to fully empower the Agency in addressing judicial cooperation, ensuring alignment with EU legal frameworks.  
ALDE underscores the importance of enhancing the FRA’s operational independence and self-initiative capabilities to robustly defend rule-of-law values against systemic threats.  
ALDE celebrates the issue’s alignment with their vision for a strong, impartial Agency capable of addressing emerging challenges in migration, asylum, and Roma integration.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the Council decision amending Regulation (EC) No 168/2007 to expand the mandate of the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights (FRA), aligning it with the Lisbon Treaty by replacing references to the "European Community" with "European Union." The resolution broadened the FRA’s scope to include police cooperation (previously excluded under the 'ex-third pillar'), enhancing its role in monitoring fundamental rights across EU policies. Key thematic priorities outlined include access to justice for victims of crime; combating discrimination based on sex, race, ethnicity, religion, disability, age, sexual orientation, or nationality; protecting privacy and personal data in the information society; judicial cooperation (excluding criminal matters); migration, asylum, and refugee integration; addressing racism and xenophobia; safeguarding children’s rights; and promoting Roma integration and social inclusion. The Parliament emphasized the FRA’s expanded competence to address these areas, particularly in policing, while ensuring alignment with EU legal frameworks post-Lisbon Treaty.

title: Situation of fundamental rights in the EU in 2016: REPORT on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU in 2016
background: In 2016, the EU faced challenges including migration inflows, rule of law concerns in member states, systemic discrimination against minorities, hate speech proliferation, and security measures impacting civil liberties. The Parliament will discuss the state of fundamental rights, focusing on governance adherence, migration policy compliance, minority protections, and countering intolerance within EU frameworks.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly accepts the issue's emphasis on activating Article 7 TEU to safeguard judicial independence and rule of law, aligning perfectly with GREEN_EFA's longstanding commitment to holding Member States accountable for systemic rights violations.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing monitoring mechanisms to address cases where national courts disproportionately restrict political freedoms, as seen in Catalonia, through clearer EU guidelines on proportionality in protest-related charges.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the focus on protecting minority rights and combating hate speech, which effectively advances their priority of defending linguistic minorities and LGBTI communities against state-backed discrimination.  
GREEN_EFA urges stricter application of corruption investigations under Article 325 TFEU to prevent misuse of EU funds in states with deteriorating rule of law, reinforcing the issue's anti-corruption goals.  
GREEN_EFA endorses creating safe migration pathways but suggests expanding family reunification clauses to prevent prolonged separations that fuel xenophobic narratives.

ECR rejects the issue's emphasis on ratifying the Istanbul Convention as a violation of subsidiarity and an imposition of ideological frameworks on member states.  
ECR opposes fundamentally the issue’s approach to hate speech definitions, arguing it conflates dissent with extremism and stifles pluralistic debate on social values.  
ECR condemns the issue’s failure to address EU complicity in austerity-driven violations of social rights, particularly in Greece, which contradicts ECR’s defense of national economic sovereignty.  
ECR disputes the issue’s characterization of dissenters as "fanatics" or "bigots," asserting this undermines free expression and democratic disagreement on cultural issues.  
ECR rejects migration policies advocating centralized EU solidarity mechanisms, citing conflicts with national sovereignty over integration and border control.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over systemic violations of EU fundamental values, emphasizing that respect for human dignity, democracy, rule of law, and minority rights are prerequisites for EU cohesion. It stressed the Commission’s obligation to enforce Treaty compliance, urging the use of Article 7 TEU as a tangible tool against Member States undermining judicial independence, separation of powers, or migrant rights. Highlighting migration challenges, it noted 27% of Mediterranean arrivals in 2016 were children, many lacking education, and condemned dangerous routes exploited by traffickers, urging safe legal pathways and solidarity in reception policies. The resolution condemned rising hate speech, fake news, and xenophobia, particularly targeting Muslims, Roma, LGBTI individuals, and minorities, citing 33% of women experiencing physical/sexual violence and 20% facing online harassment. It called for harmonized definitions of hate crimes, enhanced police training, and stricter regulation of online platforms. Addressing discrimination, it urged ratification of the Istanbul Convention, protection of minority languages (spoken by 10% of citizens), and legal gender recognition without medical requirements. The Parliament advocated for EU-wide mechanisms to monitor rule of law, corruption, and governance, alongside integration policies for migrants, including education, healthcare, and family reunification. It emphasized combating trafficking, protecting children, and ensuring digital rights, while promoting civil society and NGO roles. Specific directives on equality, asylum, and victims’ rights were reiterated, alongside calls for data collection on inequalities and intersex rights violations.

title: Report of the extraordinary European Council meeting (23 April 2015) - The latest tragedies in the Mediterranean and EU migration and asylum policies: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the latest tragedies in the Mediterranean and EU migration and asylum policies
background: Recurring migrant deaths in the Mediterranean, increased arrivals in Italy and Greece, instability in Libya and conflicts in Syria/Eritrea, and smuggling networks exploiting migration routes prompted EU action. The Parliament will discuss migration and asylum policies, focusing on search-and-rescue obligations, solidarity mechanisms, and addressing root causes of displacement.

stances.stance:
SD fully sanctions the binding asylum-seeker quotas and mandatory solidarity mechanisms, perfectly aligning with their decades-long advocacy for EU-wide burden-sharing principles.  
SD perfectly supports tripling Triton's operational capacity and restoring Mare Nostrum-level search protocols, recognizing this as essential to fulfilling humanitarian obligations under international law.  
SD fully sanctions utilizing Article 78(3) TFEU to activate emergency refugee redistribution, viewing this treaty-based approach as legally and morally non-negotiable.  
SD perfectly aligns with criminalizing maritime abandonment by traffickers through Europol-led joint investigations, mirroring their 2014 proposals to combat organized cross-border crime.  
SD fully sanctions immediate activation of the Temporary Protection Directive (2001/55/EC) for Mediterranean arrivals, considering this existing legal tool vital for crisis-response coherence.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue’s focus on border control and criminalization as fundamentally incompatible with their demand for open legal migration pathways and accountability for EU militarism.  
GUE_NGL opposes the emphasis on anti-trafficking operations, arguing this ignores the EU’s role in creating migration flows through wars in Libya/Syria and economic exploitation.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s failure to mandate binding refugee quotas, which perpetuates the “Fortress Europe” model denounced by Albiol Guzmán as “hypocritical grave-digging.”  
GUE_NGL disputes the legitimacy of EU-Turkey or Eritrea collaborations cited in the issue, aligning with Spinelli’s condemnation of “collaboration with dictatorships” violating refugee rights.  
GUE_NGL demands abolition of Frontex and Triton, citing Ernst’s critique that these agencies prioritize “border defense over rescue” and enable systemic drownings.

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns over the recurring loss of lives in the Mediterranean, citing over 1,500 migrant deaths since early 2015 and over 23,900 arrivals in Italy and 10,445 rescues by Greek authorities in the first quarter of 2015. It highlighted the critical role of search and rescue operations, noting that Operation Triton—funded at €2.9 million monthly, far below Mare Nostrum’s €9 million—rescued over 24,400 migrants but stressed the need for expanded mandates, increased funding, and EU-wide solidarity to address the crisis. The resolution urged Member States to enhance support for Frontex and the European Asylum Support Office (EASO), establish binding asylum-seeker quotas, and utilize humanitarian visas or temporary protection mechanisms under EU law. It condemned human traffickers, whose activities generate €20 billion annually, and called for stronger criminal sanctions, cross-border cooperation with agencies like Europol, and dismantling networks linked to terrorism and organized crime. Emphasizing root causes—conflict in Syria, Iraq, Libya, and Eritrea, and ISIS expansion—the Parliament advocated for EU foreign policy coherence, development aid, and governance reforms in origin countries. It also stressed holistic migration policies, including safe legal pathways, asylum system harmonization, and collaboration with transit nations to ensure compliance with international law and refugee rights.

title: Rights and Values programme: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the Rights and Values programme
background: Rising concerns over democratic backsliding, threats to judicial independence, media freedom, and civil society in some EU states, alongside attacks on public figures and systemic discrimination, prompted calls for strengthened EU mechanisms. The Parliament will discuss establishing a dedicated Rights and Values programme to reinforce foundational EU principles and address rule-of-law challenges.

stances.stance:
SD strongly accepts the increased financial allocation to civil society organizations, emphasizing their critical role in combating racism, xenophobia, and gender-based violence, which aligns perfectly with SD’s longstanding commitment to social cohesion and pluralism.  
SD approves the integration of democratic participation initiatives, particularly grassroots projects empowering youth and marginalized communities, as this effectively advances SD’s priority of fostering active citizenship and countering divisive narratives.  
SD endorses the issue’s focus on protecting EU foundational values against nationalist extremism, highlighting its alignment with SD’s unwavering advocacy for tolerance, solidarity, and rule-of-law safeguards.  
SD proposes amending Article 4 to explicitly prioritize funding for civil society in member states where governments actively undermine democratic norms, ensuring targeted support for vulnerable communities in contexts like Hungary and Poland.  
SD applauds the inclusion of intercultural and interreligious dialogue as a program pillar, which perfectly aligns with SD’s vision of a fraternal Europe built on shared historical awareness and inclusive citizenship education.

ECR rejects the programme's exclusion of explicit protections against anti-Christian hatred, fully againsting with Treaty Article 17's recognition of religious heritage.  
ECR opposes the allocation of €2 billion to NGOs as fostering misuse risks, citing past mismanagement in migration funding as evidence of structural flaws.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of religious persecution, failing to address 556 documented attacks on Orthodox Christian institutions in Greece during 2017.  
ECR opposes the prioritisation of "social-cultural gender" and sexual orientation frameworks, arguing this creates ideological imposition inconsistent with subsidiarity.  
ECR condemns the programme as a vehicle for centralised democratic control, contradicting principles of national sovereignty in cultural and religious matters.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2018 proposal (COM(2018)0383) by adopting a first-reading stance, emphasizing the need to align the legislative act with Treaty provisions, particularly Articles 16(2), 19(2), 21(2), 24, 167, and 168 of the TFEU. It underscored the importance of integrating input from multiple committees, including Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs; Culture and Education; Women’s Rights and Gender Equality; Budgets; Employment and Social Affairs; Legal Affairs; and Constitutional Affairs. The resolution urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if it substantially amends or replaces its original proposal, ensuring legislative transparency and procedural accountability. Additionally, Parliament instructed its President to formally communicate its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing inter-institutional dialogue and adherence to EU legislative processes.

title: Rule of law in Malta: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the rule of law in Malta
background: The assassination of Maltese journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia, known for investigating corruption and money laundering involving high-ranking officials, occurred amid concerns over media freedom risks, judicial appointments, and Malta's citizenship investment program. The Parliament will discuss rule of law, anti-corruption frameworks, and institutional safeguards in Malta.

stances.stance:
EPP totally accepts the issue's demand for an independent international investigation into Daphne Caruana Galizia's assassination, perfectly aligning with EPP's foundational principle that impunity for attacks on journalists constitutes existential threats to EU democracy.
